Book: Al-Mustajad min Fa'alat al-Ajwad (The Selected Anecdotes of the Deeds of the Generous)
Author: Al-Muhsin bin Ali bin Muhammad bin Abi al-Fahm Dawud al-Tanukhi al-Basri, Abu Ali (d. 384 AH)
[The book is automatically numbered and does not correspond to the printed version]

In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. In Him is my trust.
Praise be to Allah, the Possessor of generosity and kindness, the Bestower of blessings and favors. May Allah bless the best of those who walked on foot, the Chosen One sent to all nations, Muhammad bin Abdullah, our savior from error and darkness, and upon his family, companions, and wives, and grant them peace.
Now then, may Allah prolong your life in grace, improve your deeds with piety, let you reach your hopes in safety, and end your term with righteous deeds. You requested that I collect for you the best reports of the generous and the most sublime and guided deeds of the noble. I sought Allah's guidance in speech and selected what occurred to me at the moment, which I believe will provoke the reader and listener and be highly regarded by them. I composed it into a book which I named 'Al-Mustajad min Fa'alat al-Ajwad' (The Selected Deeds of the Generous), so it would match its title, suit your purpose, and surpass what is considered good. My success is only through Allah; upon Him I rely and to Him I turn.

**Anecdotes of the Generous**

**Anecdote:** It is narrated that Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, slept in the bed of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, when Quraysh conspired to kill him, sacrificing himself for him. Allah Almighty revealed to Gabriel and Michael: 'I have established brotherhood between you and made the lifespan of one of you longer than the other. You have the choice: which of you will prefer his companion with life?' Each of them loved life and chose it. Allah revealed to them: 'Why were you not like Ali bin Abi Talib? I established brotherhood between him and My Prophet Muhammad, and he settled in his bed and Ali slept on it, sacrificing himself and preferring him with life. Descend to Earth and protect him from his enemy.' So Gabriel was at his head and Michael at his feet, and Gabriel was calling out: 'Excellent, excellent! Who is like you, O son of Abi Talib? Allah boasts of you to the angels.' Then Allah revealed: (And of the people is he who sells himself, seeking means to the approval of Allah).

**Anecdote:** A man asked Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with them, for a need. He said to him: 'O you, the right of your request to me is great in my eyes, and my knowledge of what is due to you weighs heavily upon me. My hand falls short of giving you what you deserve, and much is little in the essence of Allah. What I own is not enough to repay your gratitude. If you accept the available ease and relieve me of the burden of straining and concern to undertake what is your due, I will do it.' The man said: 'O son of the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, I accept the little, thank the gift, and excuse the withholding.' Al-Hasan called his agent and began accounting him for his expenses until he exhausted them. Then he said: 'Bring the surplus from the three hundred thousand.' He brought fifty thousand. He asked: 'What did you do with the five hundred dinars?' He said: 'They are with me.' He said: 'Bring them.' They were brought, and he gave the dirhams and dinars to the man and said: 'Bring someone to carry them for you.' He brought two porters, and Al-Hasan gave them his cloak as payment for the carrying. His clients said to him: 'By Allah, we do not have a single dirham.' He said: 'But I hope to have a great reward with Allah.'

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Hasan al-Mada'ini said: Al-Hasan, Al-Husayn (may Allah be pleased with them), and Abdullah bin Ja'far went out for Hajj. Their luggage went ahead of them, so they became hungry and thirsty. They passed by an old woman in a tent of hers. One of them said to her: 'Is there any drink?' She said: 'Yes.' They dismounted at her place. She had nothing but a small sheep in the corner of the tent. She said: 'Milk it and drink its milk mixed with water.' They did so. Then they said to her: 'Is there any food?' She said: 'No, except this sheep. Let one of you slaughter it so I can prepare some of it for you to eat.' One of them stood up, slaughtered and skinned it. Then she prepared food for them, and they ate and stayed until it cooled down. When they departed, they said to her: 'We are a group from Quraysh intending this direction. If we return safely, visit us, for we will do good to you.' Then they departed. Her husband arrived, and she informed him about the people and the sheep. He got angry and said: 'Woe to you! You slaughter my sheep for people you don't know, then say they are a group from Quraysh?'

Then after some time, need drove them to enter Medina. They entered it and began transporting dung and selling it, living off its price. The old woman passed through some of the alleys of Medina and saw Al-Hasan bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, sitting at the door of his house. He recognized the old woman, but she did not recognize him. He sent his servant to her, called her, and said: 'O maidservant of Allah, do you know me?' She said: 'No.' He said: 'I was your guest on such and such day.' She said: 'By my father and mother, you are he!' He then ordered that a thousand sheep from the charity sheep be bought for her, and he ordered a thousand dinars for her with them. He sent her with his servant to Al-Husayn, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Husayn asked her: 'How much did my brother give you?' She said: 'A thousand sheep and a thousand dinars.' So Al-Husayn ordered the like for her. Then he sent her with his servant to Abdullah bin Ja'far. He asked her: 'How much did Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn give you?' She said: 'Two thousand sheep and two thousand dinars.' Abdullah ordered two thousand sheep and two thousand dinars for her, and said to her: 'If you had started with me, I would have exhausted them (i.e., given more to outdo them).' The old woman returned to her husband with four thousand dinars and four thousand sheep.

**Anecdote:** From Muhammad bin al-Munkadir from Umm Dharrah, who used to serve Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. She said: Ibn al-Zubayr sent her money in two sacks, totaling one hundred and eighty thousand. She called for a tray and began distributing it among the people until it was finished. When evening came, she said: 'O girl, bring my breakfast (to break fast).' She brought her bread and oil. Umm Dharrah said to her: 'Could you not, from what you distributed today, buy us meat for a dirham to break our fast with?' She said: 'If you had reminded me, I would have done so.'

**Anecdote:** Mus'ab bin al-Zubayr said: Muawiyah performed Hajj. When he departed, he passed by Medina. Al-Husayn bin Ali said to his brother Al-Hasan, may Allah be pleased with them: 'Do not meet him or greet him.' When Muawiyah left, Al-Hasan said: 'O brother, we have a debt, and we must go to him.' He caught up with him at Thaniyat al-Nawl, while he was descending into the valley. He greeted him and informed him of his debt. He ordered eighty thousand dinars to be poured out for him. He [the camel carrying it] had become tired and lagged behind the camels, with people driving it. Muawiyah said: 'What is this?' It was mentioned to him. He said: 'Send it with what is on it to Abu Muhammad.' So he took it and returned.

**Anecdote:** The Quran readers of Basra gathered to Ibn Abbas while he was the governor of Basra. They said: 'We have a neighbor who fasts and prays excessively; each of us wishes to be like him. He has married his daughter to his nephew, and he is poor and has nothing to equip her with.' Abdullah bin Abbas stood up, took their hands, led them into his house, opened a chest, and took out six bags of money. Then he said: 'Carry.' So they carried them. Ibn Abbas said: 'We have not treated him fairly; we have given him what will distract him from his fasting and praying. Return, so we can be his assistants in equipping her. The world does not have enough value to distract a believer from worshipping his Lord Almighty, and we do not have such pride that we would not serve the allies of Allah Almighty.' So he did, and they did.

**Anecdote:** It is narrated that Uthman had a claim of fifty thousand dirhams against Talha. Uthman went out to the mosque one day, and Talha said to him: 'Your money is ready, so take it.' He said: 'It is yours, O Abu Muhammad, as an aid to your virtue.'

**Anecdote:** Sa'da bint Awf said: I entered upon Talha bin Ubaydullah and saw heaviness in him. I said: 'What is wrong with you?' He said: 'Money has accumulated with me, causing me distress and grief.' I said: 'What grieves you? Call your people and distribute it among them.' He said: 'O boy, call my people.' He distributed it among them. I asked the servant: 'How much was it?' He said: 'Four hundred thousand.'

**Anecdote:** Al-Harith al-Muhasibi said: We were informed that a caravan arrived from Yemen for Abd al-Rahman bin Awf. Medina buzzed with a single noise. Aisha said: 'What is this?' She was told: 'A caravan arrived for Abd al-Rahman.' She said: 'Allah and His Messenger spoke the truth.' This reached Abd al-Rahman, so he asked her. She said: 'I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "I saw Paradise, and I saw the poor of the Emigrants and Muslims entering it running, but I did not see any of the rich entering it with them except crawling."' Abd al-Rahman said: 'The caravan and what is on it is for the sake of Allah, and its slaves are free; perhaps I may enter it with them running.'

**Anecdote:** From Aban bin Uthman, who said: A man wanted to harm Ubaydullah bin Abbas, so he went to the notables of Quraysh and said to them: 'Abdullah says to you: Have lunch with me today.' They came to him until they filled his house. Abdullah said: 'What is this?' He was informed of the news. He ordered fruit to be bought and ordered people to cook and bake. The fruit was presented to them, and before they finished it, the tables were set. They ate until they left. Ubaydullah said to his agents: 'Is something like this available whenever I want?' They said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Then let these people have lunch with us every day.'

**Anecdote:** It is told that when people suffered a famine in Egypt while Abd al-Hamid bin Sa'd was their emir, he said: 'By Allah, I will teach Satan that I am his enemy.' He aided their needy, opened the storehouses, and spent them until prices dropped. Then he was dismissed from them and departed. He owed merchants one million dirhams, for which he pawned his women's jewelry, the value of which was five million dirhams. When he was unable to retrieve it, he wrote to them to sell it and give the surplus to those whom his charity had not reached.

**Anecdote:** It is said that Abdullah bin Amir bin Kurayz left the mosque wanting his home, alone. A boy from Thaqif stood up to him and walked by his side. Abdullah said to him: 'Do you have a need, O boy?' He said: 'Your well-being and success. I saw you walking alone, so I said I would protect you with myself, and I seek refuge in Allah lest any harm touch you.' Abdullah took his hand and walked with him to his house. Then he called for a thousand dinars, gave them to the boy, and said: 'Spend this, for excellent is the manner your family taught you.'

**Anecdote:** Abdullah bin Amir bought from Khalid bin Uqba bin Abi Mu'ayt his house in the market for ninety thousand dirhams. When night came, he heard the weeping of Khalid's family. He said to his family: 'What is wrong with them?' They said: 'They are weeping for their house which you bought.' He said: 'O boy, go to them and inform them that the house and the money are all theirs.'

**Anecdote:** It is narrated that Abdullah bin Ja'far went out to a farm of his. He stopped at a palm grove belonging to some people, where there was a black slave tending to it. His daily food provision of three loaves was brought to him. A dog entered and approached the slave. He threw a loaf to it, and it ate it. He threw the second to it, and it ate it. Then the third, and it ate it. Abdullah was looking at him and said: 'O boy, how much is your provision every day?' He said: 'What you saw.' He said: 'Why did you prefer this dog?' He said: 'This is not a land of dogs, and I reckon it came from a far distance hungry, so I hated to turn it away.' He said: 'So what will you do today?' He said: 'I will fast this day of mine.' Abdullah bin Ja'far said: 'Am I blamed for generosity while this one is more generous than me?' He bought the garden, the slave, and the tools in it, freed the slave, and gifted it all to him.

**Anecdote:** It is said that words were exchanged between Al-Husayn bin Ali and his brother Muhammad bin al-Hanafiya, and they departed angry with each other. When Muhammad reached his home, he took a piece of paper and wrote in it: 'In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. From Muhammad bin Ali bin Abi Talib to Al-Husayn bin Ali bin Abi Talib. Now then, you have an honor I cannot reach, and a virtue I cannot attain. If you read this letter of mine, put on your cloak and shoes and come to me to reconcile with me. Beware lest I precede you to the deed of which you are more worthy than I. Peace.' He said: When Al-Husayn read the letter, he said: 'O boy, my cloak and shoes.' He put them on, came to his brother Muhammad, reconciled with him, and made peace. It is said: Words were exchanged between Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn, may Allah be pleased with them. It was said to Al-Husayn: 'Why don't you go to your brother apologizing?' He said: 'Virtue belongs to the one who initiates kindness, and I do not see it fitting for me to have virtue over my brother.' Al-Hasan heard of this, so he came to him.

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani narrated from Ishaq, said: Mus'ab al-Zubayri narrated to me from Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Abi Mulayka, from his father, from his grandfather, who said: There was a pious man in Medina, a man of knowledge and jurisprudence, who used to visit Abdullah bin Ja'far. One day he heard a singing slave girl belonging to some slave traders singing: 
'Su'ad departed, so her bond was cut... She occupied Al-Ghawr, then Al-Jaddayn, then Al-Far'a.
She denied me, and what she denied... of events was nothing but gray hair and baldness.'
He became infatuated with her and wandered in love, abandoning his ways until Ata and Tawus walked to him and blamed him. His answer was to quote the poet:
'People I sit with blame me regarding you... I do not care whether the blame flies or lands.'

This reached Abdullah bin Ja'far, so he sent for the slave trader, inspected the girl, and heard her sing this song. He asked her: 'From whom did you learn it?' She said: 'From Azza al-Mayla.' He bought her for forty thousand dirhams and ordered his head maid to adorn and bedeck her, which she did. Then he sent to the man asking about his condition, informing him of the situation, and verifying the news about him. He said to him: 'Would you like to hear this voice from the one that girl learned it from?' He said: 'Yes.' So he called for Azza al-Mayla and said: 'Sing it to him.' She sang it. The man clapped and fell unconscious. Ibn Ja'far said: 'We have sinned regarding him! Water, water!' He sprinkled water on his face. When he recovered, he said to him: 'Has your love for her reached this extent?' He said: 'What is hidden from you is greater.' He said: 'Would you like to hear it from her?' He said: 'You saw what happened when I heard it from someone else while I do not love her (Azza); how will my state be if I hear it from her (the slave girl) while I cannot possess her?' He said: 'Would you recognize her if you saw her?' He said: 'Would I recognize anyone else?' He ordered her to be brought out. He said: 'Take her, she is yours. By Allah, I have not looked at her with desire.' The man kissed his hands and feet and said: 'You have revived my eye and my soul, let me live among my people, and returned my mind to me.' He prayed for him profusely. Ibn Ja'far said to him: 'Are you satisfied?' He said: 'Yes, by Allah, and above satisfaction.' Ibn Ja'far said: 'I am not content to give her to you like this. O boy, carry with him the like of her price so that you do not worry about her and she does not worry about you.' So he returned with her and the money.

**Anecdote:** Abu Musa Muhammad bin al-Fadl bin Ya'qub, the scribe and executor of Isa bin Ja'far, narrated: My father told me: I used to visit Zaynab bint Sulayman bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Abbas and write down news of her family from her. She had a slave girl named 'Kitab'. She caught my fancy. I went to her early one day and said: 'I have a request.' She said: 'Ask me whatever you like.' I said: 'Kitab, your maid, has occupied my heart against me, so gift her to me.' She said: 'Sit down, I will tell you a story that happened yesterday, more beneficial to you than every 'Kitab' (book/writer) on the face of the earth, and you have a promise regarding Kitab.'

I was with Al-Khayzuran yesterday. Her habit when I was with her was to sit at the threshold of the hallway facing the Iwan, and I would sit opposite her. In the center was Al-Mahdi's sitting place where he would sit; he would visit us at any time, sit for an hour, then leave. While we were like that, one of her chambermaids entered and said: 'May Allah honor the Lady, at the door is a woman of beauty and fine creation, but in the utmost state of poor condition, asking permission to see you. I asked her name, but she refused to tell me.' Al-Khayzuran turned to me and said: 'What do you think?' I said: 'Let her in, for there must be a benefit or reward.' A woman entered, among the most beautiful and perfect of women, unable to hide it. She stood by the side of the doorjamb, greeted humbly, and then said: 'I am Muzna bint Marwan bin Muhammad the Umayyad.'

Zaynab said: I was reclining, so I sat up straight and said: 'Muzna! What brought you? No welcome and no proximity to you! Praise be to Allah who removed your blessing, tore your veil, and humiliated you. Do you remember, O enemy of Allah, when the old women of my family came to you asking you to speak to your master (Marwan) to permit the burial of Ibrahim bin Muhammad, and you attacked them and said what you said, and ordered them expelled, so they were expelled in the state they were expelled?' She said: She laughed—I will never forget the beauty of her teeth and the loudness of her laughter—then said: 'O cousin, does the good doing of Allah with me despite my disobedience surprise you, that you wish to follow my example in it? By Allah, I indeed did to the women of your family what I did, so Allah surrendered me to you humiliated, hungry, and naked. Is this the extent of your gratitude to Allah Almighty for what He bestowed upon you regarding me?' Then she said: 'Peace be upon you,' and turned away.

Al-Khayzuran shouted at her: 'This is not for you! You asked permission to see me, and you intended me, so what is my fault?' She returned and said: 'By my life, you have spoken the truth, O sister. What turned me back to you was the harm and exhaustion I am in.' Zaynab said: Al-Khayzuran rose to embrace her, but she said: 'There is no place for that in me given the state I am in.' Al-Khayzuran said to her: 'The bathhouse then.' She ordered a group of her maids to enter the bath with her. She entered and asked for a comb to remove the hair from her face. A maid of Al-Khayzuran came out laughing. Al-Khayzuran asked her: 'What makes you laugh?' She said: 'I laugh, my lady, at this woman and her commanding us; she acts in a way you do not.' She remained until she was brought out of the bath. Robes and perfume were brought to her; she took whatever clothes she wanted, perfumed herself, and came out to us. Al-Khayzuran embraced her and seated her in the place where the Commander of the Faithful Al-Mahdi sits when he enters.

Then Al-Khayzuran said to her: 'Would you like food, for we haven't eaten yet?' She said: 'By Allah, there is no one among you more in need of it than me, so hasten it.' The table was brought, and she began eating without shyness, feeding us mouthfuls and placing food before us, until she was satisfied. Then we washed our hands. Al-Khayzuran asked her: 'Who is behind you that you care for?' She said: 'There is no one outside this house created by Allah with whom I have relations.' Al-Khayzuran said: 'If this is so, stand up and choose for yourself one of our compartments. I will move everything you need to it, and we will not part until death parts us.' She stood up, and we walked her through the compartments. She chose the most spacious and pleasant one. She did not leave until all she needed of furnishings, clothes, silks, and slaves were moved to it. Then we left her there and went out. Al-Khayzuran said: 'This woman was in the state she was in, and harm has touched her. Nothing washes what is in her heart except money. Carry five hundred thousand dirhams to her.' So it was carried to her.

Al-Mahdi joined us and asked about the news. I told him her story and how I met her. By Allah, he did not wait for me to tell him her response before he jumped up, angry at my face, saying: 'O Zaynab! For God's sake! Is this the extent of your gratitude to Allah for His blessing, when He enabled you over such a woman in the state she is in? By Allah, were it not for your place in my heart, I would have sworn never to speak to you again.' I said: 'I apologized to her and she accepted.' Then I told him her whole story and what Al-Khayzuran did for her. He said to a servant who was with him: 'Carry a hundred bags of money to her, enter upon her, convey my greetings, and say to her: "By Allah, I have never been as happy in my life as I am today with your presence. I am your brother and one who obligates your right. Do not leave a need without asking for it. Were it not that I dislike embarrassing you, I would have crossed over to greet you and fulfill your right."' The servant went with the money and the message. She came to us with him, greeted Al-Mahdi, thanked him for his deed, praised Al-Khayzuran, and said: 'I feel no shyness before the Commander of the Faithful; I am counted among his household.' She sat for an hour then rose to her dwelling. I left her with Al-Khayzuran as if she had always been in that palace. This story is better for you than Kitab, and I have gifted Kitab to you. I left her place, and she followed it up with enough to fill my house.

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani said: Al-Hasan bin Ali told me: Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal told me: Ishaq bin Musa al-Ansari told us: Yunus bin Bukayr told us from Muhammad bin Ishaq who said: There were people in Medina who lived without knowing where their livelihood came from. When Ali bin al-Husayn, may Allah be pleased with them, died, they lost what used to be brought to them at night, and their situation was revealed.

**Anecdote:** It is narrated about Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, that he was patrolling Medina during his caliphate when he found a slave girl weeping and saying:
'I loved him before the cutting of my amulets... swaying like a soft branch.
As if the light of the full moon resembles his face... he walks and ascends to the peak of Hashim.'
He knocked on the door, and she came out to him. He asked her: 'Are you free or a slave?' She said: 'A slave, O Companion of the Messenger of Allah.' He asked her: 'Who do you love?' She wept and said: 'By the right of the owner of the grave (the Prophet), turn away from me.' He said: 'I will not leave my place until you inform me.' She said:
'I am the one whom separation has struck her heart... so she wept for the love of Muhammad bin al-Qasim.'
Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, went to the mosque and sent for her master. He bought her from him and sent her to Muhammad bin al-Qasim bin Ja'far bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, and said: 'These are the temptations of men. By Allah, they have taken away a noble one and destroyed a sound one.'

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Salih al-Balakhi narrated in Egypt... about Shaybah bin Muhammad al-Dimashqi who said: In the days of Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, there was a man named Khuzayma bin Bishr from Banu Asad in Raqqa. He possessed manliness, good wealth, virtue, and kindness to his brothers. He remained in that state until he needed his brothers whom he used to favor. They comforted him for a while, then grew tired of him. When their change became apparent to him, he came to his wife, who was his cousin, and said to her: 'O cousin! I have seen a change in my brothers, and I have resolved to stay in my house until death comes to me.' He locked his door and stayed, subsisting on what he had until it ran out and he remained bewildered in his affair.

Ikrimah al-Fayyad al-Raba'i was the governor of Al-Jazira. While he was in his assembly with a group of the people of the town, Khuzayma bin Bishr was mentioned. Ikrimah said: 'What is his condition?' They said: 'He has reached a state of indescribable badness; he locked his door and stayed in his house.' Al-Fayyad (The Overflowing)—named so for his generosity—said: 'Did Khuzayma bin Bishr not find a comforter or a rewarder?' They said: 'No.' He remained silent. When night came, he took four thousand dinars and put them in a single bag. He ordered his beast to be saddled and went out secretly from his family. He rode with one of his slaves carrying the money. He traveled until he stopped at Khuzayma's door. He took the bag from the slave and sent him away. He approached the door and knocked on it himself. Khuzayma came out to him. He handed him the bag and said: 'Fix your affairs with this.' Khuzayma took it, found it heavy, put it down, grabbed the beast's bridle, and said to him: 'Who are you? May I be your ransom.' He said: 'I did not come to you at this hour wanting you to know me.' Khuzayma said: 'I will not accept it until you tell me who you are.' He said: 'I am Jaber Atharat al-Kiram (The Repairer of the Slips of the Noble).' He said: 'Tell me more.' He said: 'No.' Then he left.

Khuzayma entered with the bag to his wife and said to her: 'Rejoice, for Allah has brought relief and good. Even if they are copper coins (fulus), they are many. Get up and light a lamp.' She said: 'There is no way to have a lamp.' He spent the night touching them, feeling the roughness of dinars, and not believing it.

Ikrimah returned to his home and found his wife missing him. She asked about him and was told he rode out alone. She became suspicious, tore her collar, and slapped her cheek. When he saw her in that state, he said: 'What has befallen you, O cousin?' She said: 'You betrayed your cousin, O Ikrimah.' He said: 'What is that?' She said: 'The Emir of Al-Jazira goes out after the quiet of the night, alone without his slaves, in secret from his family! By Allah, he goes out only to a wife or a concubine.' He said: 'Allah knows I did not go out to either.' She said: 'Then tell me regarding what you went out.' He said: 'O woman! I did not go out at this time wanting anyone to know about me.' She said: 'You must.' He said: 'Will you keep it secret then?' She said: 'I will.' So he told her the story as it happened, and what he said and what was replied to him. Then he said to her: 'Do you want me to swear to you?' She said: 'No, my heart is at peace with what you mentioned.'

Khuzayma woke up, settled with his creditors, and improved his condition. Then he prepared to go to Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik in Palestine. When he stood at his door, the chamberlain entered and informed him of his presence. Since he was famous for his manliness, Sulayman knew him and permitted him entry. When he entered and greeted him as Caliph, Sulayman said: 'O Khuzayma, what delayed you from us?' He said: 'Bad conditions.' He said: 'What prevented you from rising to us?' He said: 'My weakness.' He said: 'Then with what (means) did you rise?' He said: 'I knew nothing, O Commander of the Faithful, after the quiet of the night, but a man knocked on my door, and such and such happened,' and he told him the story from beginning to end. Sulayman asked: 'Do you know him?' He said: 'I did not know him, O Commander of the Faithful, because he was disguised, and I heard nothing from him except: Jaber Atharat al-Kiram.' Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik sighed with longing to know him and said: 'If we knew him, we would have helped him in his manliness.' Then he said: 'Bring me a staff of office.' It was brought, and he appointed Khuzayma as governor of Al-Jazira, replacing Ikrimah al-Fayyad.

Khuzayma went out heading for Al-Jazira. When he neared it, Ikrimah and the people of the town came out to meet him. They greeted each other and walked together until they entered the town. Khuzayma settled in the Emirate house and ordered that Ikrimah be taken and audited. He was audited, and many surpluses (debts) were found against him. Khuzayma demanded he pay them. Ikrimah said: 'I have no way to pay any of it.' Khuzayma said: 'It must be paid.' Ikrimah said: 'I do not have it, so do what you must.' Khuzayma ordered him to prison. Then he sent to him demanding payment. Ikrimah sent back: 'I am not one who preserves his wealth with his honor, so do what you wish.' Khuzayma ordered him shackled with iron and restricted him. He remained like that for a month or more. This exhausted him and harmed him. News of his harm reached his female cousin (wife), and she grieved and was distressed. She called a wise maid of hers and said: 'Go immediately to the door of this Emir and say: I have advice. If asked what it is, say: I will not say it except to Emir Khuzayma bin Bishr. If you enter upon him, ask him to clear the room. If he does, say to him: This was not the reward for Jaber Atharat al-Kiram from you; you repaid him with prison, restriction, and iron.' She did so. When Khuzayma heard her words, he said: 'What a shame! Is it really him?' She said: 'Yes.'

He immediately ordered his beast saddled, sent for the heads of the townspeople, gathered them, and came to the prison door. It was opened, and Khuzayma and those with him entered. He found Ikrimah at the bottom of the prison, changed and exhausted by harm. When Ikrimah looked at him and the people, he felt ashamed and lowered his head. Khuzayma approached him, bent over his head, and kissed it. Ikrimah raised his head and said: 'What followed this from you?' He said: 'Your noble deed and my bad repayment.' He said: 'May Allah forgive us and you.' Then he ordered the blacksmith to unlock his chains, and Khuzayma ordered them to be placed on his own legs. Ikrimah said: 'What do you want?' He said: 'I want to suffer the harm like you suffered.' He said: 'I adjure you by Allah not to do it.' They went out together until they reached Khuzayma's house. Ikrimah bid him farewell and wanted to leave. Khuzayma said: 'You are not leaving.' He said: 'What do you want?' He said: 'To change your condition, for my shame before your cousin is greater than my shame before you.' He ordered the bathhouse cleared, and they entered together. Khuzayma stood and served him himself. Then they came out, and he gave him robes of honor, beautified him, and carried a lot of money to him. Then he went with him to his house and asked permission to apologize to his cousin. He permitted him, so he apologized to her and blamed himself for his action. Then he asked him to go with him to the Commander of the Faithful Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik, who was residing in Ramla at that time. He agreed, so they traveled together until they arrived at Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik.

The chamberlain entered and informed him of Khuzayma bin Bishr's arrival. This alarmed him, and he said: 'The Governor of Al-Jazira arrives without our command, despite having been appointed recently? This is only for a grave event.' When he entered, he said to him before he greeted: 'What is behind you, O Khuzayma?' He said: 'Good, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'Then what brought you?' He said: 'I found Jaber Atharat al-Kiram, and I wanted to please you with him, as I saw your eagerness and longing to see him.' He said: 'And who is he?' He said: 'Ikrimah al-Fayyad.' He permitted him to enter. He entered and greeted him as Caliph. He welcomed him, brought him close to his seat, and said: 'O Ikrimah! Your good to him was nothing but trouble for you.' Then he said: 'Write all your needs and what you choose on a piece of paper.' He said: 'Or will the Commander of the Faithful excuse me?' He said: 'It must be done.' He called for an inkwell and paper and said: 'Step aside and write all your needs.' He did so. He ordered them all fulfilled immediately and ordered ten thousand dinars and two baskets of clothes for him. Then he called for a staff of office and appointed him over Al-Jazira, Armenia, and Azerbaijan, and said to him: 'Khuzayma's fate is up to you; if you wish, keep him, and if you wish, dismiss him.' He said: 'Rather, I return him to his work, O Commander of the Faithful.' Then they left together. They remained governors for Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik for the duration of his caliphate.

**Anecdote:** Al-Hasan bin Khidr narrated: When the Caliphate passed to the Abbasids, the men of Banu Umayya went into hiding. Among those hiding was Ibrahim bin Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik, until Dawud bin al-Abbas obtained a pardon for him. Ibrahim was a knowledgeable young man, favored by Abu al-Abbas al-Saffah. He said to him one day: 'Tell me about what you went through during your hiding.' He said: 'I was, O Commander of the Faithful, hiding in Al-Hira in a house overlooking the desert. While I was on the roof of a house, I saw black flags coming out of Kufa heading for Al-Hira. I felt they were coming for me, so I left the house in disguise until I came to Kufa. I knew no one there to hide with. I remained bewildered until I saw a large gate and a spacious courtyard. I entered it. Suddenly, a handsome man of good appearance on a horse entered the courtyard, accompanied by a group of his slaves and followers. He said to me: "Who are you and what is your need?" I said: "A man in hiding fearing for his blood seeking refuge in your house." He took me into his house, then put me in a room next to his harem. I was with him receiving whatever I liked of food, drink, and clothing. He did not ask me about my condition, except that he rode out every day. I said to him one day: "I see you riding constantly, why is that?" He said: "Ibrahim bin Sulayman killed my father in captivity. I have heard he is hiding, and I am searching for him to take my revenge." My amazement at our misfortune increased, by Allah, as fate drove me to my death in the house of the one seeking my blood. I hated life, so I asked the man his name and his father's name. He told me, and I knew the news was true, and I had killed his father in captivity. I said: "O you, your right has become incumbent upon me, and it is your right upon me that I guide you to your enemy and shorten your step." He said: "What is that?" I said: "I am Ibrahim bin Sulayman, your father's killer, so take your revenge." He said: "I think you are a man whom hiding has wearied, so you prefer death." I said: "Nay, the truth is what I told you. I killed him on such and such day for such and such reason." When he knew my truth, his face changed, his eyes turned red, and he looked down for a long time. Then he said: "As for you, you will meet my father and he will take his revenge from you. As for me, I will not betray my trust (of granting refuge). Go away from me, for I do not trust myself with you after this." He gave me a thousand dinars, but I did not take them, and I left his presence. This is the most generous man I have seen after the Commander of the Faithful.'

**Anecdote:** It is said that Abdullah bin al-Zubayr had land bordering the land of Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan. Muawiyah had placed negro slaves there to cultivate it, and they encroached upon Abdullah's land. He wrote to Muawiyah: "Now then, O Muawiyah, prevent your slaves from entering my land, or else there will be a matter between me and you." When Muawiyah read the letter—he was then the Commander of the Faithful—he handed it to his son Yazid. When Yazid read it, Muawiyah said to him: "O son, what do you think?" He said: "I think you should send an army to him, the first of which is with him and the last with you, to bring you his head." He said: "Or better than that, O son. Bring me an inkwell and paper." He wrote: "I have read the letter of the son of the Disciple of the Messenger of Allah, and what displeased him displeased me. The whole world to me is insignificant compared to his satisfaction. I have written a deed for the land and the slaves for him upon myself, and witnessed it. Let him annex it with its slaves to his land and slaves. Peace." When Abdullah read Muawiyah's letter, he wrote to him: "I have read the letter of the Commander of the Faithful, may Allah prolong his life. May he not lack the judgment that placed him in this position among Quraysh. Peace." When Muawiyah read Abdullah's letter, he threw it to his son Yazid. When he read it, his face brightened. Muawiyah said to him: "O son, if you are afflicted with such a disease, treat it with such a medicine."

**Anecdote:** Abdullah bin Sulayman said: I was in the presence of my father in the Bureau of Land Tax in Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) while he was in charge of it. Ahmad bin Abi Khalid al-Sarifini, the scribe, entered. My father stood up for him from his seat, seated him in the place of honor, and attended to him. He did not look at any work until Ahmad stood up, then he stood up with him and ordered his slaves to walk before him. I and everyone in the assembly found this strange, because the custom of bureau chiefs, small and large, is not to stand in the bureau for anyone entering. My father noticed this in my face and said to me: "O son, when we are alone, ask me about the reason for what I did with this man."

He said: My father used to eat in the bureau, sleep there, and do calculations in the evening. When we sat to eat, I did not mention it until the food was almost finished. He initiated saying: 'O son, did the food distract you from reminding me what I told you to?' I said: 'No, but I wanted it to be in private.' He said: 'This is a time of privacy.' Then he said: 'Did you not disapprove, along with those present, my standing for Ahmad bin Abi Khalid upon his entry and exit, and what I did with him?' I said: 'Yes.' He said: 'This man governed Egypt for years. I took over its administration and dismissed him. His term there had been long, so I investigated him. I saw the traces of a man; never have I seen better traces, nor one more chaste regarding the Sultan's and subjects' money, nor have I seen subjects more grateful to a governor than his subjects to him. Al-Husayn the Eunuch, known as 'Arq al-Mawt' (Vein of Death), the postmaster in Egypt, was the most truthful person to him despite this, and he was the most hateful person to me and the most volatile in character. So I found no argument against him. I found he had delayed submitting the accounts for a previous year and the year he was in, which he didn't complete because I dismissed him. The bureau did not send them to me. So I demanded he reduce the income record, increase expenses and salaries, and write off arrears of one hundred thousand dinars every year for me to take for myself. He refused. I was harsh with him and threatened him. I came down to one hundred thousand dinars total for the two years and swore solemn, confirmed oaths that I would not accept less. He persisted in his refusal and said: "I do not betray for myself, so how can I betray for another and remove the status my chastity has established?" I imprisoned him and shackled him, but he did not respond. He remained shackled in prison for months. 'Arq al-Mawt', the postmaster, wrote the news to Al-Mutawakkil, swearing to him that Egypt's funds were not covering my expenses and supplies, describing Ahmad bin Abi Khalid, and mentioning the subjects' inclination towards him and his chastity. Al-Mutawakkil sent his reinstatement.

I was eating one day when Ahmad bin Abi Khalid's note arrived asking me to summon him for an important matter he wanted to tell me. I had no doubt he had been harmed by the prison and chains and resolved to agree to my wish. When I washed my hands, I called him and took him aside. He said: "Isn't it time, my master, for you to pity me for what I am in, without any sin against you, nor crime, nor old grudge or enmity?" I said: "You chose that for yourself. You heard my oath, and there is no way out of it. Agree to what I want from you and get out." He began to beg for sympathy, serve me, and deceive me. This came contrary to what I estimated of him, so it enraged me. I insulted him and said: "Is this the important matter you mentioned in your note you wanted to tell me? To beg for sympathy, seek refuge, and deceive me?" He said: "O master, is there nothing else with you now?" I said: "No." He said: "If there is nothing else with you, then read this, O master," and he brought out a small sealed letter in a quarter sheet. I broke the seal, and it was in Al-Mutawakkil's handwriting, which I knew, ordering me to leave, hand over what I control to Ahmad bin Abi Khalid, clear myself of obligations, submit the accounts to him, obey his command, and march from Egypt afterward. It struck me in the ugliest way due to how recently I had insulted him and mistreated him, while he was instantly under my iron and harm. I held back, stunned. Before long, the Emir of Egypt entered with his companions and slaves, and put guards on my house, all I owned, my companions, slaves, treasurers, and scribes. I began crawling from the seat of honor until I was before Ahmad bin Abi Khalid, unable to stand, while he was still in his chains. The Emir of the town called a blacksmith who undid his chains. I extended my legs for the chains to be placed on them. He said to me: "O Abu Ayyub, pull your feet together." He jumped up standing, then said to me: "O Abu Ayyub, you are new to the governorship of this town. You have no home in it nor friend, and you have a harem and entourage. Only this house fits you (it was the Governor's House). As for me, I can find several other places, and I have little entourage, and I have just come out of calamity and chains. So stay in your place." He left me, dismissed the guards from me and the house, and took my scribes and followers to him. When he left, I said to my slaves: "Is this what I see in a dream? Look who he put in charge of us." They said: "He put no one in charge of us." I marveled at that greatly. Before I prayed Asr, those of the officials, scribes, and treasurers he had taken with him returned to me released, saying: "He took our signatures for submitting the accounts, ordered us to attend, and released us." My amazement increased. The next day he came early greeting me, and I went to him in the evening of that day. I stayed thirty days; if he beat me to coming, I went to him, and if I went to him, he came early to me. Every day his gifts and favors of ice, fruit, animals, sweets, and perfume came to me. After thirty days, he came to me and said: "You have fallen in love with Egypt, O Abu Ayyub. By Allah, its air is not good nor sweet. It is only pleasant for non-locals through governance and earning. If you traveled to Baghdad and Surra Man Ra'a, you would stay only a month before assuming the highest offices." I said: "By Allah, I only stayed expecting your order to leave." He said: "Give me your scribe's note that he is responsible for the accounts, and leave in the safety of Allah." I summoned my scribe, took his note as he wanted, and handed the note to him. He said to me: "Leave whenever you wish." So I left the next day. He, the Emir of Egypt, its judge, notables, and people saw me off to the outskirts of Egypt. He said to me: "Stay at the first station five parasangs away until I resolve the issue of a commander to accompany you with his men to Ramla, for the road is unsafe." I became terrified of that and said: "He only deceived me until I brought out all I own and earned, so he can overpower it outside the town, seize it, then return me to prison, guards, and demands, using a second letter as an excuse claiming it is a deed." I went out and stayed at the stage he mentioned, surrendering to fate, expecting evil, until I saw the vanguard of his army coming from Egypt. I said: "Perhaps it is the commander he wants to accompany me, or perhaps he wants to arrest me." I ordered my slaves to find out the news. They said: "The worker Ahmad bin Abi Khalid has come." I had no doubt that calamity had arrived with his arrival. I left my tent, met him, and greeted him. When he sat, he said: "Leave us alone." I had no doubt it was for arresting me. My mind flew, and whoever was with me left.

When no one remained with me, he said: "I know that your days in Egypt were not long, and you did not enjoy much profit. That chapter (of graft) you asked me for during your governorship, I did not respond to you in it. I delayed the permission for you to leave from the beginning until now because I busied myself completing it for you. I have lowered the revenue record and increased the expenses by fifteen thousand dinars each year, making thirty thousand dinars for the two years. It is close and does not show, and it is easier (safer) than what you wanted from me at that time. I busied myself with it until I collected it for you. This money is on the mules; I have brought it to you, so proceed to have someone receive it." I advanced to receive it, kissed his hand, and said: "By Allah, my master, you have done what the Barmakids did not do." He denied that from me, pulled away, kissed my hand and foot, and said: "There is something else here I want you to accept." I said: "What is it?" He said: "Five thousand dinars, which I have rightfully earned from my salary." I refused it and said: "There is sufficiency in what you have favored me with." He swore by divorce that I accept it from him, so I accepted it. He said: "And here are some favors from the gifts of Egypt I wanted you to take with you. For you are going to the bureau scribes and court chiefs, and they will say to you: 'You governed Egypt, so where is our share of its gifts?' Your days were not long enough to prepare that for them. I have collected for you what this list contains." He brought out a scroll containing a comprehensive list of everything beautiful, rare, and valuable in the world of every kind: Dabizi clothes, linens, servants, mules, beasts, donkeys, furnishings, perfume, even pens and ink, the value of which is a lot of money. I ordered it received and increased my thanks. He said to me: "O master, I am fond of furnishings. I had an Armenian tent made for me in Armenia, consisting of ten prayer rugs with their pillows, cushions, armrests, mattresses, and carpets, with gilded embroidery. It cost me five thousand dinars despite my strictness. I have gifted it to you. If you gift it to the Vizier, he will be your servant; if you gift it to the Caliph, you will own him with it; and if you keep it for yourself and beautify yourself with it, that is more beloved to me." He said: He loaded it. I never saw the like of it. My soul did not allow gifting it to anyone or using it. I did not use anything from it, O son, except on the day of your circumcision, for I used the centerpiece, cushions, and pillows. Do you blame me, O son, for standing up for this man? I said: "No, by Allah, O father; nor for what is more than standing, if it were possible." He said: My father was such after that, if he dismissed a man from a job, he treated him with every beauty and would say: "Ibn Abi Khalid taught us—may Allah reward him well—good conduct."

**Anecdote:** It is said that when the mosque in Egypt burned, the Muslims thought the Christians burned it, so they burned a khan belonging to them. The Sultan arrested a group of those who burned the khan. He wrote tickets containing "Killing," "Amputation," and "Flogging" and scattered them over them. Whoever got a ticket, that was done to him. A ticket containing "Killing" fell into the hand of a man. He said: "I wouldn't care if not for a mother of mine." There was a young man beside him who said: "My ticket is Flogging, and I have no mother. Give me your ticket and take mine." They did so; that one was killed and this one was flogged.

**Anecdote:** The Master Abu Ali said: When Ghulam Khalil slandered the Sufis to the Caliph accusing them of heresy (Zandaqa), he ordered their beheading. As for Al-Junayd, he covered himself with jurisprudence and used to give fatwas according to the school of Abu Thawr. As for Al-Shahham, Al-Raqqam, Al-Thawri, and a group, they were arrested, and the leather mat was spread for beheading. Al-Thawri stepped forward. The executioner said to him: "Do you know why you are stepping forward?" He said: "Yes." He said: "What makes you hasten?" He said: "I prefer my companions with an hour of life." The executioner was bewildered, and the news was raised to the Caliph. He returned them to the judge to investigate their condition. The judge posed jurisprudential questions to Abu al-Husayn al-Thawri, and he answered all of them. Then he began saying: "Furthermore, Allah has servants who, when they stand, stand for Allah, and when they speak, speak by Allah," and he recited expressions until he made the judge weep. He sent to the Caliph saying: "If these are heretics, then there is no Muslim on the face of the earth." So he ordered their release, and they were released.

**Anecdote:** It is said that when Al-Hajjaj killed Abdullah bin al-Zubayr, he traveled to Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, accompanied by Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Talha bin Abdullah. When he arrived at Abd al-Malik's, he did not begin with any speech except to say: "I came to you, O Commander of the Faithful, with the man of Hijaz in honor and fatherhood; I leave no equal for him in it, by Allah, in perfection of manliness and etiquette, good doctrine, obedience, and advice, along with kinship to the Commander of the Faithful: Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Talha bin Abdullah. So do with him, O Commander of the Faithful, what deserves to be done with the likes of him in his fatherhood and honor." He said to him: "O Abu Muhammad, you have reminded us of a mandatory right and close kinship. Permit Ibrahim to enter." When he entered and greeted as Caliph, he ordered him to sit in the place of honor. Abd al-Malik said to him: "Abu Muhammad has reminded us of what we have always known of you regarding fatherhood and honor. Do not leave a need of your private or public affairs without asking for it." Ibrahim said: "As for the needs by which proximity is sought and reward is hoped, whatever is purely for Allah and His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and for you and the Muslims, I have advice which I must mention." He said: "Is it excluding Abu Muhammad (Al-Hajjaj)?" He said: "Yes." He said: "Stand up, O Hajjaj." Al-Hajjaj stood up ashamed, not seeing where he stepped. Then he said: "Speak, O Ibn Talha." He said: "By Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, you have entrusted Al-Hajjaj in his injustice, arrogance, and transgression, his distance from the truth and listening to falsehood. You appointed him over the Two Holy Sanctuaries, where reside the sons of the Muhajirun and Ansar and the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. He humiliates them and treads on them with oppression using the riffraff of the people of Sham and rabble who have no deliberation in establishing right nor removing falsehood. So dismiss him." Abd al-Malik looked down for an hour, then raised his head and said: "You lied and spoke falsehood, O Ibn Talha. Al-Hajjaj thought of you other than what is in you. Stand up, for perhaps good is thought of people not worthy of it." Ibrahim said: "I stood up, and by Allah, I could not see a road. A guard followed me and he (Abd al-Malik) said to him: 'Hold him tight.'" Ibrahim said: "I remained sitting. Al-Hajjaj was called, and they whispered for a long time until I thought the worst, and I had no doubt it was about my affair. Then I was called. I stood up and met Al-Hajjaj in the courtyard leaving. He kissed me between the eyes and said: 'If Allah rewards brothers for the virtue of their love with good, may He beautify your reward from me. By Allah, if I live for you, I will raise your status and follow your heels.'" He said: "I said to myself: Al-Hajjaj is mocking me, by Allah. I entered upon Abd al-Malik, and he seated me in my first seat. Then he said: 'O Ibn Talha, did anyone share in your advice?' I said: 'No, by Allah, O Commander of the Faithful. I intended only Allah, His Messenger, the Muslims, and you.' He said: 'I knew that. I have dismissed Al-Hajjaj from the Two Holy Sanctuaries when you hated him there, and I informed him that you considered that too little for him and asked me for a major governorship for him. I have appointed him over the two Iraqs, and informed him that you solicited that for him to increase his status, so that he owes you a debt by which he performs to you, on my behalf, the reward of your advice. Go out with him, for you will not blame his company.' So I went out with him, and I received every good from him."

**Anecdote:** Judge Abu al-Qasim Ali bin al-Muhsin bin Ali al-Tanukhi said: Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani told me from memory: I read in some ancient chronicles that when Alexander reached China and besieged its king, his chamberlain came to him after half the night had passed and said: 'The messenger of the King of China is at the door asking permission to see you.' He said: 'Let him in.' When he entered, he stood before him, greeted, and said: 'If the King sees fit to leave me alone with him, let him do so.' Alexander ordered those present to leave, and his chamberlain remained. The messenger said to him: 'What I came for cannot bear to be heard by anyone else.' He ordered him searched. He was searched, and no weapon was found on him. Alexander placed a drawn sword before him and said: 'Stand your ground and say what you wish.' Then he sent out everyone who was with him. When the place was empty, the messenger said to him: 'I am the King of China, not his messenger. I have come to ask you what you want from me. If it is something possible to comply with, even in the most difficult ways, I will agree to it, and spare you and myself from war.' Alexander said to him: 'What secures me from you?' He said: 'My knowledge that you are a wise man, that there is no prior enmity between us, nor claim for revenge, and that you know that if you kill me, the people of China will not surrender their kingdom to you, nor will my absence prevent them from appointing a king other than me. Then you would be attributed to the essence of ignorance and the opposite of prudence.' Alexander looked down thinking about his speech and knew he was a wise man. Then he said to him: 'What I want from you is the revenue of your kingdom for three years immediately, and half its revenue every year.' He said: 'Is there anything else?' He said: 'No.' He said: 'I have answered you.' He said: 'Then how will your condition be then?' He said: 'I will be the victim of the first warrior and the meal of the first predator.' He said: 'If I accept the revenue of two years from you, how will your condition be?' He said: 'Better than it would be if I were bound by what was previously mentioned.' He said: 'If I accept the revenue of one year from you?' He said: 'That would be detrimental to my kingdom and take away all my pleasures.' He said: 'If I limited myself to the sixth?' He said: 'The sixth would be available, and the rest for my army and the causes of the kingdom.' He said: 'I have limited myself to this from you.' He thanked him and left.

When morning came and the sun rose, the army of China approached until it covered the earth and surrounded Alexander's army until they feared destruction. His companions jumped up, mounted, and prepared for war. While they were like that, the King of China appeared wearing the crown. When he saw Alexander, he dismounted. Alexander said to him: 'Did you betray?' He said: 'No, by Allah.' He said: 'Then what is this army?' He said: 'I wanted to let you know that I did not obey you out of scarcity or weakness—and for you to see the army, and what is absent from you is greater—but I saw the ethereal world turning towards you, enabling you. I knew that whoever fights the ethereal world is defeated. So I wanted to obey it by obeying you, and humble myself to its command by humbling myself to you.' Alexander said: 'One like you should not have anything taken from him. I have not seen anyone between me and you deserving preference and description of wisdom other than you. I have exempted you from everything I wanted from you, and I am leaving you.' The King of China said: 'Since you have done that, you will not lose.' When Alexander departed, the King of China followed him with gifts and favors double what he had decided with him.

**Anecdote:** Numayr al-Hilali narrated: Among the youths of Banu Hilal was a young man named Bishr bin Abdullah, known as Al-Ashtar. He was one of the masters of Banu Hilal, the best looking, and the most generous of hand. He admired a girl from his people called Jayda, who was of outstanding beauty and perfection. Their affair became famous, and news of them appeared. Evil occurred between their families until blood was shed between the two groups, then they separated and their dwellings became distant. Numayr said: When the separation became long for Al-Ashtar and the distance continued, he came to me and said: 'O Numayr, is there any good?' I said: 'I have it, say what you like.' He said: 'Help me visit Jayda, for longing has taken my soul.' I said: 'Yes, with love and honor. Let us go if you wish.' He rode, and I rode with him. We traveled our day and night, evening and morning, until when it was evening, we made our camels kneel in a ravine near the group. He said: 'O Numayr, go and socialize with the people. Mention if you meet anyone that you are seeking a stray animal. Do not hint at my mention by lip or tongue, unless you meet her maid so-and-so, the shepherdess of their sheep. Give her my greetings, ask her about the news, and inform her of my location.' Numayr said: I went out not exceeding what he ordered me until I met the maid. I delivered the message, informed her of his place, and asked her about the news. She said: 'By Allah, she is strictly watched and guarded. But your appointment is those trees at the backs of the houses at the time of the last evening prayer.' He said: I returned to my companion and informed him of the news. Then he and I went leading our camels until we came to the place at the appointed time. We waited only a little when Jayda walked near us. Al-Ashtar jumped up, shook her hand, and greeted her. I stood up turning away from them. They said: 'We swear you must return. By Allah, we are not doing anything hateful, nor is there anything between us to hide from you.' I returned to them and sat with them. Al-Ashtar said to her: 'Is there any trick, O Jayda, to distract yourself tonight?' She said: 'No, by Allah, I have no way to that unless the calamity and evil you know returns.' Al-Ashtar said to her: 'It must be, even if it is whatever it may be.' She said: 'Is there any good in this companion of yours?' I said: 'Say what seems best to you, for I will follow your opinion even if it means the loss of my life.' She took off her clothes and said to me: 'Wear them and give me your clothes.' I did so. Then she said: 'Go to my house and enter my curtain. My husband will come to you asking for the bowl to milk into. Then he will come to you after finishing milking with the bowl full and say: "Here is your evening drink." Do not take it from him until you prolong that upon him. Then take it or leave it until he puts it down and leaves. You will not see him, God willing.'

He said: I went and did what she ordered me. When he came with the bowl, I did not take it from him until my stubbornness prolonged upon him. Then I reached to take it from him, and he reached to put it down. Our hands clashed over the vessel; it slipped and the milk spilled. He said: 'This is the recalcitrance of Jayda!' He struck his hand on the front of the tent and pulled out a twisted whip like a snake. Then he entered, tore the curtain off me, and enjoyed giving me twenty full lashes. Then his mother and sister came and pulled me from his hand. By Allah, they did not do that until I lost my mind, and I intended to stab him with a knife even if it meant death. When they left, I tightened my curtain and sat as I was. I waited only a little until Jayda's mother entered. She spoke to me, having no doubt I was her daughter, and burst into weeping and wailing. I covered myself with my garment and turned my back to her. She said: 'O daughter, fear Allah regarding yourself, and do not expose yourself to your husband's hatred, for that is better for you. As for Al-Ashtar, he has perished forever.' She left me and said: 'I will send your sister to you to keep you company tonight.' I stayed not long, and behold, the girl came. She began crying and praying against the one who beat me, while I did not speak to her. Then she lay down by my side. When I had power over her, I tightened my hand over her mouth and said: 'O you, that is your sister with Al-Ashtar by the trees, and my back has been cut tonight because of her. You are the most worthy to cover for her. Choose for yourself and her. By Allah, if you speak a word, I will shout with all my might until the scandal is total.' Then I lifted my hand from her mouth. She shook like a reed shakes. I remained with her until she became familiar. By Allah, she spent the night with me as the best companion I ever accompanied. We kept talking and she laughing at me and what befell me. I had power over her such that if one wanted something illicit, he could have, but Allah protected, so praise be to Him. We remained like that until dawn broke, and suddenly Jayda entered upon us. When she saw us, she was startled and said: 'Woe to you, who is this?' I said: 'Your sister.' She said: 'What is the news?' I said: 'She will tell you, for she is an excellent sister.' I took my clothes and went to my companion. I rode, and he rode. I told him what befell me and uncovered my back to him. It had beating marks—may Allah strike the beater with a crushing fire—every blow bleeding. When he saw that, he said: 'Your deed is great, your thanks are obligatory, and your hand is long.

May Allah not deprive me of rewarding you.' He remained thankful and acknowledging to me.

**Anecdote:** Abd al-Rahman bin Umar al-Fihri narrated from men he named: Al-Mamun ordered ten men from Basra who were accused of Zandaqa (heresy) to be brought to him. While one of the party-crashers (Tufayli) was looking around, he saw them gathered being taken to the shore to travel to Baghdad. He said: 'These people have gathered only for a banquet.' He slipped in with them and entered their group. The guards took them to the river and made them board a skiff prepared for them. The Tufayli said: 'No doubt it is a picnic.' He went up with them into the skiff. No sooner had he done so than the group was shackled, and the Tufayli was shackled with them. He knew he had fallen into a predicament. He tried to escape but could not. Then the sailor pushed off, and they traveled until they reached Baghdad. They were carried until they entered upon Al-Mamun. He ordered their beheading. They were called by their names, man by man. Everyone he called, he questioned and ordered his beheading, until no one remained but the Tufayli, and the count was finished. Al-Mamun said to the guards: 'What is this?' They said: 'By Allah, we do not know, O Commander of the Faithful, other than that we found him with the group, so we brought him.' Al-Mamun said: 'What is your story, woe to you?' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, his wife is divorced if he knows anything of their sayings, and he knows nothing but "There is no god but Allah, Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah." I only saw them gathered, thought they were invited to a banquet or feast, so I joined them.' Al-Mamun laughed and then said: 'The bad luck of party-crashing reached such an extent that it put its owner in this place. This ignorant man has been saved from death, but let him be disciplined so he repents.'

Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi was present that day and said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, gift him to me, and I will tell you a wondrous story about myself regarding party-crashing.' He said: 'I gift him to you, so bring your story.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, I went out one day in disguise to look at the alleys of Baghdad. Sightseeing distracted me, and my walking ended at a wing (of a house) where I smelled the scents of food and spices wafting. My soul longed for it, and I stood, O Commander of the Faithful, unable to move on. I raised my gaze, and there was a window. In its opening were a hand and a wrist; I had never seen anything more beautiful. I stood bewildered, forgetting the food smells because of that hand and wrist. I began devising a trick to reach it. I looked and saw a tailor near that place. I approached him and greeted him. He returned the greeting. I said: "O master, whose house is this?" He said: "It belongs to a linen merchant." I said: "What is his name?" He said: "So-and-so son of So-and-so." I said: "Is he one who drinks wine?" He said: "Yes, and I think today he has a party; he only drinks with merchants like himself who are discreet." While we were talking, two noble men riding approached. He said: "These are his drinking companions." I said: "What are their names and kunyas?" I was told So-and-so and So-and-so. I moved my beast and caught up with them. I said: "May I be your ransom, Abu So-and-so (the host) has found you slow, may Allah honor him." I rode with them until we came to the door. I entered, and they entered. When the owner of the house saw me with them, he had no doubt I was associated with them. He welcomed me and seated me in the best places. Then the table was brought, and dishes were transferred to it. Its taste, O Commander of the Faithful, was better and more delicious than its smell. I said to myself: "Allah has granted me the attainment of the goal regarding these dishes; the hand and wrist remain." Then washing water was brought, and we washed. Then we were moved to the drinking assembly. It was the most shapely and elegant assembly in all its affairs. The owner of the house began treating me kindly and turning to me in conversation, thinking I was a guest of his guests, and they did the same to me, thinking his honoring me was due to prior acquaintance and friendship.

We drank several cups, then a slave girl came out to us like a willow branch, in the utmost elegance and good appearance. She greeted without shyness. A cushion was folded for her, and she sat on it. A lute was brought, and she took it and tuned it perfectly. She was skillful. She burst into song:
"My eye imagined her, so her cheek became... and in the place of imagination, there is a trace of my gaze.
Her figure passed through my mind, so it wounded it... I have never seen a figure wound the mind before.
My hand shook hers, so it pained her hand... from the touch of my hand, there is a wound in her fingertips."

Then she burst into singing again:
"I signaled to her: Have you known my affection?... She replied with the corner of the eye: I am upon the covenant.
So speak about the intentional revealing of her secret... and she swerved from revealing also intentionally."

I shouted: "The weapon! The weapon!" (implying killing/overwhelming beauty). Delight came over me such that I could not control myself. The group was also extremely delighted. Then she sang:
"Is it not strange that a house joins me... and you, yet we are not alone nor do we speak?
Except eyes revealing the secrets of souls... and the breaking of breaths upon a fire burning.
A signal of mouths, a wink of an eyebrow,... a breaking of eyelids, and a hand greeting."

By Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, I envied her skill, her knowledge of singing, and her hitting the meaning of the poetry, because she did not depart from the art she began with. I said: 'Something remains for you, O girl.' She threw the lute and said: 'When did you used to bring hateful people to your gatherings?' I regretted what I did and saw the people turn against me. I said to myself: 'I will lose everything I hoped for if I do not remedy my story.' I said: 'Is there a lute there?' They said: 'Yes.' A beautifully crafted lute was brought. I fixed what I wanted in it, then I burst into singing:
'What is wrong with the dwellings that they do not answer a sad one?... Did they become deaf or did decay come and they decayed?
Indeed, those who left with your heart left... a trickle in your eye that remains flowing.
They diminished their tears and said to me:... What did you encounter of love and what did we encounter?
They went in the evening, a memorable going... If they were confused, we were confused; or if guided, we were guided.
And they threw themselves and others across the desert... If they died, we died; and if they lived, we lived.'

I had not finished it, O Commander of the Faithful, before the girl jumped up and fell upon my feet kissing them and saying: 'An apology to you, my master. By Allah, I did not know your status, and I have never heard such craftsmanship from anyone.' Her master and everyone present stood up and did the same as her. Then the people increased in honoring and revering me. They were delighted to the utmost limit and drank with goblets and bowls. When I saw their delight, I burst into singing:
'Is it in (the law of) Allah that you spend the evening not remembering me... while my eyes have shed blood from remembering you?
To Allah I complain of her stinginess and my generosity... She gives me sickness while giving bitter apple.
So return the stricken heart, you killed it... and do not leave it mind-boggled, infatuated.
To Allah I complain that she is a foreigner... while for her I am honored with love as long as I live.'

I saw from the people's delight something that made me think they had lost their minds. I held back for an hour until they reviewed their affair and their souls calmed. Then I burst into singing:
'This is your lover folded upon his grief... pouring his tears running upon his body.
He has a hand asking the Compassionate for his rest... from what is in him, and another hand upon his liver.
O you who saw an infatuated, reckless, sick one... whose death was in his eye and his hand.'

The girl began shouting: 'This, by Allah, is singing, not what we are in.' The people drank, but the owner of the house retained some hold due to his good drinking capacity. The people became drunk and were overcome. He ordered his servants to protect them and take them to their homes. They left, and I remained alone with him. He drank some cups, then said: 'My master, what passed of my life went to waste since I did not know the likes of you, nor sat with a chief resembling you. So by Allah, my master, who are you so I may know my drinking companion?' I began to hide it from him while he swore upon me until I informed him who I really was. He jumped up on his feet and said: 'I wondered that this excellence could belong to anyone but the likes of you. Time has bestowed a favor upon me I cannot thank enough. When did I hope for the Caliphate to visit me in my home and drink with me all night! This is only in dreams. I will not complete my night except standing before you, as I am too despicable to sit with the Caliphate.' I swore upon him to sit, so he sat. Then he began asking me: 'What is the reason for your presence at his place?' with the gentlest question and finest meaning. I told him, O Commander of the Faithful, the story from beginning to end and hid nothing of it. Then I said: 'As for the food, I have attained my desire of it.' He said: 'And the hand and wrist you shall attain, God willing.' Then he said: 'O so-and-so, tell so-and-so (a maid of his) to come down.' Then he began calling them one by one, presenting them to me, but I did not see my companion. Until he said: 'By Allah, none remains but my mother and my sister, and by Allah, they shall come down.' I marveled at his generosity and broadmindedness. I said: 'May I be your ransom, start with the sister before the mother, for I am shy to look at your mother's palm.' He said: 'With love and honor.' Then his sister came down and showed me her palm. It was the one I saw. I said: 'Enough, this is the girl.' He immediately ordered his servants to summon ten sheikhs he named. Then he stood up and brought out two bags containing twenty thousand dirhams. The sheikhs arrived, and he said to them: 'This is my master Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi proposing to my sister so-and-so, and I call you to witness that I have married her to him and given her a dowry from him of ten thousand dirhams.' I said: 'I accept and agree to the marriage.' They witnessed for us. Then he gave one bag to his sister and distributed the other among the sheikhs. Then he said: 'Excuse us, for this is what was available in such a situation.' They thanked him, prayed for him, and left. Then he said: 'My master, shall I prepare a bed for you in one of the rooms so you can sleep with your wife?' I was embarrassed by what I saw of his generosity and felt ashamed to be alone with her in his house. I said: 'Rather, bring a litter and carry her to my house.' He said: 'Whatever you wish.' A litter was brought, and I carried her to my house. By your right, O Commander of the Faithful, he carried to me such trousseau that our houses, despite their size, were too narrow for it. I fathered from her this boy standing before the Commander of the Faithful.

Al-Mamun marveled at the generosity of this man and said: 'To Allah is his excellence! I have never heard of such a deed.' Then he released the party-crasher and rewarded him, and ordered Ibrahim to bring the man so he could see him. He was brought before him, he spoke with him, liked him, and he became one of his intimates and companions.

**Anecdote:**

It is told about a scholar who said: An old man used to sit with me. Whatever topic of knowledge I spoke about, he would weep, until this went on for a long time. I said to him one day when we were alone: 'I see you sticking to my assembly yet asking nothing, and I constantly see you weeping. What is your situation?' He said: 'Yes, my master. I was a man who bought and sold slaves for profit. Once, a boy with a radiant face and perfect physique fell into my hands. He was young. I bought him for three hundred dinars, adorned him, and prepared him for whoever would desire to buy him. One day, a handsome young boy passed by us. When he saw the slave boy, he got off his beast and said: "Is this boy for sale?" I said: "Yes." He turned the boy around, examined him, and said to him: "What is your name, what is your race, and what are you good at?" He informed him. Then he said to me: "How much is he?" I said: "A thousand dinars." He squeezed the boy's hand a pinch then left. I looked at the boy's hand and found a purse. I counted it and found one hundred dinars. I said to him: "Do you know the man?" He said: "No." When the next day came, he came and did as he did yesterday. When the third day came, he came and did as he did the previous two days. I said to myself: "This man did not give this one three hundred dinars unless he loves him, and he cannot afford the price I mentioned to him." So I followed him until I knew his place. When evening came, I ordered the boy to wear his finest clothes, perfumed him, adorned him, and said to him: "This man has given us the like of your price. I have decided to take you to him, so be obedient to him, and inform me of what happens with him." I went with him to the man's house after the last evening prayer. I knocked on the door. He came out and opened the door. When he saw us, he was dumbfounded, then said "Inna lillahi..." and said: "What brought you two?" I said: "I presented this boy to some Baghdadi kings just now, and no deal was concluded with them. I fear the night patrol for him, so keep him with you until morning." He said: "Come in and stay with him until morning." I said: "I cannot do that, so leave him with you, and beware that he leaves your house or control until I come to you early." I left and returned to my bed, thinking about his affair. Suddenly, the boy came terrified and weeping. I said to him: "What is behind you?" He said to me: "The man died just now." I said: "Woe to you, how did that happen?" He said: "I entered with him. He brought me food, so I ate. I washed my hands, and he perfumed me. Then he came and placed his index finger on my cheek and said: 'I testify that you are beautiful, and what my soul calls me to regarding you is ugly, and the punishment Allah threatened for it is uglier and more severe.' Then he said 'Inna lillahi...'. Then he placed his finger on my cheek again and said: 'I testify that you are beautiful, and the good and reward Allah promised for (abstaining from) it is better and more beautiful.' Then he fell. I moved him, and behold, he was dead." The Sheikh said: "So I weep for that young man, his charm, his beauty, and his chastity until I die."

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani said: Al-Hasan bin Ali told me: Ahmad bin al-Harith al-Kharraz told us from Al-Mada'ini from Abu Bakr al-Hudhali who said: When Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, released Al-Hutay'ah from his prison, he said to him: "O Commander of the Faithful, write a letter for me to Alqama bin Ulatha so I may go to him, for you have forbidden me from earning through my poetry." He said: "I will not do it." It was said to him: "O Commander of the Faithful, what is it to you? Alqama is not your governor that you fear sinning regarding him; he is but a man of the Muslims you intercede for." So he wrote for him what he wanted. Al-Hutay'ah went with the letter and found Alqama had died, and people were leaving his grave. He stood over it and recited:
"By my life, excellent is the man from the family of Ja'far... in Hawran, whom the snares (of death) have caught.
If you live, I do not get bored, and if you die... then there is no benefit in life after your death.
There was nothing between me, had I met you safe,... and wealth except a few nights."
His son said to him: "How much did you think Alqama would give you?" He said: "One hundred she-camels." He said: "You have one hundred she-camels followed by one hundred of their offspring." So he gave them to him.

**Anecdote:**

And Abu al-Faraj also said: Abu Zayd told me: My uncle told me from his father from Ibn al-Kalbi from his father who said: A sheikh from Banu Nabhan told me: A famine struck Banu Shayban that took away their wealth. A man from them went out with his family until he settled them in Al-Hira. He said to them: 'Be close to the King so that some of his good may reach you, until I return to you.'
