He swore an oath upon himself not to return until he earned some good for them or died. He took provisions and walked for a day until night. He found a tied colt circling a tent. He said: 'This is the first booty.' He went to untie it and ride it, but a call came: 'Leave it and save yourself.' So he left it and walked for seven days until he reached a camel resting place as the sun was setting. There was a huge tent and a leather dome. He said: 'I said to myself: This tent must have people, this dome must have a master, and this resting place must have camels.' I looked into the tent and saw an old man whose collarbones differed (twisted), looking like a vulture. I sat behind him hiding. When the sun set, a knight approached; I never saw a knight greater or huger than him, on a tall horse, with two black slaves walking by his sides. There were a hundred camels with their stallion. The stallion knelt, and they knelt around it. He dismounted his horse and said to one of his slaves: 'Milk So-and-so then give the Sheikh to drink.' He milked into a large bowl until he filled it and placed it before the Sheikh and stepped aside. The Sheikh sipped from it once or twice then took it away. I rushed to it and drank it. The slave returned to him and said: 'O my master, he finished it.' He rejoiced at that and said to him: 'Milk So-and-so for him.' He milked it and placed the bowl before the Sheikh. He sipped one sip then took it away. I rushed to it and drank half of it, hating to finish it lest I be accused. The slave came, took it, and said to his master: 'He drank and quenched his thirst.' He said: 'Leave him.' Then he ordered a sheep slaughtered and roasted for the Sheikh. He ate, and he and his slaves ate. I waited until they slept and I heard snoring. I rushed to the stallion, untied its hobble, and rode it. It rushed off with me, and the camels followed. I traveled all night until morning. When morning came, I looked and saw no one. I drove them violently until the day rose high. Then I turned around and saw something like a bird. It kept getting closer until I distinguished it as a rider on a horse. It was my companion from yesterday. I hobbled the stallion, emptied my quiver, and stood between him and the camels. He stopped far away and said: 'Untie its hobble.' I said: 'No, by Allah. I left poor women in Al-Hira and swore an oath not to return until I benefit them with good or die.' He said: 'You are dead. Untie its hobble, may you have no mother.' I said: 'It is as I told you.' He said: 'You are deceived. Set up its halter for me and make five knots in it.' I did so. He said: 'Where do you want me to place my arrow?' I said: 'In this spot.' It was as if he placed it there with his hand. Then he began shooting until he hit the five knots with five arrows. I returned my arrows to my quiver, put down my bow, and stood surrendering. He approached me, took the sword and bow, and said: 'Ride behind me.' He recognized that I was the one who drank the milk at his place. He said: 'What is your opinion of me?' I said: 'The best opinion.' He said: 'How so?' I said: 'Because of the fatigue you faced last night, yet Allah gave you victory over me.' He said: 'Do you think we would harm you with evil when you spent the night drinking with Muhalhil?' I said: 'Are you Zayd al-Khayl?' He said: 'Yes, I am Zayd al-Khayl.' I said: 'Be the best captor.' He said: 'There is no harm on you.' He went to his place where he was, then said: 'If these camels were mine, I would have handed them to you, but they belong to the daughter of Muhalhil. Stay with me for I am on a high place.' I stayed with him for days. Then he raided Banu Numayr at Al-Milh and captured one hundred camels. He said: 'Is this dearer to you or that?' I said: 'This one.' He said: 'Take it.' He sent guides with me from water to water until they reached Al-Hira. A Nabataean met me and said: 'O Arab, would it please you to exchange these camels of yours for a garden among these gardens?' I said: 'How?' He said: 'This is the time a Prophet will emerge who will own this land and intervene between its owners and it, such that one of you will buy a garden for the price of a camel.' He said: I departed with my family until I reached a place. While we were at Al-Shattayn at a water of ours—Al-Hawfazan bin Sharik had raided Banu Tamim—the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came to us, and we accepted Islam. Only days passed before I bought a garden in Al-Hira for the price of one camel of my camels.

**Anecdote:**

And he also said: Muhammad bin al-Husayn bin Durayd told me: Al-Harmani told us from Al-Abbas bin Hisham from his father: Utba bint Afif, the mother of Hatim al-Tai, was wealthy and was one of the most generous people and most hospitable to guests. She would not keep anything she owned. When her brothers saw her squandering her wealth, they quarantined her and withheld her money. She remained for a time with nothing given to her. Until they thought she had felt the pain of that, they gave her a small herd of her camels. A woman from Mazin came to her; she used to come to her every year asking. She said to her: 'Take this herd, it is yours. By Allah, I have suffered from hunger such that I will never refuse a beggar after it.' Then she recited:
'By my life, hunger has bitten me a bite... so I swore not to withhold from a hungry one forever.
So tell this blamer today: Excuse me... for if you do not, then bite your fingers.
What can you say to your sister... except your blame or the blame of one who denies?
Is what you see today anything but nature... so how can I leave, O son of my mother, natures?'

**Anecdote:** Al-Haytham bin Adi—or Al-Qasim bin Adi—narrated from someone who told him from Malkhan, the nephew of Mawiya, Hatim's wife. He said: I said to Mawiya: 'O aunt, tell me some of the wonders of Hatim.' She said: 'All his affairs were wonders. Which one do you ask about?' I said: 'Tell me whatever you wish.' She said: 'A famine struck the people, destroying camels and sheep. One night, hunger kept me and him awake. He took Adi, and I took Suffana, and we tried to soothe them until they slept. Then he turned to me entertaining me with talk so I would sleep. I pitied his exhaustion, so I refrained from answering him so he would sleep. He said to me: "Are you asleep?" several times, but I did not answer. He fell silent. He looked and lifted the tent flap, and behold, something approached. He raised his head and it was a woman. He said: "Who is this?" She said: "I am, O Abu Suffana, coming to you from children howling like wolves from hunger." He said: "Bring me your children, by Allah I will satisfy them." She said: I got up quickly and said: "With what, O Hatim? By Allah, your children did not sleep from hunger except by being soothed." He said: "By Allah, I will satisfy your children along with hers." When she came, he went to his horse and slaughtered it. Then he struck a fire and kindled it. He gave her a knife and said: "Roast and eat." Then he said to me: "Wake up your children." I woke them up. Then he said: "This is meanness, that you eat while the people of the encampment are in a state like yours." He went to the encampment, house by house, saying: "Get up; come to the fire." They gathered around that horse. He wrapped himself in his cloak and sat aside. By morning, there was nothing of the horse left on the ground, little or much, except bone and hoof, while he was hungrier than them and had not tasted it.'

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj said: Ahmad bin Muhammad al-Bazzaz al-Atrush told me: Ali bin Harb told us: Hisham bin Muhammad told us: Abu Miskin Ja'far bin al-Muhriz bin al-Walid told us from his father who said: My grandfather Al-Walid, a client of Abu Hurayra, said: I heard Muhriz bin Abu Hurayra speaking saying: A man called Abu al-Khaybari passed with a group of his people by Hatim's grave. Around it were opposing stones like women wailing. They camped by it. Abu al-Khaybari spent the whole night saying: 'O Abu Adi, host your guests.' They said to him: 'Wait, why do you speak to decaying bones?' He said: 'Tayy claims that no one ever stopped by him while he was dead but that he hosted him,' mocking him. When it was the end of the night, Abu al-Khaybari slept. At dawn, he jumped up shouting: 'O my camel!' His companions said: 'Woe to you, what is wrong?' He said: 'By Allah, Hatim came out with a sword while I was looking at him until he hamstrung my she-camel.' They said: 'You lied.' He said: 'Nay.' They looked at his camel, and it was struggling, unable to stand. They said: 'By Allah, he has hosted you.' They slaughtered it and spent the day eating its meat. Then they let him ride behind one of them and departed. They traveled for a while, then looked at a rider, and it was Adi bin Hatim leading a black camel. He caught up with them and said: 'Which of you is Abu al-Khaybari?' They said: 'This one.' He said: 'My father came to me in a dream and mentioned your insulting him and that he hosted your camel for your companions. He recited verses about that and repeated them to me until I memorized them:
"O Abu al-Khaybari, you are a man... oppressive to creation, insulting them.
What did you want with bones... in a desert where their owl hooted?
Do you seek his harm and insolvency... while around you is aid and his cattle?
Indeed we feed our guests... from the herd, selecting them with the sword."
He ordered me to mount you on a camel, so here it is.' He took it, rode it, and they went.

**Anecdote:** He said: Ahmad bin Muhammad al-Bazzaz al-Atrush told me: Abu Miskin Ja'far bin al-Muhriz bin al-Walid told us from his father: Al-Waqidi said: Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi had claimed the Caliphate for himself in Rayy, and ruled it for one year, eleven months, and twelve days. He has many stories; the best of them in my opinion is what he told me. He said: When Al-Mamun entered Rayy and sought me most intensely, placing a reward of one hundred thousand dirhams for anyone who brought me, I feared for myself and became bewildered in my affair. I left my house at noon time—it was a summer day—not knowing where to head. I walked aimlessly until I ended up in a dead-end alley. I said: "We belong to Allah and to Him we return. If I go back on my tracks, I will be suspected." I saw at the head of the alley a black slave standing at the door of his house. I approached him and said: "Do you have a place where I can stay for an hour of the day?" He said: "Yes," and opened the door saying: "O master, enter with welcome and space. I am yours, and the house is at your command." I entered a clean house with a clean mat and a leather pillow, but clean. Then he locked the door on me and left. I imagined he had heard the reward for me and went out to guide to me. I remained anxious like on fire. While I was like that, he arrived with a porter carrying everything needed of bread, meat, a new pot and its tools, a clean jar, and new cups. He unloaded from the porter then turned to me and said: "May Allah make me your ransom. I am a cupper (barber), and I know you shrink from me because of my livelihood. So do as you please with what no hand has touched." I needed food, so I cooked a pot for myself; I do not remember eating the like of it. When I satisfied my need for food, he said: "Would you like a drink, for it consoles worry, scents the mouth, improves the soul, and removes grief?" I said: "I do not dislike that," desiring to be friendly with him. He brought a new glass jar untouched by hands, and brought me two vessels of perfumed drink and said: "Clarify for yourself." So I clarified a drink of utmost quality. He brought me a new cup, fruits, and snacks in new clay basins. Then he said: "Do you permit me, may I be your ransom, to sit aside from you and drink some of my nabidh (date wine) out of joy for you?" I said: "Do so." He drank, and I drank three. Then he went into a closet of his and brought out a laminated lute and said: "O master, it is not my rank to ask you to sing, but your nobility has obligated my sanctity upon you. If you see fit to honor your slave by singing for yourself, do so." I said: "How did you know I sing well?" He said with wonder: "Glory be to Allah! You are more famous than that. You are Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi, our Caliph of yesterday, for whom Al-Mamun put a hundred thousand dirhams reward." He said: When he said that, his ambition and manliness grew in my eyes, and I knew his pride was greater than what was offered for me. I took the lute, fixed it, and sang, as separation from my family and children crossed my mind:
'Perhaps He who returned his family to Joseph... and honored him in prison while he was a captive,
Will respond to us and gather our union... for Allah is capable over all worlds.'
He said: "O master, do you make what you sing what I requested of you?" I said: "Yes." He said: "It occurred to me:
Indeed He who tied the knot which tied... the knot of hardships upon you is good at untying it.
So be patient, for Allah follows with relief... perhaps it will clear, and perhaps."
So I sang it. I did not know its tune, but I composed it on the spot and took it as a good omen, and its rendition was good to me. I drank and drank. He said: "It occurred to me, O master:
Do not panic if you are in difficulty one day... for you have been in ease for a long time.
And do not despair, for despair is disbelief... perhaps Allah will enrich from a little.
And do not think of your Lord other than good... for Allah is worthy of beauty."
I knew it, so I sang it. He drank and I drank. He said: "I have a vow to Allah if you comfort me with your proximity—and I never thought time would allow your being in my house—if you see fit to sing:
And if my soul disputes with me, I tell it: Be patient... death will relieve you or ascending the pulpit.
What has been decreed for souls, be patient for it... and you have safety from what has not been decreed."
I sang it, and his request pleased me, and I found it witty. Then he said: "O master, do you permit me to sing what occurs to me, even if I am not of the people of this art?" I said: "An increase in your etiquette and manliness." He took the lute and sang:
'We complained to our loved ones about the length of our night... They said to us: How short is the night with us!
That is because sleep covers their eyes... quickly, and sleep does not cover our eyes.
When the night, harmful to the lover, approaches... we panic, and they rejoice when it approaches.
If they were encountering the like of what... we encounter, they would be like us in the beds.'
By Allah, I felt the verse carry me away, and all the panic in me left and I forgot it. I asked him to sing, so he sang:

'She taunts us that we are few in number... I said to her: Indeed, the noble are few.
What harm is it to us that we are few and our neighbor... is honored, while the neighbor of the many is humiliated?
We are a people who do not see it as a disgrace... what Amir and Salul see.
The love of death brings our terms closer to us... and their terms hate it, so they grow long.'

He filled me with such delight that there was no more to add, until intoxication overtook me and him. I did not wake up until after sunset. My thought returned to the preciousness of this cupper, his good manners and wit, and how he requested from me songs intended to console me, and my singing which contained hints to his specialty. I stood up, washed my face, and woke him. I took a purse I had with me containing dinars of great value and threw it to him. I said to him: "I entrust you to Allah, for I am leaving you. I ask you to spend what is in this purse on some of your needs, and you have with me more if I am safe from my fear." He returned it to me, denying it, and said: "O master, the poor among us has no value to you people of leadership, and you think bad thoughts of him. Should I take a price for what time granted me of your proximity and staying with me?" I insisted, so he pointed to his razor and said: "By Allah, if you repeat that to me, I will kill myself." I feared for him, took the purse, and returned it to my sleeve, its weight burdening me. When I reached the door of his house resolving to leave, he said: "O master, this place is more hidden for you than others, and I am not burdened by your provision, so stay with me until Allah grants you relief." I returned and asked him to spend from that purse, but he refused. Every day he did the like of what he did on the day of my arrival. I stayed some days in the best life. I felt guilty staying at his expense and was shy of burdening him, so I left him, while he continued renewing our conditions. I stood up, dressed in women's clothing with boots and veil, and left. When I was on the road, intense fear entered me. I came to cross the bridge, but the water had splashed on a spot making it slippery. A soldier who used to serve me saw me and recognized me. He said: "This is Al-Mamun's need!" and grabbed me. Out of love for life, I pushed him and his horse, throwing them into that slippery spot. He became a spectacle, and people rushed to kill him (or save him/beat him). I struggled walking until I crossed the bridge. I entered an alley and found a house door with a woman in its vestibule. I said: "O mistress of women, save my blood, for I am a fearful man." She said: "Welcome." She took me up to a room, furnished it for me, offered me food, and said: "Calm your fear, for no creature knows you are with me, even if you stayed a year." She was with me in that when the door was knocked violently. She went out and opened the door. It was my companion whom I pushed on the bridge, his head bandaged, blood running on his clothes, without a horse. She said to him: "What happened to you?" He said to her: "My story is strange. I obtained riches and they escaped me." She said: "How so?" He said: "Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi, I met him and grabbed him, but he pushed me and the horse, so what you see happened to me, and he escaped. If I had brought him to Al-Mamun, I would have made a hundred thousand dirhams." She brought out a rag, treated his wound, bandaged it, made a bed for him in the hall, and he slept sick. She came up to me and said: "I think you are the owner of the story." I said: "Yes." She said: "No harm on you." Then she renewed her hospitality to me, and I stayed with her for three days. Then she said: "I fear for you from this man lest he discover your affair and inform on you, so save yourself." I asked her to delay me until night, and she did. When night entered, I wore women's clothes and left her. I came to the house of a former slave woman (mawlah) of mine. When she saw me, she wept, pained for me, and praised Allah for my safety. She went out as if she wanted the market to prepare hospitality, so I thought good. Before I knew it, Ibrahim al-Mawsili himself appeared with his cavalry, foot soldiers, and entourage, and the mawlah with him, until she handed me over to him. I saw death with my own eyes. I was carried in my attire to Al-Mamun. He sat in a public session and I was brought in. When I stood before him, I greeted him as Caliph. He said: "May Allah not grant you peace, nor life, nor care." I said: "Gently, O Commander of the Faithful. The avenger is the judge in retaliation, but forgiveness is closer to piety. Whoever is deceived by the extended ropes of hope is not safe from the aggression of fate. Allah Almighty has placed you above every pardon, just as He made every sin beneath your pardon. If you punish, it is by your right; and if you forgive, it is by your grace." Then I recited:
'My sin against you is great... and you are greater than it.
So take your right first... then pardon with your clemency from it.
If I was not in my deeds... of the noble, then you be (of them).'
He raised his head to me, so I hastened and said:
'I committed a great sin... and you are worthy of forgiveness.
If you forgive, it is grace... and if you punish, it is justice.'

Al-Mamun softened towards me, and I sensed the scents of mercy in his demeanor. Then he turned to his brother Abu Ishaq al-Mu'tasim, his son Al-Abbas, and all those present of his elite and said: 'What do you say regarding his matter?' All advised killing me, except they differed on how the killing should be. Al-Mamun said to Ahmad bin Abi Khalid: 'What do you say, O Ahmad?' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, if you kill him, I have found the likes of you who killed the likes of him; but if you forgive him, I have not found the likes of you who forgave the likes of him.' Al-Mamun lowered his head and began tapping the ground with his finger, reciting proverbially:
'My people, they killed Umaym, my brother... So if I shoot, my arrow hits me.
So if I forgive, I forgive a great thing... And if I assault, I weaken my bone.'
I uncovered the veil from my head and shouted 'Allahu Akbar' a great takbir and said: 'By Allah, the Commander of the Faithful has forgiven me.' Al-Mamun said: 'No harm on you, O uncle. Apologize.' I said: 'My sin, O Commander of the Faithful, is too great for me to utter an excuse with it, and your pardon is too great for me to speak gratitude with it. But I say:
Indeed He who created noble traits gathered them... in the loin of Adam for the seventh Imam.
The hearts of people were filled with awe of you... and you continue to guard them with a humble heart.
So you forgave one whom the like of was never... forgiven, nor did an intercessor intercede with you for him.
And you had mercy on children like sandgrouse chicks... and the yearning of a mother with an anxious heart.
Returning life to me after it was gone... is the generosity of the Just, Humble King.'
Al-Mamun said to me: 'There is no blame on you today. I have forgiven you and returned your wealth and estates to you.' I said:
'You returned my wealth and were not stingy with it to me... and before returning my wealth, you spared my blood.
I felt safe from you, and you bestowed favors on me... excellent are the two lives: from death and from non-existence.
If I sacrificed my blood seeking your pleasure with it... and wealth until I pull the shoe from my foot,
That would be nothing but a loan returned... to you; had you not gifted it, you would not be blamed.
Kindness to me from you is treading the excuse you have for me... in what I committed, so you did not chide or blame.
If I denied what you bestowed of favors... I would be more worthy of blame than you of generosity.'
Al-Mamun said: 'Indeed, among speech is speech like pearls, and this is of it.' He ordered money and robes for Ibrahim and said: 'O Ibrahim, Abu Ishaq and Al-Abbas advised killing you.' I said: 'They gave you sincere advice, O Commander of the Faithful, but you refused except what you are worthy of, and repelled what I feared with what I hoped.' Al-Mamun said: 'My malice has died with the life of your excuse, and I have forgiven you. Greater than my forgiving you is that I did not make you swallow the bitterness of indebtedness to intercessors.' Then Al-Mamun prostrated for a long time, then raised his head and said: 'O Ibrahim, do you know why I prostrated?' I said: 'In thanks to Allah who granted you victory over the enemy of your state.' He said: 'I did not intend that, but thanks to Allah for inspiring me to forgive you. Now tell me your story.' I explained to him the situation of my affair and what happened to me with the cupper, the soldier, and the mawlah who handed me over. Al-Mamun ordered the mawlah to be brought while she was in her house awaiting the reward. He said to her: 'What drove you to do what you did despite Ibrahim and his family's kindness to you?' She said: 'Desire for money.' He asked her: 'Do you have a child or husband?' She said: 'No.' He ordered her to be flogged two hundred lashes and imprisoned for life. Then he said: 'Bring the soldier, his wife, and the cupper.' They were brought. He asked the soldier about the reason that drove him to do what he did. He said: 'Desire for money.' Al-Mamun said to him: 'You are more fitting to be a cupper than to be among our allies.' He appointed someone to force him to sit in the cupper's shop to learn cupping. He employed his wife, after treating her well, as a housekeeper in his palace, saying: 'This is a wise, polite woman suitable for important tasks.' Then he said to the cupper: 'There has appeared from your manliness what necessitates preserving you.' He handed him the soldier's house and beast, gave him robes, and established him with his salary plus an increase of a thousand dinars every year. He continued in good condition until he died.

**Anecdote:** Sulayman bin Wahb narrated: When Al-Wathiq persecuted me, he said to Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik al-Zayyat: 'Torture Sulayman, restrict him, confiscate him, and demand the money.' Sulayman said: 'So he dressed me in a wool jubba, shackled me, and restricted me. He used to bring me to Al-Wathiq's house and address me with the harshest address, threaten me, and treat me with the ugliest and most hideous treatment. Informers would write this to Al-Wathiq, and it would please him. When it was night, Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik ordered my shackles removed and my clothes changed. He would lay out a prayer rug for me, keep me company, eat and drink with me, consult me in his affairs, and confide his secrets to me. When it was time for me to leave him, he would tap my shoulder with his hand and say: "O Abu Ayyub, this is the right of friendship, and that is the right of the Sultan. Do not deny this, nor deny that." So I would thank him for his deed. When it was tomorrow, we returned to what we were on, as if we did not know each other.'

**Anecdote:**

Hammad bin Ishaq narrated from his father who said: I entered upon Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi'. Al-Rashid had been informed about Yahya bin Abdullah bin al-Hasan, whom he had ordered him to kill. He (Al-Rashid) did not reveal to him that he heard about him releasing him, but asked him about his news: 'Did you kill him?' He said: 'No.' He said to him: 'Where is he?' He said: 'I released him.' He said: 'Why?' He said: 'Because he asked me by the right of Allah Almighty and His Messenger and his kinship to him and to you, and swore to me that he would not cause any event and that he would come to me whenever I requested him.' He (Al-Rashid) looked down for an hour, then said to him: 'Go yourself in search of him until you bring him to me, and leave immediately.' So he left. Ishaq said: I entered upon him congratulating him on safety. I said to him: 'I have never seen a firmer heart nor a more correct opinion than yours in what happened. You are, by Allah, as Ashja' said:
His intuition and thought are equal... when a great calamity befalls him.
The most decisive time in opinion... is when the consultant and advisor are incapable.
And a chest in which there is room for worry... when chests are narrowed by worry.'
Al-Fadl said: 'Look how much Ashja' was given for this poem and carry the like of it to Abu Muhammad.' He said: It was found that he had taken thirty thousand dirhams, so they were carried to me.

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani said: ... Ibn Aisha said: Hisham bin Abd al-Malik performed Hajj during the caliphate of his brother Al-Walid, accompanied by the people of Sham. He struggled to touch the Black Stone but could not due to the crowding of people. A pulpit was set up for him, and he sat on it looking at the people. Zain al-Abidin Ali bin al-Husayn, may Allah be pleased with them, approached. He was the most handsome of people in face, cleanest in dress, and best in scent. He circled the House. When he reached the Stone, the people all moved aside for him and cleared the Stone for him to touch, out of awe and reverence for him. This enraged Hisham and affected him. A man said to Hisham: 'Who is this, may Allah amend the Emir?' He said: 'I do not know him'—though he knew him well—but he feared the people of Sham would desire him and listen to him. Al-Farazdaq, who was present for all this, said: 'I know him, so ask me, O Sham, who he is.' He said: 'And who is he?' He said:
'This is he whose footprint the valley of Mecca knows... and the House knows him, and the Hill and the Sanctuary.
This is the son of the best of all Allah's servants... This is the pious, the pure, the clean, the banner.
In his hand is a cane whose scent is fragrant... In the hand of a noble one, having a high nose bridge.
He lowers his gaze out of modesty, and gaze is lowered out of awe of him... He is not spoken to except when he smiles.
When Quraysh sees him, their speaker says:... To the noble traits of this one, generosity is attributed.
The corner of the Hatim almost holds onto... the palm of his hand when he comes to touch it.
Your saying "Who is this?" does not harm him... The Arabs know whom you denied, and the non-Arabs.
Which creatures do not have on their necks... a favor from his priority or from him?
Whoever knows Allah knows the priority of this one... For religion from the house of this one reached the nations.'
Hisham imprisoned him. Al-Farazdaq said:
'Does he imprison me between Medina and the one... to which the hearts of people yearn turning?
Turning a head that was not the head of a master... and a cross-eye showing its defects.'
Hisham sent for him and released him fearing his tongue. Ali bin al-Husayn sent him ten thousand dirhams and said: 'Excuse us, O Abu Firas, if we had more than this at this time, we would have connected you with it.' He returned it and said: 'What I said was only for Allah, and I would not take anything from you for it.' Ali bin al-Husayn said to him: 'Allah has seen your place and thanked you, but we are a household; if we send something, we do not take it back.' He swore upon him, so he accepted it.

**Anecdote:** Ahmad bin Yahya al-Makki said: Ishaq al-Mawsili used to praise the Barmakids frequently and exaggerate in eulogizing them. He attended the assembly of Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi' one day and mentioned the Barmakids. This used to enrage Al-Fadl and affect him greatly. Some of those present said to Ishaq: 'Will you not cease mentioning these people and stop that, while you have in praising the Vizier what would reach the highest ranks with him and occupy the loftiest place in his soul?' Al-Fadl withheld from speaking, pleased with how Ishaq was addressed. Ishaq said: 'As for the Barmakids, my adherence to them, my love for them, and my praise of them are too famous to deny, and that, by Allah, is the least they deserve from me.' Then he turned to Al-Fadl, whose praise of them had enraged him. He said to him: 'Hear from me one thing of what they did for me; it is not great among their favors to me nor to my father before me. If you find an excuse for me in that, then do so; otherwise, do not.

At the beginning of my affair, I was living with my father in his house. Disputes would constantly occur between my slaves and his slaves, and my maids and his maids, as happens between these classes. They would complain to him, and I would notice annoyance and disapproval in his face. So I rented a house near him and moved to it with my maids and slaves. It was a spacious house, but I was not satisfied with the furnishings I had for it, nor for my friends who visited me to see the like at my place. I thought about that and how to handle it. My thinking increased until the ugliness of the gossip about someone like me living in a rented house crossed my mind, and that I was not safe from a time when permission to enter might be asked while I had someone I respected who didn't know my situation, and it would be said: "Your landlord is asking for the rent." My chest tightened severely because of that, exceeding the limit. I ordered my slaves to saddle a donkey I had so I could go to the open country to relieve myself of what entered my heart. It was saddled for me, and I put on a cloak and sandals and rode. The path led me, while I was thinking and not distinguishing the road I was taking, until I suddenly arrived at the door of Yahya bin Khalid. His slaves jumped to me and said: "Where is this road?" I said: "To the Vizier, may Allah honor him." They asked permission for me to enter, so I entered. I remained ashamed, having fallen into two ugly matters: if I entered upon him with a cloak and sandals and told him I intended him in that state, it would be bad manners; and if I told him I was passing by and did not intend you but made you a path, it would be ugly. Then I resolved to tell him the truth. When he saw me, he smiled and said: "What is this attire, O Abu Muhammad? Did we count for you intention, purpose, and visitation, then learned you made us a path?" I said: "No, by Allah, may Allah support the Vizier, but I will tell you the truth." He said: "Bring it." I told him the story from beginning to end. He said: "This is a valid right. Did this occupy your heart?" I said: "Yes, by Allah, and more." He said: "Do not occupy your heart with this. O boy, return his donkey and bring him a robe." They brought me a complete robe of his clothes, and I wore it. He called for food, and I ate. He placed the wine, and I drank and he drank, and I sang for him. In the midst of that, he called for an inkwell and wrote four notes which I thought some of might be a signature for a reward for me. Then he called one of his agents, gave him the notes, and whispered something to him. My hope for a reward increased. The man left, and we sat drinking while I waited, seeing nothing but the enjoyment. Then Yahya bin Khalid leaned back and slept. I stood up from his presence broken and disappointed. I went out, my donkey was brought to me, I rode it and traveled. When I passed the house, my slave said to me: "Where are you going?" I said: "To the house." He said: "By Allah, the house has been sold, and the whole alley has been bought, witnesses testified against its owners, the price has been weighed, and the buyer is sitting at your door waiting for you to identify you. I think he bought that for the Sultan," because I saw the matter in his haste and urgency as a Sultani matter. I fell from that into a matter not in my calculation. I traveled not knowing what to do. When I dismounted at the door of my house, the agent to whom Yahya whispered stood up to me and said: "Enter your house, may Allah support you, so I can enter into a matter in which I need to speak to you." My soul felt good, so I entered, and he entered with me. He read to me a signature from Yahya granting Abu Muhammad Ishaq one hundred thousand dirhams to buy his house and all that neighbors and adjoins it. The second signature to his son Al-Fadl: "I have ordered Abu Ishaq one hundred thousand dirhams to buy his house; release for him another hundred thousand to spend on fixing the house as he wishes and building it as he desires." The third signature to his son Ja'far: "I have ordered Abu Muhammad Ishaq one hundred thousand to buy a house to live in, and your brother ordered him one hundred thousand dirhams to spend on building and repairing it as he wants; so release for him one hundred thousand dirhams to buy furnishings to exchange in it." The fourth signature to Muhammad: "I and your brothers have ordered Abu Muhammad Ishaq three hundred thousand dirhams for a house to buy, expenses to spend on it, and furnishings to exchange in it; so order for him yourself one hundred thousand dirhams to spend on the rest of his expenses." The agent said to me: "I have carried the money and bought everything neighboring you for seventy thousand dirhams. These are the deeds of purchase in my name and the acknowledgment to you. Here is the money, may it be blessed for you, take it." So I took it, and I became in better condition than my father in my house and all my furnishings and tools. Nay, by Allah, this is not one of the biggest things they did for me. Am I to be blamed for thanking them?

**Anecdote:**

It is said that Muawiyah's companions discussed in his presence one day the noble people and those of status and illustrious houses, while Al-Husayn bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them, was present. Muawiyah said: "Who do you know as the most generous of people in terms of father, mother, grandfather, grandmother, uncle, aunt (paternal), uncle, and aunt (maternal)?" They said: "The Commander of the Faithful knows best." He took the hand of Al-Husayn bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them, and said: "This one. His father is Ali bin Abi Talib, his mother is Fatima daughter of Muhammad, his grandfather is the Messenger of Allah, his grandmother is Khadija, his uncle is Ja'far bin Abi Talib, his paternal aunt is Hala bint Abi Talib, his maternal uncle is Al-Qasim son of the Messenger of Allah, and his maternal aunt is Zaynab daughter of Muhammad." All of them said: "The Commander of the Faithful spoke the truth."

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani said in his book: ... that Ubaydullah bin Abi Bakra wrote to Yazid bin Abi Rabi'a bin Mufrigh: "I have headed to Sijistan, so join me. Perhaps if you come to me, you will not regret it nor blame your opinion." Ibn Mufrigh prepared himself and went out until he came to Sijistan in the evening. He entered upon him, so he busied him with conversation and ordered a house, furnishings, and servants for him. He delayed him until he knew he had completed what was ordered for him, then dismissed him to the house prepared for him. Then he called for him on the second day and said to him: "O Ibn Mufrigh, you have endured a long journey to me, and your hope has expanded. You traveled to me so I would pay your debt for you and enrich you from people, and you said: 'Abu Hatim in Sijistan is capable of making me rich after him.'" He said: "By Allah, O Emir, you have not missed anything of what was in my soul." Ubaydullah said: "By Allah, I will do that, I will reduce your stay with me, and I will improve your gift." He ordered one hundred thousand dirhams, one hundred maidservants, and one hundred noble camels for him. He ordered for him what he would spend until he reached his country apart from the hundred thousand, and enough servants and clients to serve him. He said to him: "Part of the lightness of travel is not to worry about hoof or camel." His stay with him was seven days. Then he departed, and Ubaydullah bin Abi Bakra saw him off to a village four parasangs away called Zaliq. Then he said to him: "O Ibn Mufrigh, it is fitting for the bidder of farewell to leave and the speaker to fall silent. I am whom you have known. Spend on hope, and improve your opinion of me and your hope in me. If it occurs to you to return, then return. Peace." Ibn Mufrigh traveled until Ahvaz. Ubaydullah's messengers returned from him and said: "We have reached where we were ordered." He said: "Yes." Then he ordered Anahid bint A'naq, a woman he loved, to open the door, and said to her: "Everything that enters your house is yours." He stayed in Ahvaz and invited boon companions he had among the Arab youths. No wit or singer remained but came to him. A group of people from Basra, Kufa, and Sham sought his generosity, and he gave to them. He did not leave Anahid with any money. The people began asking him about Ubaydullah bin Abi Bakra and how he and his morals and generosity were. He said:
"The people of Iraq ask me about generosity... I said Ubaydullah is the ally of noble traits.
A Hatim-like youth, his saddle is in Sijistan... It is enough generosity for you that he is like Hatim.
He rose to attain honors and attained them... with the strength of a lion and the giving of dirhams.
And forbearance, when the fit of war is unleashed... he grants the people during the worsening calamity.
He has a favor in every tribe... discussed by riders and people of the seasons (Hajj).
His generosity and loyalty invited me to him... and beyond his night journey are the enemies of the non-Arabs.
I stayed only a week in his neighborhood... and two days lawful from the oath of a sinner.
Until he bid me farewell, adorned by Allah with loftiness... and grew the broken feathers of my wing.
He said: If you wish, O Ibn Mufrigh... then return a return that is not like the confused dreams of a sleeper.
I said to him: May Allah not make his house far... I will return if I come to you without retinue.
I praised my arrival when I arrived at his pools... and every generous one is an opportunity for the noble.
So he became hoping for nothing from Iraq and its people... neither for benefit nor for repelling great misfortunes.
Indeed Ubaydullah prepared his support... freely and gave his good without sterility."

**Anecdote:**

And Abu al-Faraj also said: ... Al-Qahdhami said: Yazid bin Mufrigh's creditors stuck to him for a debt. He said to them: 'Let us go sit at the door of Prince Isa until the nobles come out and see me, so they pay my debt for me.' So they went with him. The first to come out was either Umar bin Ubaydullah bin Ma'mar or Talha al-Talhat. When he saw him, he said: 'Abu Uthman, what seated you here?' He said: 'These creditors of mine stuck to me for a debt I owe.' He said: 'How much is it?' He said: 'Seventy thousand.' He said: 'Ten thousand dirhams of it are on me.' Then the other came out afterwards and asked him what his companion asked. He said: 'Did anyone come out before me?' They said: 'Yes, So-and-so.' He said: 'What did he do?' They said: 'He guaranteed ten thousand dirhams.' He said: 'The like of it is on me.' People kept coming out; some guaranteeing a thousand up to more than that, until they guaranteed forty thousand. He was hoping for Ubaydullah bin Abi Bakra, but he did not come out until the sun set. He came out rushing and did not see him until he almost reached his house. It was said to him: 'You passed by Ibn Mufrigh who is detained, and nobles passed by him and guaranteed for him.' He said: 'What a shame! I fear he thinks I ignored him.' He turned back and found him sitting. He said to him: 'Abu Uthman, what seats you here?' He said: 'These creditors of mine are detaining me.' He said: 'How much do you owe?' He said: 'Seventy thousand.' He said: 'How much was guaranteed for you?' He said: 'Forty thousand.' He said: 'Enjoy them, and your entire debt is on me.' He said about him:
'If you wished, you would not suffer nor toil... You lived by the means of Abu Hatim.
You lived by the means of the generous one who... does not seal wealth with a seal.
From the hand of a chief who has equipment... such that whoever opposes him has no protector.
The feeder of people when... their winds withhold rain in the fierce time.
And the decider of the plan on the day of dispute... for the matter necessary at distress.
I neighbored him for a time and praised him... I praise, and the praiser is not like the blamer.
How many a hating, gloating enemy... did you disgrace one day, and how many a tyrant,
Did you make taste death by surprise... with a sharp sword of white luster.'

**Anecdote:** He also said: ... Yahya bin Urwa bin Udhayna said: My father and a group of poets came to Hisham bin Abd al-Malik. He asked their lineage, and they identified themselves. When he recognized my father, he said to him: "Are you the one who says:
'I have known, and the ambition is not behind me... that what is my provision will come to me.
I strive for it, and seeking it wearies me... and if I sat, it would come to me causing me no fatigue.
Indeed, the luck of a person other than me will reach him... inevitably, inevitably, he will possess it without me.
There is no good in greed that brings one close to deficiency... and a little of sufficient living suffices me.
I do not ride a matter whose consequences are shameful... nor is my honor or religion faulted by it.
How many a poor man, rich of soul, do you know... and how many a rich man, poor of soul, is destitute.
And an enemy who shot at me, had I sat for him... would not have taken half from me when shooting me.
And a brother of mine who turned away, I said to him... Indeed your turning away from me will fold me up.
I indeed speak in what is my concern... and increase silence in what does not concern me.
I do not seek the connection of one who seeks my separation... nor do I soften for one who does not desire my softness.'"
Ibn Udhayna said to him: "Yes, I am the one who said it." He said: "Then why didn't you sit in your house until your provision came to you?" Hisham neglected him, so he left immediately, mounted his camel, and departed. Hisham missed him and learned his news. He sent a reward after him and said to the messenger: "Say to him: You wanted to make us liars and prove yourself truthful." The messenger went and caught up with him while he had stopped at a water place having lunch. He delivered the message and gave him the reward. He said: "Tell him my Lord proved me truthful and you a liar." Yahya bin Urwa said: He assigned him two stipends, and I was in one of them.

**Anecdote:** And Abu al-Faraj also said: ... Yazid bin Mazyad entered upon Al-Rashid. He said to him: "O Ibn Mazyad, who says about you:
'Perfume does not cling to his cheeks and parting... nor does he wipe his eyes with kohl.
He has accustomed the birds to habits they trusted... so they follow him in every departure.'"
He said: "I do not know who said it, O Commander of the Faithful." Harun said to him: "Is such poetry said about you and you do not know its speaker?" He left his presence ashamed. When he arrived at his house, he called his chamberlain and said: "Which poet is at the door?" He said: "Muslim bin al-Walid." He said: "And how did you block him from me and not inform me of his presence?" He said: "I told him you are in straits and have nothing in your hand to give him, and asked him to wait and stay for days until you have means." He denied that from him and said: "Let him in." He entered and recited his saying about him:

'I dragged the rope of a dissolute in youth, flirtatious... and the determinations of blamers fell short of blaming me.
The ambitious eye returned weeping, a passion... dividing between farewell and departure.
Was it not enough for separation to shoot me with its arrows... that it shot me with the glance of wide eyes?
From what they committed against me, even if they were from me, they proved true... an ardor whose delivery was stolen by eyes.'
Until he says in it:
'Overlooking souls on a day of dust... as if he is a death hastening to a hope.
You see him in safety in double armor... Fate is not safe from being called upon in haste.
Perfume does not cling to his cheeks and parting... nor does he wipe his eyes with kohl.
When he draws his sword, its paths are... the paths of death in intestines and eyes.
And if you are alone with self-talk, his look is... hope lives and fear dies from dread.
Like the lion, if you stir him, death is his rest... he does not rest to days and states.
He has accustomed the birds to habits they trusted... so they follow him in every departure.
To Allah belongs a mountain of Hashim in his land... and you and your son are the pillars of that mountain.
You proved my opinion true and proved thoughts true about him... and your generosity put down the knot of the saddle from my camel.'
He said to him: "We have ordered fifty thousand dirhams for you, so take it and excuse." The chamberlain went out and said: "He ordered me to mortgage an estate of his for one hundred thousand dirhams, fifty thousand for you and fifty thousand for his expenses," so he gave it to him. The intelligence officer wrote about that to Al-Rashid, so he ordered two hundred thousand dirhams for him and said: "Pay the fifty thousand the poet took and add the like to it, and take one hundred thousand for yourself." So he redeemed his estate and gave Muslim another fifty thousand.

**Anecdote:** It is said that Mukhariq loved a maid of Umm Ja'far named Nhar. He was infatuated with her, hiding it from Umm Ja'far until it reached her. She distanced him and banned him from passing her door. When he knew the news reached Umm Ja'far, he cut ties and avoided her out of reverence for Umm Ja'far and hoping to forget her. He became distressed by that. While he was one night in a boat returning from Al-Mamun's house, and Umm Ja'far was overlooking the Tigris, he passed her house. He saw candles shining in it. When he was within hearing and sight of her, he burst into singing poetry by Al-Abbas al-Ahnaf:
'If they ban my passing near their house... I will look from afar at the house.
They cannot ban me, even if they try hard... if I pass and my greeting is hidden.
What harm would it do your neighbors, may Allah amend them... were it not for my misery, my approach and retreat?
The mark of love was publicized until I became known by it... that I am a lover, and there is no shame in love.'
Umm Ja'far said: "Mukhariq, by Allah! Bring him back." They shouted to him, so he came. The servants ordered him to ascend, so he ascended. Umm Ja'far ordered a chair and a tray with wine for him. He drank, and she gave him a robe. She ordered the maids to sing, then they played for him, so he sang. The first thing he sang was also poetry by Al-Abbas:
'I am absent from you with a love not changed by... distance of place nor turn of time.
If I live, perhaps time will gather us... and if I die, then a victim of worry and sadness.
Allah has beautified what you did in my eyes... until I see as beautiful what is not beautiful.'
He said: Nhar burst into singing as if following him, but she answered the meaning he alluded to:
'You use busyness as an excuse not to visit us... The busyness is for the heart, the busyness is not for the body.'
Umm Ja'far thought she addressed her with what was in her soul, so she laughed and said: "We have not heard better than what you two did," and she gifted her to him.

**Anecdote:** Abu Zayd said: Some Arabs raided the livestock of Ahmad bin Anqa' al-Fazari and drove them away until nothing remained. He came to his nephew and said to him: "O son of my brother, what you see has befallen your uncle, so is there any milking animal?" He said: "Yes, uncle, when the wealth returns (in the evening), attain your desire." When his wealth returned, he divided it with him and gave him half. Ibn Anqa' said:
'He saw me suffering from what was in me, so he complained... to his wealth about my condition, secretly as if openly.
He called me and consoled me, and if he were stingy I wouldn't blame... at a time when no Bedouin is hoped for nor city dweller.
So I said good to him and praised his deed... and fulfilled what you wore out of blame or thanks.
A youth whom Allah threw with good while young... having a sign not hard on the sight.
As if the Pleiades were hung on his forehead... and on his cheek Sirius and on his face the moon.
When he saw glory, his clothes were reclaimed... he wore a wide-tailed robe and wrapped himself.
If a flaw appeared, he turned away as if... humiliated without humiliation, and if he wished he would triumph.'

**Anecdote:**

From Ibn Umar, who said: Ishaq bin Ibrahim al-Zahiri saw the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in his dream saying to him: "Release the killer." He woke up terrified, called for a candle, and brought the letters arriving from the jailers. He did not see a mention of a killer in them. He ordered Al-Sindi and Abbas to be brought and asked them about the news. Abbas said to him: "Yes, we wrote with news of a killer." He re-examined them and found the letter in the folds of papers. There was a man against whom testimony of killing was given, and he confessed to it. He ordered him brought. When he stood before him and he saw his terror, he said to him: "If you tell me the truth, I will release you." He began informing him. He mentioned that he and a number with him used to commit every enormity and permit every forbidden act. Their meeting was in the city of Abu Ja'far, keeping to every calamity. One day, an old woman who used to visit them for corruption came to them with a girl of outstanding beauty. He said: When the girl reached the middle of the house and saw us, she screamed a scream and fainted. When she woke up, she said: "For God's sake regarding me! This old woman deceived me and informed me that among her neighbors were people who had a right (party/event) like never seen, and made me long to look at it. I went out with her trusting her word, and she attacked me with you. My grandfather is the Messenger of Allah, my mother is Fatima, and my father is Al-Husayn bin Ali, so preserve them in me." It was as if, by Allah, she only incited them with herself. I stood up for her and defended her, fighting those who wanted her until I received wounds. I aimed at the most intense of them—he was like their dog in her affair—and killed him. The girl got free from him safe, and I brought her out safe. I heard her say addressing me: "May Allah cover you as you covered me, and be for you as you were for me." The neighbors heard a noise and entered upon us. The knife was in my hand, and the man was wallowing in his blood. I was raised in that state. Ishaq said: "I have known what was from you, and I have gifted you to Allah and His Messenger." The man said: "By the right of the One you gifted me to, I will never return to a sin again."

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani raised it to Ali bin Umar, said: Muslim bin al-Walid, known as Sari' al-Ghawani, told me: I was sitting one day in a tailor's shop opposite my house when I saw a knocker at my door. I stood up to him, and it was a friend of mine from Kufa who had arrived from Qom. I was happy with him. He was a person who slapped my face (i.e., shamed me) because I did not have a single dirham to spend on him. I stood up, greeted him, brought him into my house, and took two boots I had for dressing up. I gave them to my maid and wrote a note with her to an acquaintance in the market asking him to sell the boots and buy me meat and bread for a price I named. The maid went and returned having bought all I specified, having sold the boots for nine dirhams. It was as if she brought me two new boots. I sat cooking with my guest, and I asked a neighbor to give us a bottle of nabidh (wine). He sent it to me. I ordered the maid to lock the door fearing a knocker would come and share what we were in, hoping what we had would remain for me and him until he left.

We were sitting cooking when the door was knocked. I said to the maid: "Look who this is." She looked through the crack of the door and said it was a man wearing black, a Shashiyya (cap), and a belt, accompanied by a lackey. She told me his position, and I denied my affair (feigned ignorance/hid). Then I returned to myself and said: "I am not a man of vice, nor does the Sultan have a way against me." I opened the door and went out to him. He dismounted his beast and said: "Are you Muslim bin al-Walid?" I said: "Yes." He said: "How can I verify you?" I said: "The one who guided you to my house can verify me." He said to his slave: "Go to the tailor and ask him about him." He went and asked, and he said: "Yes, he is Muslim bin al-Walid." He brought out a letter from his boot and said: "This is a letter from Emir Yazid bin Mazyad to me ordering me not to break its seal except upon meeting you." He broke it, and in it was: "If you meet Muslim bin al-Walid, give him these ten thousand dirhams I have sent; let them be for him in his house. And give him three thousand dirhams for his expenses to travel to us." I took the three and the ten and entered my house. The man was with me. We ate that food, and I added to it and the drink. I bought fruit and expanded. I gave my guest some of the dirhams to buy a gift for his family. I started preparing (for travel). Then I remained with him until we arrived in Raqqa at the door of Yazid bin Mazyad. The man entered; he was one of his chamberlains. He found him in the bath. He came out to me and sat with me a little. Then the chamberlain informed me he left the bath. He brought me in, and there he was sitting on a chair. At his head was a maid holding a mirror case, and in his hand were a mirror and a comb with which he was combing his beard. He said to me: "O Muslim, what delayed you from us?" I said: "O Emir, lack of means." He said: "Recite to me." I recited my poem I came to him with:
'I dragged the rope of a dissolute in youth, flirtatious... and the determinations of blamers fell short of blaming me.'
When I reached my saying:

'Perfume does not cling to his cheeks and parting... nor does he wipe his eyes with kohl.'
He put the mirror in its case and said to the maid: "Leave, for Muslim has forbidden perfume for us." When I finished the poem, he said to me: "O Muslim, do you know what drove me to send for you?" I said: "No, by Allah, I do not know." He said: "I was with Al-Rashid nights ago squeezing his feet when he said to me: 'O Yazid, do you know who says about you:
Ask the Caliph for a sword of Banu Matar... passing through, piercing intestines and skulls.
Like time, he does not turn away from what he intends... he has encompassed people with bounty and compulsion.'
I said: 'No, by Allah, I do not know.' Al-Rashid said: 'Glory be to Allah, you remain in your Bedouin ways! Such poetry is said about you, and you do not know who said it?' I asked about its speaker and was told it was you. 'Stand up so I can bring you to the Commander of the Faithful.' He stood up and entered upon Al-Rashid. Before long, the usher came out to me. I entered upon Al-Rashid and recited to him what poetry I had about him. He ordered one hundred thousand dirhams for me, and Yazid ordered ninety thousand, saying: 'It is not permissible that I give you the like of what the Commander of the Faithful gave you.' He gave me land grants whose revenue reached two hundred thousand dirhams."

Muslim said: Then matters led after that to him angering me, so I satirized him. He complained about me to Al-Rashid. He summoned me and said: "Will you sell me Yazid's honor?" I said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful." He said: "For how much?" I said: "For a loaf of bread." He became angry until I feared for myself, and said: "I thought I would buy it from you for a huge sum, but I will not do it, and no honor (to you). You have known his kindness to you 'I am banished from my father by Allah' (an oath), by Allah if I hear that you satirized him, I will tear your tongue from between your jaws." So I refrained from him after that and mentioned him neither with good nor evil.

**Anecdote:** Al-Waqidi said: I had two friends, one Hashimite and the other Nabataean. We were like one soul. I suffered severe distress, and Eid arrived. My wife said to me: "As for us, we can be patient with misery and hardship, but as for these children of ours, my heart is torn with pity for them because they see the neighbors' children adorned for their Eid while they are in this state. If only you could devise something to spend on their clothes." I wrote to my Hashimite friend asking him to expand on me from what was available. He sent me a sealed purse mentioning it had a thousand dirhams. It had barely settled when my other friend wrote to me complaining of what I complained to my companion. I sent the purse to him as it was and went out to the mosque. I spent my night shy of my wife. When I entered upon her, she approved of that and did not blame me for it. While I was like that, my Hashimite friend arrived with the purse in its state and said: "Tell me the truth about what you did with what I sent you." I told him the news plainly. He said: "You sent to me while I owned nothing on earth except what I sent you. I wrote to our friend asking him for help, and he sent me my purse with my seal." He said: We took out one hundred dirhams for the woman and divided the rest among us in thirds. The news reached Al-Mamun, so he summoned me and asked me about it. I explained it to him, so he ordered seven thousand dinars for us: one thousand for the woman and two thousand for each one of us.

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani said: Ahmad bin Abi Tahir told me: Abu Du'ama Ali bin Yazid told me: Al-Tamimi or Muhammad told me: I entered upon Al-Hasan bin Sahl and recited a eulogy for Al-Mamun and a eulogy for him. Tahir bin al-Husayn was with him. Tahir said to him: "This, by Allah, O Emir, is the one who says about Muhammad the Deposed (Al-Amin):
'There must be drunkenness upon delight... perhaps a spirit will be relieved from distress.
The Caliph of Allah, best chosen one... for the best mother from Hashim and father.
The Caliphate of Allah inherited by... his fathers in the ancient books.
It is for you... inherited... from the Seal of Prophets in eras.
O son of him who is in the peaks of... ancient honor, you are the pillars of the Arabs.'
Al-Hasan said: "By Allah, the son of the uncircumcised woman insinuated against the Commander of the Faithful. By Allah, I will inform him." He stood up to Al-Mamun and informed him. Al-Mamun said to him: "What is against him in that? A man hoped in a man and praised him. By Allah, he was good to us and bad to him, since he did not draw near to him except by drinking wine." Then he summoned me, gave me a robe, and ordered ten thousand dirhams for me.

**Anecdote:** It is said Abd al-Malik bin Marwan went out to Al-Ghouta for a picnic. While traveling, he passed a bridge erected over some of its waters. The army had lagged behind him, and he was separated from his entourage. When he came down from the bridge, a man of the Arabs on a horse came to him. This alarmed him. He said to him: "Who are you and what is your business?" He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, I am one of the knights of the Arabs. My hope in you and the reliance of the needy upon you called me to you. Return me to my family safe, and from your wealth amply provided and gaining." He said: "O brother of the Arabs, have you not heard the poet's saying:

'Disobey the blamers and shoot arrows broadly... with a horse enduring a night of trotting.
Until you acquire wealth or it is said: A youth... met what splits young men, so he was split.
There is no good in a youth whose manliness has perished... giving leadership to one who does not lead well.'
He said: "And did the poet say that, O Commander of the Faithful?" He said: "Yes." He said: "I will act by what he said. Peace be upon you." He turned his horse and left. When he disappeared from Abd al-Malik's sight and his army caught up with him, he advanced in pursuit of the man but did not catch him. Then time struck its blows. It was reported to Abd al-Malik that a man of the Arabs rebelled in some regions, a group joined him, and money being carried to Abd al-Malik was intercepted by him. Abd al-Malik sent an army against him and defeated him. Then the days did not last long until his affair worsened and his power intensified. Abd al-Malik wrote to him asking what drove him to leave obedience and duel in war. He wrote back: "I am the knight of Al-Ghouta; I have done what you advised, and I have seen nothing but good from it until now." Abd al-Malik wrote to him enticing him, granting him safety, and promising that if he came to him obediently, he would reward him well. He carried a sum of money to him. He returned to him, leaving what he was involved in, and became one of the foremost with him, and his service was good.

**Anecdote:** He said: Muslim bin al-Walid entered one day upon Al-Fadl bin Yahya, who had received news of a son born to him. He sat for the poets, who praised him, and he rewarded them. He looked into people's needs and fulfilled them. The people dispersed from him, and he sat for drink. Muslim was not present for that; he only heard when the assembly ended. He was brought in and asked permission to recite. He permitted him, so he recited about him:
'The riding camels came guided by a mount... upon which is a youth like a blade comforted by a blade.'
Until he reached in it his saying:
'I came to the tent of Al-Fadl hoping for his favor... for the lot of great praise is great reward.
A youth whose cloud of generosity hopes graze upon... when their pasture was wishes and procrastination.
His right hand drops dew (generosity), and his left... death, and the essence of speech is his decisive word.
He pressed upon the days with the loops of their calamities... on a path he found his father on before.
Yahya and Khalid elevated highness with him... so there is no like to him nor like to them.
Branches that hit a firm planting place... and a root, so they were good where the origin directed them.
By the hand of Abu al-Abbas wealth is rained down... favors are brought down, and decisiveness is made to flow.'
He said: Al-Fadl was extremely delighted. He ordered the verses to be counted. They were counted and were eighty. He ordered eighty thousand dirhams for him and said: "Were it not that this is the most a poet has been gifted, I would have increased for you, but it is a limit that cannot be exceeded," meaning what Al-Rashid prescribed for Marwan bin Abi Hafsa. He ordered him to sit with him and stay for his companionship, so he stayed with him.

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani mentioned with a chain of transmission that Amr bin Bana said: I rode one day to the house of Salih bin al-Rashid and passed by Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Musa al-Hadi. He was addicted to morning draughts, but I found him that day free of it. I asked him the reason for his suspension. He said: "Niran is angry with me"—meaning a slave girl belonging to some slave traders in Baghdad. She was one of the excellent ones, of outstanding beauty and witty tongue. He had loved her excessively until he became known for it. I said to him: "So what would you like?" He said: "That you make your way to her master, for he will bring her out to you. If he does, give her this note of mine." He gave me a note containing:
'You wasted the covenant of a youth keeping your covenant... in his keeping is wonder and in your wasting.
You distanced from him so he has no device... except waiting for the time of your return.
Humbled, shedding his tears for you... in sorrow, wondering at the freezing of your tears.
That you let him slip and go with his heart... is by the beauty of your face, not the beauty of your deed.'
I said to him: "Yes, I will carry this message, and honor to me is what is in it, preserving your soul for you, for I am not safe from this matter continuing with you." I took the note and made my way to the slave trader's house. He sent for the girl to come out. She came out. I gave her the note and told her my news. She laughed and returned to the place she came out from. She sat for a brief sitting, then behold, she came to me with a note containing:
'You continue to exclude me and incite enemies against me... and abandon me until I became practiced in abandonment.
You cut my means and forget my affection... so how do you see, O my owner, my patience in love?
I have become not knowing: is it despair making me patient... over abandonment? Or do I find patience? I do not know.'

He said: I took the note from her and delivered it to him. I went to my house and composed a melody for Muhammad bin Ja'far's verses and a melody for her poetry. Then I went to Prince Salih bin al-Rashid and informed him of what happened to me and sang him the two songs. He ordered his beast to be saddled. It was saddled, and he rode, and I rode with him to the slave trader—Niran's master. We did not leave until he bought her from him for three thousand dinars and carried her to Muhammad bin Ja'far's house, gifting her to him. We stayed a day with him.

**Anecdote:** Judge Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad narrated: I have not seen a man to whom death was presented and he did not care about it, nor "did it distract him from what he wanted until he achieved it and Allah saved him from killing" except Tamim bin Jamil al-Sadusi the Kharijite. He had rebelled against Al-Mu'tasim. I saw him brought as a prisoner and entered upon him on the day of the procession. Al-Mu'tasim sat for the people in a public assembly and called for the sword and the leather mat. When he stood before him, Al-Mu'tasim looked at him; his beauty, stature, and his walking to death without caring about it pleased him. He thought about him for a long time, then asked him to speak to see where his mind and tongue stood in relation to his beauty. He said: "O Tamim, if you have an excuse, bring it." He said: "As for now, if the Commander of the Faithful permits speech, I say: Praise be to Allah who perfected everything He created and began the creation of man from clay, then made his progeny from a quintessence of despised fluid. O Commander of the Faithful, may Allah mend through you the fracture of religion, gather through you the disarray of Islam and Muslims, extinguish through you the meteor of falsehood, and illuminate through you the path of truth. Sins, O Commander of the Faithful, silence tongues and crack hearts. By Allah, the crime is great, the argument is cut off, and suspicion is bad. Nothing remains but your pardon or your vengeance. You are closer to pardon, and it is more like you and more fitting." Then he recited to him:
'I see death between the sword and the mat lurking... watching me wherever I turn.
My greatest thought is that you are my killer today... and what man escapes from what Allah has decreed?
What man presents an excuse and argument... while the sword of death is drawn between his eyes?
It is hard on Aws bin Tha'lab a position... where the sword is drawn on me and I am silent.
My panic is not that I die, for I... know that death is a timed thing.
But behind me are children I left... their livers crumbling from sorrow.
As if I see them when I am announced dead to them... slapping the heat of cheeks and wailing.
If I live, they live safe with envy... I drive destruction away from them, and if I die, they die.
How many a speaker: May Allah not make his house far... and another joyful, happy and gloating.'
He said: Al-Mu'tasim wept and said: "Indeed, from eloquence is magic," as the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said. Then he said: "O Tamim, by Allah, the sword almost preceded the blame. I have gifted you to Allah and to your children and forgave your slip." Then he contracted a governorship for him over his work, gave him robes, and gave him fifty thousand dinars.

**Anecdote:** It is said a Bedouin stood at the door of Dawud bin al-Muhallab for a year without being permitted entry. When permission was given to the people generally, he entered among them. Needs of people were fulfilled according to their classes, and he remained. Dawud raised his head and said: "Do you have a need, O Bedouin?" He said: "Yes, may Allah amend the Emir. I came to you praising with verses of poetry, hoping for a thousand dirhams for every verse." Dawud said to him: "Gently." Then he entered his house, girded his sword, and came out. He said: "Speak. If you do well, we will let you judge (your reward), and if you do not do well, we will deprive you." He began:
'I felt safe through Dawud and the generosity of his right hand... from the feared event, misery, and poverty.
I felt safe, so I fear no calamity with Dawud... nor misfortune, since I strengthened my back with him.
Talha al-Talhat did not equal him in generosity... nor Hatim al-Tai nor Khalid al-Qasri.
He has the wisdom of Luqman, the form of Joseph... the kingdom of Solomon, and the truthfulness of Abu Dharr.
A youth from whose generous palm wealth flees... as Satan flees from the Night of Decree.
He has ambitions with no end to their greatest... and his smallest ambition is greater than time.
His palm, if a tenth of a tenth of it... were on the land, the land would be dewier than the sea.'
Dawud said to him: "You have done well, O Bedouin. We have made you the judge. Which is more beloved to you: that I give you according to your worth, or according to my worth, or according to the worth of the poetry?" He said: "Rather, according to the worth of the poetry." He ordered a thousand dirhams for every verse for him, and he left. Some of his sitters said: "If you had called him back, O Emir, and asked him why he chose according to the worth of the poetry and not according to your worth?" He ordered him back and asked him about that. He said: "O Emir, I looked at the world and what is in it, and it does not equal a tenth of a tenth of your worth, so I feared asking you what you cannot bear." He said: "You have done well, by Allah, better than your poetry." He doubled the reward for him, and he took it and left.

**Anecdote:**

Al-Utbi from his father said: Zayd bin Munya came from Basra to Muawiyah. He is the brother of Ya'la bin Munya, owner of the Camel (Aisha's camel) and the one in charge of those wars and head of the people of Basra. Ya'la's daughter was married to Utba bin Abi Sufyan. When he entered upon Muawiyah, he complained to him of his debt. He said: "O Ka'b, give him thirty thousand." When he turned away, he said: "And for the Day of the Camel, thirty thousand more." Then he said: "Join your brother-in-law"—meaning Utba. He arrived at Utba in Egypt and said: "I traveled to you for two months wading through perils, wearing the cloaks of night once and wading the depths of mirage another, loaded with good opinion of you, and fleeing from a frowning time and a sticking debt, after wealth with which we cut the noses of enviers." Utba said: "Time lent you wealth and mixed you with us, then retrieved what it could take. There remains for you from us that with which there is no loss. I raise my hand and your hand is in Allah's hand." He gave him sixty thousand as Muawiyah gave him.

**Anecdote:** Al-Asma'i said: I passed by some Arab tribes, narrating their poetry and gathering their novel news. I left the tribe as if I hadn't entered it. Fate threw me to some clans. I asked the people of the clan for water, but I was not given drink. I left the clan and ended up at a solitary house. I asked its people for water. A girl came out to me with a cup of milk in one hand and a container with water in the other. She said: "O you, this is water and this is milk, start with whichever you wish. If you want food, it is prepared for you." I marveled at her generosity given her people's stinginess and my staying among them. Then I complained to her about her people's stinginess. She said: "Listen to me," then began saying:
'Take from people what is easy... and leave from people what is difficult.
For people are but glass... if you are not gentle with it, it breaks.'
I left with the two verses, and they were dearer to me than two hundred dinars. Then I saw a high mound with a solitary house on it. I said: "This house I see is surely one that is noble, and perhaps I will find a scholar in it." I headed for it. When I approached, there was a man standing at the door. When he saw me, he entered the house. I entered after him. He went out from the side of the house, and I went out after him. I followed him; he looked at me, stopped, wept loudly, and recited:
'I paused a pause of doubt, then certainty continued with me... that death is better than poverty.
And one saying she fears death for me... while death is better than life in hardship.
I will pour out wealth or die in a town... where the flow of tears on my grave is little.'
I said: "This is the speech of a writer and the poetry of a wise man. Increase me from your speech, may Allah increase you in every good." He said:
'I was granted a mind but not granted its manliness... and manliness is nothing but abundance of wealth.
If I want an elevation, the thinness of my condition... holds me back from making my name famous.'
I said to him: "O you, I am the Caliph's companion. Perhaps I can cultivate good for you with him. Increase me from your speech and good composition." He began saying:
'Whoever sows good harvests what pleases him... and the sower of evil is upside down on the head.
Indeed those whose flow of giving was hoped for... have become in a grave in the belly of dust.'
I brought his words to Al-Rashid. He admired them and gave me a thousand dinars, ordering me to return before visiting my family. He said: "Give them to the man, and if you do not meet him, give the money to the closest people to him." I came to the tribe and headed for the house. The house had been dismantled. I asked about him. It was said he was called and answered (died). I asked about the closest people to him. I was told: "The owner of this solitary house." I came to it, and it was my companion who gave me water. I asked her about her brother. She said: "O you, by Allah, he used to bear debts, build nobilities, and repel calamities. His people surrendered him to misfortunes and left him to calamities, so he perished, by Allah, wasted, and left no luggage." I said to her: "O you, I have a thousand dinars the Commander of the Faithful gifted you." She said: "May Allah connect the Commander of the Faithful with honor and increase his reward in the Abode of Standing." Then she said: "By Allah, we are too noble for a thousand dinars to gather with us, for which we would be accounted and punished." Then she said to her servant: "Bring me the old women of the tribe." She brought fifty old women. She divided the money among them and kept nothing of it except what fell to the share of one of them.

**Anecdote:** It is said Kuthayyir Azza had a merchant slave who came to Sham with goods to sell. Azza sent a woman asking for clothes. She stood over Kuthayyir's slave not knowing him. She bought her need from him but did not pay the price. He used to go to her demanding payment. One day he recited from his master's sayings:
'Every debtor paid and fulfilled his creditor... while Azza is a procrastinator making her creditor suffer.'

He said: The woman who bought the clothes from him said to him: "This, by Allah, is Azza's house, and for her, by Allah, I bought the clothes from you." He said: "By Allah, I am Kuthayyir's slave. I call Allah to witness that the clothes are hers, and I will take nothing of their price." This reached Kuthayyir, so he said: "And I call Allah to witness that he is free, and whatever wealth remains with him is his."

**Anecdote:** Al-Haytham bin Adi reported: Three men argued about the generous ones. One man said: "The most generous person in our time is Abdullah bin Ja'far bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him." Another said: "Rather, the most generous person today is Araba al-Awsi." Another said: "Rather, it is Qays bin Sa'd bin Ubada." They argued and exceeded in dispute, and their noise increased while they were in the courtyard of the Kaaba. A man said to them: "You have argued much. Why doesn't each of you go to his man and ask him, so we look at what he gives and judge by observation?"

Abdullah bin Ja'far's champion went to him and found him having placed his foot in the stirrup of his mount intending to go to an estate of his. He said to him: "O son of the worry of the Messenger of Allah." He said: "Say what you wish." He said: "A traveler cut off." He took his foot out of the stirrup and said: "Put your foot and settle on the she-camel, and take what is in the bag, and do not be deceived regarding the sword, for it is one of the swords of Ali bin Abi Talib." He came with the she-camel, and in the bag were silk cloaks and four thousand dinars, and the greatest and most majestic was the sword.

Qays bin Sa'd bin Ubada's champion went and found him asleep. The maid said: "He is asleep, what is your need with him?" He said: "A traveler cut off." She said: "Your need is easier than waking him up. This is a bag containing seven hundred dinars; there is nothing else in Qays's house today.
