Take it and go to the camel pens to our master with our sign, take one of his mounts and what suits it, and a slave, and go about your business." It is said that when Qays woke up from his sleep, the maid told him what she did, so he freed her.

Araba al-Awsi's champion went to him and found he had left his house intending prayer, leaning on two slaves, having lost his sight. He said: "O Araba." He said: "Say what you wish." He said: "A traveler cut off." He released the two slaves, clapped his right hand over his left, and said: "Awah! Awah! By Allah, Araba has neither morning nor night, for rights have left him no wealth. But take them"—meaning the two slaves. He said: "I was not one to clip your wings of them." He said: "If you do not take them, they are free. If you wish, take them; if you wish, free them." He proceeded touching the wall with his hand returning to his house. He said: So he took them and brought them.

It was said they were the most generous people of their time, except they ruled for Araba because he gave his utmost effort.

**Anecdote:** Abdullah bin al-Mu'tamir al-Qaysi said: I performed Hajj one year to the Sacred House of Allah. When I finished my Hajj, I returned to visit the grave of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. While I was sitting one night between the Grave and the Rawdah, I heard loud moaning and apparent yearning. I listened to it, and he was saying:
'Did the cooing of the Sidr doves sadden you... and stir up the anxieties of the chest in you?
Or did the memory of a beauty prevent your sleep... gifting you the whispers of remembrance?
In a night where the empty-hearted slept... and you were alone with sorrows and thoughts.
O night that grew long on a sick man... complaining of separation and lack of patience.
You surrendered one who loves to the heat of passion... burning like the burning of ember.
The moon testifies that I am infatuated... fond of the love of one resembling the moon.
I did not think I would be saddened by her... until I was afflicted and I did not know.'
He said: Then the voice stopped, and I did not know where it came from. I remained bewildered for an hour. Suddenly he returned to weeping and yearning and recited:
'Did a visitor from Rayya's phantom sadden you... while the night has black locks, dark?
And love visited your soul with its fervor... and early sleep agitated your eye.
I called Layla while the darkness was like... a sea in which a crashing wave crashes.
And the moon travels in the sky as if... a king departed and the stars are soldiers.
If the Pleiades appear, you think them... a cup with wine bubbles circling.
You see Gemini dancing in the dark... the dance of a beloved overcome by visible drunkenness.
O night, you have been long on a lover who has no... helper and supporter but the morning.
So it answered me: Die a natural death and know... that love is present humiliation.'

He said: I stood up when he began the verses, heading for the voice. He did not finish the last of them until I was with him. I saw a youth whose facial hair had not yet sprouted, and tears had cut two paths in his cheeks. I said: "Blessed be the darkness." He said: "And you, blessed be the darkness. Who is the man?" I said: "Abdullah bin al-Mu'tamir al-Qaysi." He said: "Do you have a need, O youth?" I said: "I was sitting in the Rawdah, and nothing startled me this night except your voice. May I protect you with myself, ransom you with my soul, and console you with my money. What do you suffer?" He said: "If it must be, then sit." I sat. He said: "I am Uyayna bin al-Hubab bin al-Mundhir bin al-Jamuh al-Ansari. I went early to the Mosque of Al-Ahzab and remained prostrating and bowing. Then I moved away not far. Suddenly, women swaying like sandgrouse appeared, and in their midst was a girl of marvelous beauty in her age, perfect loveliness in her time. Her light shone, and her scent wafted. She stopped by me and said: 'O Uyayna, what do you say about the union of one who seeks your union?' Then she left me and went. I heard no news of her, nor followed a trace of her. I am bewildered moving from place to place." Then he screamed a great scream and fell to the ground unconscious. He recovered after an hour, his face looking as if dyed with saffron, and recited:
'I see you with my heart from distant lands... You see me seeing you with hearts from afar.
My heart and eye are sorry for you... My soul is with you and your memory is with me.
I do not enjoy life until I see you... Even if I were in Paradise or the Garden of Eternity.'
He said: I said to him: "O brother, repent to your Lord, and ask forgiveness for your sin, for before you is the terror of the Rising and the evil of the resting place." He said: "Far from it! Far from it! I will not be consoled until the two gatherers of acacia leaves return (i.e., never)." I stayed with him until dawn broke. I said to him: "Come with us to the Mosque of Al-Ahzab, perhaps Allah will relieve your distress." He said: "I hope for that through the blessing of your countenance, God willing." We walked until we reached the Mosque of Al-Ahzab. I heard him say:
'O men, regarding Wednesday... Will it not cease causing delight for me after prohibition?
A gazelle never ceases to wrong me in it... falling to the Mosque of Al-Ahzab veiled.
Telling people that reward is his intent... while he came not seeking reward nor calculating.
If he sought reward, he would not have come at noon... smeared with crushed musk, dyed.'
We sat until we prayed Dhuhr. Suddenly the women approached, but the girl was not among them. They said: "O Uyayna, what do you think of one seeking your union while your mind is eclipsed?" He said: "What is wrong with her?" They said: "Her father took her and moved to Samawa." I asked them about the girl. They said: "She is Rayya, daughter of Al-Ghatrif al-Sulami." He raised his head to them and recited:
'My friends, Rayya has hastened her early departure... and her caravan traveled to the land of Samawa.
My friends, whatever Umm Malik decrees... upon me, no emir can transgress against me.
My friends, I have become blind from weeping... Is there with anyone else an eye I can borrow?'

He said: I said, "O Uyayna, I came to Hijaz with abundant wealth, curious gifts, fabrics, and goods, intending them for people of covering (virtue). By Allah, I will spend it before you until I give you satisfaction and above satisfaction. Come with us to the assembly of the Ansar." We stood up until we overlooked a gathering of them. I greeted, and they returned the greeting well. Then I said: "O gathering, what do you say about Uyayna and his father?" They said: "Good and son of good, from the masters of the Arabs." I said: "He has been struck by a calamity of love, and the fever of passion has settled in his heart. I want nothing from you but assistance to Samawa." They said: "Hearing and obedience." We rode, and the people rode with us until we overlooked the dwellings of Banu Sulaym in the regions of Khaffan in Samawa. We said: "Where is the house of the Master Al-Ghatrif?" They said: "Before you." We traveled, and Al-Ghatrif was informed of us. He came out rushing and met us saying: "Greeted with honor, and gifted with the best livestock." We said: "And you are greeted and gifted. We are your guests." He said: "You have landed in the best dwelling and settled in the most generous stronghold." Then he said: "O slaves, settle the people." Leather mats, cushions, and carpets were spread for us, and we settled. Then sacrifices were slaughtered and camels butchered. We said: "O master of the people, we will not taste your food until you fulfill our need and send us back with our joy." He said: "What is your need?" We said: "We propose for your noble daughter to Uyayna bin al-Hubab bin al-Mundhir, of good element and current pride." He said: "O brothers, the one you propose to, her affair is up to herself. Here I am entering to inform her." Then he rose angrily and entered upon Rayya—she was true to her name (fragrance). She said: "O father, why do I see anger apparent on you?" He said to her: "The Ansar arrived proposing for you from me." She said: "Noble masters, great heroes, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, asked forgiveness for them. Who is the proposal for among them?" He said: "For a youth known as Uyayna al-Hubab." She said: "By Allah, I have heard about this Uyayna; he fulfills what he promises, achieves if he intends, eats what he finds, and does not ask about what he lacks." He said: "I swear I will never marry you to him, for some talk of your conversation with him has reached me." She said: "That was not so. But if you have sworn, the Ansar are not to be rejected with an ugly rejection. Give them a good rejection." He said: "With what?" She said: "Be harsh with them regarding the dowry, for they will return and not agree." He said: "How excellent is what you said." Then he went out rushing and said: "The girl of the tribe has agreed, but I want a dowry like hers. Who will undertake it?" Abdullah bin al-Mu'tamir said: "I will. Say what you wish." He said: "I want one thousand mithqals of red gold." He said: "You have that." He said: "I want five thousand dirhams of Hajar mint." He said: "You have that." He said: "I want one hundred garments of striped cloaks and ink-colored cloth." He said: "You have that." He said: "I want twenty garments of embroidered silk." He said: "You have that." He said: "I want a pearl necklace." He said: "You have that." He said: "I want five stomachs of ambergris." He said: "You have that." He said: "I want twenty pods of pungent musk." He said: "You have that. Have I answered?" He said: "Yes." He said: Abdullah bin al-Mu'tamir sent a group of Ansar to Medina, and they brought all he guaranteed. Sheep and camels were slaughtered, and people gathered to eat food. He said: We stayed forty days in this state. Then he said: "Take your girl and depart accompanied." Then he carried her in a howdah and equipped her with thirty camels carrying many gifts and curiosities. He bid us farewell, and we traveled. When one stage remained between us and Medina, horsemen came out against us intending a raid; I think they were Banu Sulaym. Uyayna bin al-Hubab charged them and killed several men. He turned back towards us with a stab wound gushing blood. Then he fell to the ground. Help came to us from the inhabitants of the land, and they drove away the horses. Uyayna had passed away. We said: "O Uyayna!" The girl heard us and threw herself upon him. She began kissing him and shouting with burning grief, saying:
'I forced patience, not that I was patient, but... I distract my soul that it will join you.
If my soul were fair, it would have been to death... before you, ahead of creation, preceding.
No one after me and you is fair... to a friend, nor is a soul truthful to a soul.'
Then she gasped one gasp and died. We dug one grave for them and buried them in it. I returned to the dwellings of my people and stayed seven years. Then I returned to Hijaz and came to visit. I said: "By Allah, I will return to Uyayna's grave to visit him." I came to the grave and found a tree growing on it with red, yellow, and green ribbons. I said to the owners of the house: "What is this tree called?" They said: "The Tree of the Two Bridegrooms." I stayed at the grave a day and a night, then left. That was the last contact with it. Peace.

**Anecdote:**

Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Ali al-Madharai narrated in Egypt: I was riding with Abu al-Jaysh Khumarawayh bin Ahmad bin Tulun in Damascus. We went out hunting and took the route of the Thawra river. While we were traveling, a Bedouin met him, took the rein of his horse, and recited:
'If the spearhead and the sword edge could speak... they would tell people wonders about you.
You exhausted your wealth giving and looting it... O bane of white silver and gold.'
Abu al-Jaysh said: "O boy, give him what is in the pouch." There were five hundred dinars in it. He said: "O Emir, increase me." Abu al-Jaysh said to the slaves present: "Throw your swords and belts on him." Seventeen slaves rushed and threw their belts and swords. He said: "O Emir, transport me." He ordered a mule from the procession's mules to be given to him, and he carried that with him. We returned from the hunt. I had not yet settled in my seat when Abu al-Jaysh Khumarawayh's signature came to me: "Advance, may Allah give me enjoyment of you, with the crafting of seventeen swords and seventeen belts of good gold for the slaves in place of what they gave, so that those slaves who delayed regret what they missed of that."

**Anecdote:** Al-Fadl bin Yahya rode one day from his house in Al-Khuld intending his house at Bab al-Shamasiya. A young man from the Abna (Persian settlers) who was getting married met him, accompanied by a group of people carrying his wedding items. When he saw Al-Fadl, he dismounted and kissed his hand, though he did not know him. Al-Fadl asked him about the dowry and learned it was four thousand dirhams. He ordered four thousand dirhams for him as his wife's dowry, four thousand dirhams as the price of a house to live in, four thousand dirhams for the cost of his banquet, and four thousand dirhams to help him with the contract he made upon himself. He left.

**Anecdote:** It is said that Muhammad bin Ibrahim the Imam fell into debt. He rode to Al-Fadl bin Yahya with a box containing jewels. He said to him: "Our yields have fallen short, our Caliph has neglected our affair, and our expenses have increased. A debt has become obligatory upon us to pay, which is one million dirhams. I hated exposing my face to merchants and degrading my honor among them. You have people among them who will give you what you want, and I have a pledge that suffices for that. If you see fit to order some of them to take it and carry the money to us, do so." Al-Fadl called for the box, saw what was in it, sealed it with Muhammad bin Ibrahim's ring, and said to him: "The need succeeds if you stay with me today." He said to him: "Staying is difficult for me." He said to him: "What is difficult for you in that? If you see fit to wear some of our clothes 'I called for it', otherwise I ordered clothes brought from your house." He stayed. Al-Fadl stood up, called his agent, and ordered him to carry the money and hand it to Muhammad bin Ibrahim's servant, and hand the box with the jewels with his seal to him, and take his receipt for that. The agent did that. Muhammad stayed with him until sunset, having no news. Then he went to his house, saw the money, and the servant brought the box. He went early to Al-Fadl to thank him but found he had preceded him in riding to Al-Rashid's house. He stood waiting for him at Al-Rashid's door. He was told he had left from the other door. He followed him and found he had entered to his son. He stood waiting for him. He was told: "He left from the other door heading to his house." So he turned away from him. When he reached his house, Al-Fadl sent him another one million dirhams. He went early to him, thanked him, and prolonged it. Al-Fadl informed him that he spent a night long with grief over what he complained of, until he met Al-Rashid and informed him of his condition. He ordered him to estimate for him. He continued to negotiate with him until the situation was settled at one million dirhams. He said: "He has never given you the like of it, nor exceeded twenty thousand dinars. I thanked him and asked him to send you a check for it in his handwriting and make me the messenger, so he did." Muhammad thanked him and said: "The Commander of the Faithful told the truth; he never connected me with more than twenty thousand dinars. This was only made possible by you and at your hands. I cannot fulfill your right nor offer thanks to repay your favor, except that upon me is a vow"—and he swore confirmed oaths—"that I will not stand at anyone's door but yours, nor ask anyone else a need ever, even if I lick the soil." He used not to ride to anyone but Al-Fadl until what happened to them happened. After that, he used not to ride to anyone but Al-Rashid and return to his house. He was blamed after their days ended for leaving visiting Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi'. He said: "By Allah, if I lived a thousand years and sucked water from rocky ground, I would not stand at anyone's door after Al-Fadl bin Yahya, nor ask him a need ever until I meet Allah Almighty." This remained his state until he died.

**Anecdote:**

It is said that when Al-Rashid performed Hajj and returned, he stopped at Al-Anbar. He summoned Salih, the owner of the prayer-mat, when he turned against the Barmakids. He said to him: "Go out to Mansur bin Ziyad and tell him: Ten million dirhams have been validated against you, so bring them to me this very day. If he pays them to you complete before the sun sets this day, fine; otherwise, bring me his head. Beware of reviewing me regarding anything of his affair." Salih said: I went out to Mansur while he was in the house and informed him of the news. He said: "We belong to Allah and to Him we return. By Allah, my life is gone." Then he swore he did not know the location of three hundred thousand dirhams, let alone ten million. Salih said to him: "Start your work." He said to him: "Go with us to my house so I can make a will and settle my affairs." We went. No sooner had he entered than screaming rose from his homes and women's chambers. He made his will and came out bloodless. Salih said: "Let us go until we come to Yahya bin Khalid; perhaps Allah will bring us relief from his direction." He went with him and entered upon Yahya weeping. Yahya said to him: "What is behind you?" He told him the story. Yahya became anxious for his sake and looked down thinking. Then he called his treasurer and said to him: "How much money do you have?" He said: "Five million dirhams." He said: "Bring me its keys." He brought them. Then he sent to his son Al-Fadl: "You had informed me, may your father be your ransom, that you have two million dirhams and I wished you would buy an estate with them. I have found an estate for you whose remembrance and gratitude will remain, and whose fruit will be praised. Send the money to us." He sent it. Then he said to the messenger: "Go to Ja'far and say to him: Send me, may your father be your ransom, one million dirhams for a right incumbent upon me." He sent it to him. Salih said: "This is eight million dirhams." Then he prolonged his looking down because nothing remained with him. Then he raised his head to a servant of his and said: "Go to Dananir and tell her: Send me the necklace the Commander of the Faithful gave you." He brought it. It was a huge necklace like the thickness of an arm. He said to Salih: "I bought this for Al-Rashid for one hundred and twenty thousand dinars. The Caliph gave it to Dananir. We have calculated it against you for two million dirhams (note: text says 2000, context implies 2 million to reach 10 million). This is the complete amount. Leave and let our friend go; you have no way against him." Salih said: I took that and returned Mansur with me. When we were at the door, he recited proverbially:
'You two left me while nothing remained of me... but you feared the penetrating arrows.'
Salih said: "There is no man on the whole earth more generous than the man we left, nor have I heard of the like of him in the past, nor will there be the like of him among those remaining. And there is no man on the face of the earth with a more malicious secret or worse nature than this Nabataean, since he did not thank the one who gave him life." He said: Then I went to Al-Rashid and told him the story of the money, and withheld from him what Mansur said because I feared if he heard it he would order his killing. Al-Rashid said: "As for me, I knew that if he was saved, he would only be saved by the people of this house." He said: "Take the money and return the necklace to Dananir, for I would not give a gift and have it return to me." Salih said: I did not feel good leaving Yahya uninformed of what Mansur said. I said, when I saw him after praising his thanks and describing his deed: "You bestowed favor on an ungrateful one who met the noblest deed with the vilest speech." He said: "How is that?" I informed him of what he said and what happened. He began, by Allah, seeking excuses for him and saying: "O Abu Ali, the terrified heart may let the tongue slip with what is not in the conscience, and the man was in a terrible state." I said: "By Allah, I do not know which of your matters I marvel at more, the beginning or the end, but I know that time will never replace the like of you."

**Anecdote:**

Judge Abu al-Qasim Ali bin al-Muhsin bin Ali al-Tanukhi, author of the book 'Al-Faraj ba'd al-Shiddah' (Relief after Hardship), said in his book: Ali bin Hisham told me: I heard Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Isa speaking, saying: I heard Abdullah bin Sulayman bin Wahb saying: My father told me: I and Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin al-Khasib, along with a multitude of officials and scribes, were detained in the hands of Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik al-Zayyat at the end of his vizierate for Al-Wathiq. Al-Wathiq's illness intensified, and he was veiled from people for six days. Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad, the Chief Judge, may Allah have mercy on him, entered upon him. Al-Wathiq said to him: "O Abu Abdullah"—and he used to use his kunya—"The world and the Hereafter have gone from me. As for the world, you see death present. As for the Hereafter, what I have sent forward of ugly deeds. Do you have any remedy?" He said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful. Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik has dismissed a group of scribes and deceived you regarding them. He filled the prisons with them and did not obtain much from them. They are a large multitude behind whom are a thousand hands raised to Allah against you. Order their release so hands may be raised in supplication for you. Perhaps Allah Almighty will grant you health, for in this state you need to lessen your adversaries." He said: "Yes, what you advised. Sign on my behalf for their release." He said: "If he sees my handwriting, he will resist and persist. But let the Commander of the Faithful seize the reward, force himself, sit up, and sign for them in his own hand." Al-Wathiq did that and signed with a shaky hand to Ibn al-Zayyat for their release, and the release of everyone in the prisons without consultation or review. He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, order the Chamberlain Itakh to go with the signature to him, and not let him do anything or release them (on his own terms), and to prevent him from reaching you or writing a note or occupying himself with anything at all except after releasing them. If he meets him riding on the road, let him make him dismount and sit until he finishes your command." Al-Wathiq ordered Itakh to comply with that. He headed out and met Ibn al-Zayyat riding, intending the Caliph. He said to him: "Dismount your beast and sit on your saddle cover." He was terrified and thought the calamity had befallen him. He dismounted and sat on his saddle cover. He showed him the signature. He refused and said: "If I release these people, from where will I spend money and establish supplies?" He said: "It must be done." He said: "Ride and ask his permission." He said: "There is no way to what you mentioned." He said: "Then let me write." He said: "Nor this." He did not let him leave his place until he signed for the release of the people to the last of them.

The Chamberlain came to us while we were in prison, most despairing of relief. We had heard of the intensification of Al-Wathiq's illness, and rumors spread about the Caliphate for his son, who was a boy. We feared that if that happened, Ibn al-Zayyat would become the boy's sheikh, take over the administration, and destroy us. We had refrained from food and drink out of excessive grief. When Itakh entered the prison, we had no doubt he came only for a calamity. He said: "Good news of release," and informed us of the situation. We were released. We praised Allah Almighty, prayed for Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad and the Caliph, and left for our homes. We stayed a moment then went out and stood for Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad on his way, waiting for his return from the Caliph's house. When we saw him, we dismounted, prayed for him, and thanked him. He denied that, considered it great, and forbade us from dismounting, but we did not refrain. He stopped until we rode and walked with him. He began telling us the news while we thanked him, and he belittled what he did, saying: "This is the least of your rights, and you will know what I will do in the future." He returned to the Caliph's house in the evening. Al-Wathiq said to him: "I was blessed by your opinion, O Abu Abdullah, and found lightness from the illness. I became active and ate the weight of five dirhams of bread with a francolin breast." He said to him: "O Commander of the Faithful, those hands that were praying against you in the morning have become praying for you in the evening. A large number of your subjects pray for you because of them. However, they have returned to ruined houses and ugly conditions, without furnishings, clothes, or beasts, dead from hunger and emaciation." He said: "So what do you think?" He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, complete Allah's blessing upon you and perfect your blessing upon these people by what you do with them." He said: "What is that?" He said: "In the treasuries and stables are remnants of what was taken from them. If you order that to be looked into, so everyone for whom something remaining is found, it is returned to him, and their estates are released for them to live by, the sin will be lightened, supplication doubled, and health strengthened." He said: "Sign on my behalf for that." So he signed for it. We felt nothing until our blessings returned to us. Al-Wathiq died after three or four days. Allah brought us relief through Ibn Abi Du'ad, and this noble deed remained for him on our necks.

**Anecdote:**

Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani said: Ismail bin Yunus told me raising it to Jarir, said: Yunus al-Katib said: I went out to Sham during the caliphate of Hisham bin Abd al-Malik, accompanied by my slave girl Atika. I had taught and refined her, and I estimated in her what would make me rich. When we neared Damascus, the caravan stopped at a water pond, and I stopped aside from them. I ate some food I had and brought out a small water skin containing leftover nabidh I had, so I drank. While I was in that state, a young man of handsome face and appearance appeared on a blond horse, accompanied by two servants. He wore gilded brocade clothes. I didn't know whether his face was more beautiful, or his clothes, or his beast. He greeted me and said: "Do you accept a guest?" I stood up, held his stirrup, and realized he was from the Caliphate family. Awe and reverence for him entered me. I said: "Dismount, O my master." He dismounted and said: "Give us drink from your drink." I gave him drink. He said: "If it is easy for you to sing me a song, do so." I sang to him:
'I wonder, is this the beginning of confusion... or a time of sedition other than confusion?'
He was delighted and asked for it again. Then he said: "Tell your slave girl to sing us a song." She sang my melody to Ibn Harma's poetry:
'O Fatim, does distance console those of passion... or does my distance increase my ecstasy for you?'

He was delighted, drank, and asked for it repeated many times until I prayed the final evening prayer. He said to me: 'What brought you to us in this city?' I said: 'I wanted to sell this slave girl of mine.' He said: 'And how much did you estimate for her price?' I said: 'Whatever pays my debt and fixes my condition.' He said: 'Does thirty thousand satisfy you?' I said: 'How needy I am for Allah's bounty and increase from Him.' He said: 'Does forty thousand satisfy you?' I said: 'It would pay my debt and leave me bare and empty.' He said: 'I have taken her for fifty thousand dirhams, and you will have after that a reward, clothes, and expenses for your journey, and I will share my state with you forever as long as I live.' I said: 'I have sold her to you.' He said: 'I have accepted. Do you trust me to carry that to you tomorrow and carry her with me, or shall she stay with you?' Intoxication, awe of him, and shyness drove me to say: 'Yes, I trust you, so take her, may Allah bless her for you.' He said to one of his servants: 'Carry her on your beast and ride behind her and go with her.' He rode his horse and bid me farewell. No sooner had he disappeared from me than I realized the place of my error and mistake. I said: 'What have I done to myself and committed against it? I handed over a slave girl to a man I do not know, nor do I know what he is, nor his name or lineage, nor from which land he is. Even if I knew him, how would I reach him?' I sat thinking until morning. I prayed and sat in my place. My companions departed and entered Damascus. The sun melted me. I hesitated between staying and entering. I said: 'If I enter, I am not safe from the man's messenger coming to seek me and not finding me or knowing my location, and I would have committed a second crime against myself.' So I stayed, sent my luggage with some people from Medina, and sat in the shade of a wall there. When the day was high, one of the two servants who were with the man yesterday approached me. I do not remember being happy with anything as I was with seeing him. He said to me: 'I have been going around looking for you in your caravan since morning.' Before I asked him anything, I said: 'Who is my companion?' He said: 'The Crown Prince Al-Walid bin Yazid.' My soul calmed. Then he said: 'Stand up and ride.' He had a beast with him. I rode and entered upon him. The slave girl had been given a separate room and she was in it. He brought me into her. When she saw me, she jumped and greeted me. I said: 'What happened to you?' She said: 'He entered his house, I was settled here and checked upon for what I needed, and I am as you see in travel clothes.' I sat with her. Suddenly the servant came and said: 'Stand up.' I stood up, and he brought me into my companion of yesterday. He was sitting on his bed. He said: 'Who are you?' I said: 'Yunus al-Katib.' He said: 'Welcome to you. By Allah, I was longing for you, and I used to hear about you. How was your night?' I said: 'Good, may Allah honor the Emir.' He said: 'Did you regret what you did last night, saying "I gave my slave girl to a man I do not know"?' I said: 'O Emir, God forbid I regret, even if I gifted her to the Emir. What is the value of this slave girl?' He said: 'But I regretted taking her from you, saying: "A stranger who does not know me, and I distressed him tonight, and I was foolish in my haste to take her." Do you remember what passed between us yesterday?' I said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Did you sell me the slave girl for fifty thousand dirhams?' I said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Bring the money, O boy.' The slaves brought it carrying it and placed it before him. He said: 'Bring, O boy, a thousand dinars separately.' A bag was brought and placed. Then he said: 'Bring another five hundred dinars.' It was brought and placed as well. Then he said: 'This is the money for your slave girl, take it. And this is a thousand dinars for your good opinion of us. And this is five hundred dinars for your travel expenses and what you buy for your family. Are you satisfied?' I kissed his hand and foot and said: 'By Allah, you have filled my eye and hand.' He said: 'O boy, present to him a beast with its saddle and bridle to ride, and a mule for his luggage.' Then he said: 'If you hear that this affair (Caliphate) has passed to me, visit me. By Allah, I will fill your hands and enrich you as long as I remain.' I left and headed to my country. When the Caliphate passed to him, I went to him, and by Allah, he fulfilled his promise and increased. I was with him in the easiest condition and highest status. My conditions expanded, and I acquired estates and properties from which I live until now, and those after me. I remained with him until he was killed.

**Anecdote:**

It is said that Al-Afshin hated Abu Dulaf al-Qasim bin Isa al-Ijli and envied him for his virtue. One day he resolved to kill him and summoned him with urgency and disturbance. Abu Dulaf was a friend of the Chief Judge Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad. He sent to him: 'Save me, for my situation is such and such.' He rode quickly and summoned the witnesses present with him. When he arrived at Al-Afshin's door, the slaves said to him: 'We will ask permission for you.' He said: 'The matter is more urgent than that.' He dismounted and entered. He found Al-Afshin sitting in his place, and Abu Dulaf had been made to stand before him in the courtyard. When Al-Afshin saw the Chief Judge enter without permission, he was dumbfounded. Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad said to him: 'O Emir, I am the messenger of the Commander of the Faithful to you, ordering you not to do anything regarding Al-Qasim without his permission.' Then he turned to the witnesses and said: 'Bear witness that I have conveyed the message of the Commander of the Faithful, and that Al-Qasim is alive and healthy.' Then he left and came to Al-Mu'tasim's door quickly. He asked permission to see him and was permitted. When he entered upon him, he said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, I have told a lie on your behalf hoping for Paradise by it, and for you, pride in it.' He said: 'What is it?' He said: 'The matter was such and such.' Al-Mu'tasim laughed and said: 'You did well, may Allah do well to you.' Before long, Al-Afshin came asking permission. He was permitted. When he settled in his seat, he said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, a message came to me from you with the Chief Judge regarding Abu Dulaf, so what do you command regarding him?' He said: 'Yes, I sent to you regarding him, so beware of touching him except with good.' Thus he escaped his hand.

**Anecdote:** Judge Abu al-Qasim Ali bin al-Muhsin bin Ali al-Tanukhi narrated in the book "Al-Faraj ba'd al-Shiddah": Abu al-Faraj Ali bin al-Husayn al-Isfahani told me: Muhammad bin Zayd the Alawite, the Da'i (Caller) in Tabaristan, used to check the land tax treasury when he opened the tax collection. He would distribute the tax of the previous year among the tribes of Quraysh according to their stipends, and among the Ansar, the jurists, the Quran readers, and other classes of people, until he distributed all that remained. One year, he sat distributing the like as was his habit. When he started with Banu Abd Manaf, having finished with Banu Hashim, he called the rest of Banu Abd Manaf. A man stood up to him. He said: 'From which Banu Abd Manaf are you?' He said: 'From Banu Umayya.' He said: 'From which of them are you?' He remained silent. He said: 'Perhaps you are from the descendants of Muawiyah?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Are you from any of them?' He remained silent. He said: 'Perhaps you are from the descendants of Yazid?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Wretched is the choice you made for yourself. Do you seek a land ruled by the family of Abu Talib while you have their blood revenge regarding their master (Husayn)? You had an alternative away from them in Sham and Iraq with those who support your grandfather and love your piety. If you came out of ignorance of this, then there is no ignorance after your ignorance. And if you came mocking them, you have risked yourself.' The Alawites looked at him intensely. Muhammad shouted at them and said: 'Stop, may Allah heal you. Do you think that killing this man is an achievement or revenge for the two Hasans bin Ali? What is this man's crime? Allah Almighty has forbidden that a soul be held accountable for other than what it earned. By Allah, no one touches him but I will execute him for it. Listen to a story I will tell you to be an example for you in the future:

My father told me from his father who said: A magnificent jewel was presented to Al-Mansur in a Hajj year. He recognized it and said: "This belonged to Hisham bin Abd al-Malik. This means news of him has reached me that he is with his son Muhammad, and no one else remains of them." Then he said to Al-Rabi': "When it is tomorrow and I pray with the people in the Sacred Mosque and the people are inside, close the doors, place your trusted Shia men at them and lock them. Open only one door for the people, stand at it, and let no one exit unless you know him." When it was tomorrow, Al-Rabi' did that. Muhammad bin Hisham realized the story and knew he was the one sought and that he would be caught, so he became bewildered. Muhammad bin Zayd bin Ali bin al-Husayn bin Ali bin Abi Talib approached after that and saw him bewildered, not knowing him. He denied his state (found it strange) and said to him: "O you, I see you bewildered and looking around. Who are you? You have the complete general safety of Allah Almighty, and you are in my protection until I save you with the help of Allah Almighty." He said: "I am Muhammad bin Hisham bin Abd al-Malik. Who are you?" He said: "I am Muhammad bin Zayd bin Ali bin al-Husayn." He said: "Then I count my soul with Allah (expect death)," since he said: "No harm on you, O cousin. You are not the killer of Zayd, nor is obtaining his revenge in killing you. I am now more entitled to save you than to surrender you. However, excuse me for the dislike I will handle you with and the ugly address I will address you with, for in it is your salvation, by the will of Allah Almighty." He said: "O master, it is up to you." He threw his cloak over his head and face, grabbed his collar, and began dragging him. When Al-Rabi's eye fell on him, he slapped him several times and brought him to Al-Rabi', saying: "O Abu al-Fadl, this malicious man is a camel driver from Kufa. He rented me his camel going and returning, and he fled from me at this time and rented it to some Khurasani commanders. I have witnesses against him for that. Assign two guards to me to go with him and me to the judge and prevent the Khurasani from interfering if he interferes with us." Al-Rabi' assigned two guards to him and said: "Go with him." After he distanced from the mosque, he said to him: "O malicious one, will you give me my right?" He said: "Yes, O son of the Messenger of Allah." He said to the guards: "Leave in the safety of Allah Almighty." They left. When they were far away, he released him. Muhammad bin Hisham kissed his head and said: "By my father and mother you are, by Allah. Allah knows best where He places His messages." Then he brought out a jewel of great value and gave it to him saying: "Honor me, O master, by accepting this from me." He said: "Go with your goods, O cousin. We, the People of the House, do not accept reward for kindness. I have left the blood of Zayd for you, which is greater in value than your goods. Go guided and hide your person from this man until he leaves, for he is serious in seeking you." He left and hid. He said: Then Muhammad bin Zayd, the Da'i in Tabaristan, ordered for the Umayyad the like of what he ordered for the rest of Banu Abd Manaf. He assigned a group of his clients to him and ordered them to take him out to Rayy and bring him a letter of his safety. The Umayyad stood up, kissed his head, went with them until he reached his safe place, and they brought him the letter of his safety.

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Qasim bin al-Mu'ammar al-Zuhri said: I was walking with Yahya bin Khalid, and he was between his two sons Al-Fadl and Ja'far. Abu al-Yanbaghi was standing on the road and called out to me: "O Zuhri!" I looked up at him. He said:
"I accompanied the Barmakids for ten consecutive years... and my house is rented and my bread is purchased."
He said: Yahya heard him, turned to Al-Fadl and Ja'far, and said: "Fie on this deed! Is Abu al-Yanbaghi someone to be audited (treated stingily)?" When it was the next day, Abu al-Yanbaghi came to me. I said: "Woe to you, what is this you exposed yourself to?" He said: "Be silent. No sooner had I returned to my house than a bag of money came to me from Al-Fadl and a bag from Ja'far, and each of them gifted me a house and assigned me sufficient provisions from his kitchen."

**Anecdote:** It is said that Muhammad bin al-Jahm offered a house of his for sale for fifty thousand dirhams. When the witnesses arrived to witness, he said: "How much will you buy from me the neighborhood of Sa'id bin al-As?" The house was in the neighborhood of Sa'id bin al-As. They said: "Is neighborhood sold?" He said: "How can the neighborhood of one who gives if you ask him, initiates if you are silent, and does good if you treat him badly not be sold?" It is said: This reached Sa'id, so he sent him one hundred thousand dirhams and said to him: "Keep your house."

**Anecdote:**

Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi narrated: Ja'far bin Yahya secluded himself one day in his house, and his boon companions attended, and I was among them. He perfumed himself with Khaluq (perfume), wore silk, and did the same to us. He ordered the chamberlain to guard the door (letting no one in) except Abd al-Malik bin Najran, his scribe. The chamberlain heard "Abd al-Malik" without "Ibn Najran". A part of the day passed. Abd al-Malik bin Salih bin Ali al-Hashimi, the uncle of Al-Rashid, learned of Ja'far's stay in his house and rode to him. When he reached Ja'far's house, the chamberlain sent word that Abd al-Malik had arrived. He said: "Let him in," thinking it was his scribe. Abd al-Malik bin Salih entered trailing his black robes and Rusafi cap, with his majesty, piety, noble status, and etiquette. When Ja'far saw him, his face turned black; the matter was grave and alarmed him. Abd al-Malik did not drink nabidh (wine), and that was the reason for Al-Rashid's anger at him, because he requested his companionship but he refused. Abd al-Malik understood what he saw from Ja'far. He called his servant, handed him his black robes, turban, and sword, and approached until he stood at the door of the sitting room we were in. He greeted and said: "Include us in your affair; do to us what you did to yourselves." A servant approached him, dressed him in silk, and perfumed him with Khaluq. Then he sat and called for food and ate. He called for nabidh; a rotl (large cup) was brought, and he drank it. He said to Ja'far: "By Allah, I have never drunk it before today, so let it be lightened for me." A large pitcher was called for and placed before him. Every time he did something like that, Ja'far's anxiety cleared. When he wanted to leave, Ja'far said to him: "May Allah make me your ransom. You have been gracious and helpful. Ask your need, for my ability cannot encompass rewarding what came from you today. There is some ill feeling in the Commander of the Faithful's heart against me; ask him to be pleased with me." He said: "The Commander of the Faithful is pleased with you and what he had against you is gone." He said: "I have a debt of four million dirhams to be paid for me." He said: "It is yours from me ready, but I will make it from the Commander of the Faithful's wealth, for it is nobler for you and more beloved to you." He said: "And Ibrahim my son, I wish to strengthen his back by marriage from the descendants of the Caliphate." He said: "The Commander of the Faithful has married him to his daughter Al-Aliyah." He said: "And I wish for a banner to flutter over his head (governorship)." He said: "The Commander of the Faithful has appointed him governor of Egypt." Abd al-Malik left, and we were amazed at Ja'far's boldness in fulfilling needs without permission, and we said: "Perhaps his requests for needs will be granted, but what about the marriage? Will he or others be granted authority for that?" When it was tomorrow, we went early and stood at Al-Rashid's door. Ja'far entered. Before long, Abu Yusuf the Judge, Muhammad bin al-Hasan, and Ibrahim bin Abd al-Malik bin Salih were called. Then Ibrahim came out with banners before him, having been given robes of honor, married to Al-Aliyah daughter of Al-Rashid, and his decree for Egypt written. The bags of money were carried to Abd al-Malik's house. Ja'far came out and signaled us to follow him to his house. When we returned to Ja'far's house, he said: "Your hearts were attached to the beginning of Abd al-Malik's affair, so you loved to know its end: When I entered upon the Commander of the Faithful and stood before him, I began telling him the story from beginning to end. He kept saying: 'Good, by Allah! Good, by Allah!' until I completed his news and what I granted him. He kept saying in all of that: 'You did well, you did well.' So it was as you saw." Ibrahim bin al-Mahdi said: By Allah, I do not know which of them is more generous and amazing in deed: what Abd al-Malik bin Salih initiated of assistance and drinking wine etc., while he was a man of seriousness, chastity, dignity, and reputation; or Ja'far's boldness with Al-Rashid in what he undertook; or Al-Rashid's execution of everything Ja'far judged upon him?

**Anecdote:**

It is said that an incident occurred between Ghassan bin Abbad and Ali bin Isa al-Qummi that led to enmity. Ali bin Isa was the guarantor of the land tax and estates in his region. A balance of forty thousand dinars remained against him. Al-Mamun insisted on his paying it and demanded it until he said to Ali bin Salih, his chamberlain: "Demand from Ali bin Isa what remains against him, and give him three days respite. If he brings the money before they pass, fine; otherwise, flog him with whips until he pays it or perishes." Ali bin Isa left Al-Mamun's house despairing of himself, as he knew no way to free himself of the money. His scribe said to him: "If you turned to Ghassan bin Abbad and informed him of your news, I would hope he might help you in your affair." He said to him: "Despite what is between me and him?" He said: "Yes, for the man is noble and generous." The condition he was in drove him to accept that from his scribe. They entered upon Ghassan. He stood up for him, received him with acceptance, and fulfilled his due respect. Ali bin Isa said to him: "The situation between me and you does not mandate what you showed of your generosity." He said: "That is regarding a matter of competition and conflict. As for what is between me and you (personally), leave it as is. Your entering my house has a sanctity that obligates attaining what you hoped for with me. Mention if you have a need." His scribe told him the story. He said: "I hope Allah Almighty suffices him," and added nothing to this. Ali bin Isa stood up and left him despairing of his good, regretting his approach to Ghassan given what was between them. He said to his scribe when he left: "You have benefited me nothing by approaching Ghassan and forcing me to enter upon him except hastening gloating and humiliation. Perhaps he will find through this a way to vent his anger on me."

Ali bin Isa had not reached his house before Ghassan's scribe arrived with mules carrying the money. He conveyed his greetings and said: "The money is present, so proceed to hand it over and go early to the Commander of the Faithful's house tomorrow." Ali bin Isa went early and found Ghassan had preceded him there and entered upon Al-Mamun standing between the rows. He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, Ali bin Isa has sanctity, service, and precedent, and the Commander of the Faithful has kindness towards him that is the guardian of his care and preservation. He has suffered loss and calamity in his guarantee as people know. The Commander of the Faithful has exceeded in harshness against him in demand and threatened him with whipping for money that would destroy his soul, which made his mind fly, took his wit, and stunned him from moving to free himself and devising means for what he owes, with lack of ability for that. If the Commander of the Faithful sees fit to treat me according to the good habits of his generosity to me, and accept my intercession for him regarding some of what he owes, it is a favor he renews for me guarding his previous kindness, and doubling the obligation of thanks for it." He continued to speak gently to him with this and the like until he deducted half of what he owed and limited it to twenty thousand dinars. Ghassan said: "On condition that the Commander of the Faithful renews the guarantee for him and dismisses him with robes that strengthen his soul, sharpen his resolve, and let him know the place of satisfaction with him." Al-Mamun agreed to that. He said: "Then permit me, O Commander of the Faithful, to carry the inkwell to your presence so you may sign what you saw of this favor, so the honor of carrying it remains with me and my descendants after me." He said: "Do so." He carried the inkwell and brought it. Al-Mamun signed for him what he requested. Ali bin Isa went out with the robes on him and the signature in his hand. When he arrived at his house, he carried twenty thousand dinars of the money and returned it to Ghassan, thanking him for his beautiful deed with him. He said to his scribe: "Did I intercede with the Commander of the Faithful to return the money to me? I only asked for its deduction so it would be saved for him to benefit from, and nothing of it returns to me ever." He returned the money to him. That was the cause of reconciliation between them. Ali bin Isa recognized the value of what Ghassan did for him and continued to serve him until the end of his life.

**Anecdote:**

Judge Abu al-Qasim Ali bin al-Muhsin al-Tanukhi narrated in his book: Al-Suli told me: Muhammad bin al-Qasim bin Khallad told me: Some officials reported to Al-Mu'tasim—who had taken over the land tax and war (administration) previously handled by Khalid bin Yazid bin Mazyad—that Khalid bin Yazid had cut off funds and withheld some of them. Al-Mu'tasim became angry and swore to take Khalid's wealth, punish him, and exile him. Khalid sought refuge with Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad, the Judge. He used a stratagem until he brought him and his accuser together, and no proof was established against Khalid. The Judge Ibn Abi Du'ad informed Al-Mu'tasim of that and interceded with him for Khalid, but he did not accept his intercession. He summoned Khalid and brought instruments of punishment for him. Before that, he had seized his wealth and estates and dismissed him from work.

Ibn Abi Du'ad attended the assembly and sat lower than his usual seat. Al-Mu'tasim said to him: "Rise to your place." He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, I deserve only below this seat." He said: "How so?" He said: "People claim that my position is not that of one who intercedes for a man accused of what is not in him, against whom nothing was proven, yet his intercession was not accepted." He said: "Then rise to your place." He said: "Accepted or not accepted?" He said: "Accepted. I have gifted Khalid to you and am pleased with him." He said: "The people do not know this." He said: "I have returned to him all his estates and wealth that were seized." He ordered his shackles removed and gave him robes of honor. That was done. He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, he and his companions deserve six months' salary. If the Commander of the Faithful sees fit to make it a gift to him." He said: "Let it be carried with him." Khalid went out wearing the robes with the money before him, while people were expecting his punishment. When they saw him in that state, they were happy. A man shouted to him: "We praise Allah for your safety, O Master of the Arabs." He said: "Hush! Rather, the Master of the Arabs, by Allah, is Ibn Abi Du'ad who collared me with this noble deed that will never be removed from my neck."

**Anecdote:** It is said that a youth of wealth whose time had turned against him had a beautiful slave girl proficient in singing. They were straitened and their condition became severe in lack of food. He said to her: "You see what bad state we have come to. By Allah, my death with you is easier for me than what I mention to you. It pains me to see you in a state other than what pleases me for you. The end of our matter is that death befalls one of us, and the other kills himself over him. If you see fit that I sell you to someone who will treat you well, washing away what you are in, and I get relief through what price might come to me, and perhaps you end up with someone through whom you can reach benefit for me." She said: "By Allah, my death with you in this state is preferred by me over moving to another, even if he were a king. But do what seems best to you." He said: He went out and offered her for sale. A friend of his with opinion advised him to take her to Umar bin Ubaydullah bin Ma'mar, who was then Emir over Iraq. He said: He carried her to him. When she was presented to him, he admired her and said to her master: "How much was her purchase price upon you?" He said: "One hundred thousand dirhams, and I have spent one hundred thousand dinars on her." He said: "As for what you spent on her, it is not counted for you because you spent it on your pleasures. As for her price, we have ordered one hundred thousand dirhams for you, ten baskets of clothes, ten heads of horses, and ten slaves. Are you satisfied?" He said: "Yes, may Allah please the Emir." He ordered the money brought and ordered his head maid to take the girl into the harem. She held the side of the curtain, wept, and said:
'Congratulations to you on the money you have gained... and nothing remains in my hand but regret.
I say to my soul while it is in its distresses... Reduce or increase, for the beloved has departed.
If you have no trick for the matter... and find no escape from patience, then be patient.'
Her master answered her saying:
'Were it not for time sitting me down away from you... nothing would separate us but death, so excuse me.
I go with a painful concern for your separation... whispering to a heart of little patience.
Peace be upon you, no visit between us... and no union unless Ibn Ma'mar wills.'
Ibn Ma'mar said: "I have willed. Take her, may Allah bless you in her and in what came from me to you." He took her, the money, horses, slaves, and clothes, and returned enriched, and his condition improved.

**Anecdote:**

Musa bin al-Husayn bin Ziyad narrated: Muhammad bin Aws loved Ghars, a large-eyed slave girl belonging to Mutahhar al-Saghani. She would not go out for a day and night except for five dinars. When he summoned her and she went out to him, he would keep her for a month or more. She withheld herself from him at some times, using winter clothing as an excuse. He wrote her a note asking her to save him (visit him) and promising to speak to the Vizier about his salary to fulfill her desire. He wrote another note to the Vizier Ubaydullah bin Yahya bin Khaqan and went out early in the dark to meet the Vizier with the note. He mistook the two notes and carried in his sleeve the note he wrote to Ayna (Ghars). When he saw the Vizier, he went to dismount, but he prevented him from that. He greeted him and handed him the note. Ubaydullah called for a candle, brought it close, read the note on the way, summoned Ahmad bin al-Abbas, whispered to him, and said: "Take this note and act according to what is in it." He revealed something to him secretly. He went to Ayna, bought the slave girl from her, bought a maid for her for one hundred dinars, and clothes for three hundred dinars, and went with all of them to Muhammad bin Aws's house. The Vizier had kept him until mealtime, so he had lunch with him and sat for drink. Ahmad bin al-Abbas said: When I obtained what he ordered me for him, I came to him. The Vizier said to me: "What did you do regarding what I ordered you?" I said: "I have accomplished it." He said to Muhammad bin Aws: "Go to your house, for the boy will meet you." When he entered his house, the slave girl met him cheerfully, coming towards him without shyness or reservation, whereas during his love for her she used to prevent him from approaching her. He proceeded according to his habit of refraining from her and leaving approaching her, based on what he knew of her. She said: "Do not hold back, for I have no refusal from you today; I am now the property of your hands." He said: "What is the story?" She informed him of what happened with Ahmad bin al-Abbas by the order of the Vizier. He marveled at that and did not know its reason. Then he thought of the note and stood to look at the other note. He found the one he wrote to the Vizier remaining. He knew he had mistaken the two notes. He rode to the Vizier's house and asked permission to apologize to him. He sent word to him: "You are a groom tonight. Go and stay in your wedding for seven days, then come to us after that." He returned to his house and stayed with the girl for days. Ubaydullah sent him a signature for his salary, having increased it and raised his rank. He went to him after that and thanked him for what he did for him.

**Anecdote:** It is said Aws bin Haritha al-Murri was a chief, noble, high-minded, and he has many stories. One of the best of them is what Abu al-Faraj al-Shalahi narrated from Ibn Hatim from Al-Asma'i, said: Abu Amr bin al-Ala' told us from his sheikhs: Al-Nu'man bin al-Mundhir sat on his day of bliss in a gilded robe collared with pearls, the like of which had not been seen. He permitted the Arabs to enter, and among them was Aws bin Haritha bin Lam al-Tai. He said: The faces of the Arabs began to marvel at the beauty of the robe and talk to each other, while Aws bin Haritha looked down. Al-Nu'man said: "I do not see anyone who entered upon me but admired this robe despite its diminished value to me, except you, O Aws." He said:

"O King, may your god make you happy and your time aid you. This is admired only if it is in the hand of its merchant. But if it is on the King, and his radiant face shines in it, eyes are restricted to him rather than it." He weighed his mind and appreciated what he said. Khalid bin Bishr hinted to Al-Nu'man requesting it. Al-Nu'man said: "I will think tonight and give it tomorrow to the one I see as the Master of the Arabs." They left, every hopeful one concerned. When it was tomorrow, the faces of the Arabs adorned themselves and went early to Al-Nu'man's door, dragging their trails and looking at their sides, each thinking he was the owner of the robe. Aws bin Haritha delayed. His companions said to him: "Why don't you go early to the King's house? Perhaps you will be the Master among the Arabs by taking it, and your pride will be complete." Aws said: "Glory be to Allah! If I am the master of my people, I am not the master of the classes of Arabs in my own view. The King promised to give the robe to the Master of the Arabs, and I do not know him to be me or anyone else, but the King is worthier of his opinion. If I attend and do not take it, I leave diminished and worried. If I am the sought one, he will send for me." They stopped urging him, considering his opinion weak. He said: Al-Nu'man looked at the faces of the group and missed Aws, so what he thought occurred to him. He summoned one of his entourage and sent him as if finding out his news from his slaves. What he said was repeated to him. He repeated it to Al-Nu'man. He said: "Go to him and tell him the King finds you slow for your delay, and summon him." He attended that day in the clothes he attended in yesterday. The faces of the Arabs were happy with his delay, sensing that the King would have given him the robe had he attended. When he took his seat in Al-Nu'man's presence, he raised him and brought him forward, then extended his hand to him and said: "I see you did not change your clothes for your day, so wear this robe to beautify yourself with among those of your companions who beautified themselves." He wore it. The faces of the Arabs envied him and said: "Nothing lowers his status except satire, and there is no one for him like Jarwal." They spoke to Jarwal (Al-Hutay'ah), but he said: "I have no way against him. How can I satirize a man of noble lineage whose house is not denied, generous whose giving does not cease, virtuous whose opinion is not impugned, brave whose fire is not warmed by (approached), beneficent from whom I see nothing in my house except his favors?" Then he said:
'How can there be satire when a good deed... from the family of Lam never ceases coming to me unseen?'
He said: Bishr bin Abi Khazim, one of Banu Asad bin Khuzaima, heard of that. He desired the payment and resolved to satirize him. They gave him three hundred camels or thereabouts, so he satirized him. Aws targeted his camels which he had hastened to take—he had none before them—drove them away, and secured them with himself. He sought him to kill him. He fled from his hand and began seeking a mighty one to seek refuge with. He did not approach anyone but he said to him: "I protect you from all people except Aws bin Haritha, for I do not like his enmity." While he was wandering, and Aws had set spies on him, one of those watching him saw him, seized him, and carried him to Aws. When he was in his hand, he consulted his mother Sa'da about him—he had satirized her excessively—and said: "What killing do you like me to kill him with?" She said: "No, by Allah, O Aws! If you kill him, his words will be established like engraving on rock. Nothing erases his satire of you except his praise of you. So favor him, release him, and return to him what was taken from him." He knew the correct action was what she advised. He brought him and said to him: "What do you think I will do to you?" He said: "Kill me." He said: "You deserve that from me, but Sa'da pitied you and advised me regarding you a matter I am doing." Then he ordered him released. He untied him, returned his camels to him, added to them from his own, clothed him, gave him a mount, and said to him: "Return to your family guided." He said: Bishr raised his hand and gaze to the sky and said: "O Allah, bear witness against Bishr that he will praise no one but Aws bin Haritha as long as You extend life for him." He said: So he praised him with several poems established in his Diwan. From his sayings:
'To Aws bin Haritha bin Lam... so he fulfills my need among those he fulfilled.
When a banner is raised for glory... they set it up for him to reach its end.
No one trod the pebbles like Ibn Sa'da... nor wore sandals nor was shod with them.'

**Anecdote:**

Abdullah bin Mansur mentioned: I was one day in the assembly of Al-Fadl bin Yahya. The chamberlain came to him and said: 'There is a man at the door who has persisted in asking permission, claiming he has a favor (connection) by which he relates.' He said: 'Let him in.' A man of handsome face but shabby appearance entered. He greeted well. He gestured for him to sit, so he sat. When he knew he was at ease and could speak, he said to him: 'What is your need?' He said to him: 'My shabby appearance and weak capability have expressed it.' He said: 'Yes. So what is it you relate by?' He said: 'A birth close to your birth, a neighborhood close to your neighborhood, and a name derived from your name.' Al-Fadl said: 'As for the neighborhood, it is possible as you said, and the name may match the name, but what is your knowledge of the birth?' He said: 'My mother informed me that when she gave birth to me, she was told that a boy was born tonight to Yahya bin Khalid and named Al-Fadl, so she named me Fudayl in honor of your name to attach me to it "and diminished it due to the shortness of my rank compared to yours".' Al-Fadl smiled and said: 'How many years have passed over you?' He said: 'Thirty-five years.' He said: 'You spoke the truth; this is the amount I count for myself.' He said: 'What did your mother do?' He said: 'She died, may Allah have mercy on her.' He said: 'What prevented you from joining us in the past?' He said: 'I was in commonness and youthfulness that held me back from meeting kings.' He said: 'O boy, give him a thousand for every year that passed of his years, and give him of our clothes and mounts what befits him.' He did not leave the house until he was surrounded by his brothers and the elite of his family.

**Anecdote:** It is narrated that a man came to Ubaydullah bin al-Abbas while he was in the courtyard of his house. He stood before him and said: 'O Ibn al-Abbas, I have a favor (hand) with you, and I have needed it.' He raised his eyes to him and lowered them but did not recognize him. Then he said to him: 'What is your favor with us, for I do not verify you?' He said: 'I saw you standing at Zamzam, and your boy drawing water for you from it. The sun was melting you, so I shaded you with the edge of my garment until you drank.' He said: 'Yes, I indeed remember that, and it wavers between my mind and thought.' Then he said to his steward: 'What do you have?' He said: 'Two hundred dinars and ten thousand dirhams.' He said: 'Give it all to him, and I do not see it fulfilling the right of his favor to us.' The man said to him: 'By Allah, if Ismail had no son but you, there would be sufficiency in you, so how is it when the Master of the first and last, Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, begot him, then "interceded" him with you and your father.'

**Anecdote:** It is said that a brother of Amr bin Dawsara fell in love with his cousin (daughter of his uncle) intensely. Her father hated that and refused. He complained about him to Khalid bin Abdullah al-Qasri, who was then over Iraq, mentioning that he was a bad neighbor and asked to imprison him. He imprisoned him. Then Khalid was asked about him, so he released him. The youth stayed for a period refraining from his cousin. Then what was in him increased and excessive longing overcame him. He forced himself to climb the wall of his uncle's house to see his daughter. He was detected and caught. He was brought to Khalid accused of theft, and a group was brought testifying they found him in the upper part of his house at night. Khalid asked him, and the youth confessed to theft to ward off suspicion from his cousin. Khalid resolved to cut off his hand. His brother wrote a note and gave it to someone to deliver to Khalid. In it was:
'O Khalid, you have been trodden in darkness, by Allah... The oppressed lover among us does not steal.
He confessed to what he did not commit, except that... he saw cutting (the hand) better than the scandal of a lover.
Were it not for fear of his hand being cut... you would have found the youth silent regarding the matter.
If goals appear in the race for highness... Ibn Abdullah is the first preceding.'
Khalid sent a trusted client of his to uncover his state and find the truth of the matter. He brought him the truth of the boy's affair. He summoned his uncle and obliged him to marry the girl to her cousin. He refused and said: 'He is not a match for her.' He said: 'Yes, by Allah, he is above a match since he sacrificed his hand for her. If you do not marry him, I will marry her to him while you dislike it.' Her father married her, and Khalid paid the dowry on his behalf from his own money and ordered him to stick to him to benefit him. He stuck to him. The youth was called 'The Lover' until he died.

**Anecdote:**

And from Waqid bin Muhammad al-Waqidi who said: My father told us that he submitted a note to Al-Mamun mentioning abundance of debt and lack of patience with it. Al-Mamun wrote on the back of his note: "You are a man in whom two qualities are combined: generosity and modesty. As for generosity, it released what was in your hand. As for modesty, it prevents you from informing us of what you are in. I have ordered one hundred thousand dirhams for you. If you are correct (in your assessment/need), increase in extending your hand. If I am not correct, your crime is against yourself, for you narrated to me—and I was in charge of judiciary for Al-Rashid—from Muhammad bin Ishaq from Al-Zuhri from Anas that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Al-Zubayr bin al-Awwam: 'O Zubayr, know that the provisions of servants are opposite the Throne. Allah Almighty sends to every servant according to his spending. Whoever increases, it is increased for him, and whoever decreases, it is decreased for him, and you know best.'" Al-Waqidi said: "By Allah, Al-Mamun's reminding me of the hadith was dearer to me than the reward 'and the hundred thousand'."

**Anecdote:** It is authenticated that Abu Talib bin Kathir was a Shiite. A man said to him: "By the right of Ali bin Abi Talib, gift me your palm trees in such-and-such place." He said: "I have done so. And by his right, I will give you what adjoins them." That was multiples of what the man asked.

**Anecdote:** Some narrators mentioned that Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan gifted Ubaydullah bin al-Abbas, while he was with him in Sham, gifts of Nowruz: many robes, musk, and vessels of gold and silver, and sent them with his chamberlain. When he placed them before him, he looked at the chamberlain looking at them. He said: "Is there anything of it in your soul (do you desire it)?" He said: "Yes, by Allah, there is in my soul of it what was in Jacob's soul of Joseph." Ubaydullah laughed and said: "Take them, they are yours." He said: "May I be your ransom, I fear Muawiyah will hear of it and be angry with me." He said: "Seal them with your ring and give them to the treasurer. When it is time for our departure, he will carry them to you at night." The chamberlain said: "By Allah, this trick in generosity is greater than the generosity itself. I wish I would not die until I see you in his place"—meaning Muawiyah. Ubaydullah thought it was a ploy from him, so he said: "Leave this talk, for we are a people who fulfill what we promised and do not break what we confirmed."

**Anecdote:** It is said Abu Mazyad was one of the generous. A poet praised him. He said to the poet: "By Allah, I have nothing to give you, but take me to the judge and claim ten thousand dirhams against me. I will acknowledge it to you, then imprison me, for my family will not leave me imprisoned." He did that. He did not spend the evening until ten thousand dirhams were paid to him, and Abu Mazyad was released from prison.

**Anecdote:** Ma'n bin Zaida was governor of the two Iraqs in Basra. A poet attended his door and stayed for a period wanting to enter upon him but could not. One day he said to some of his servants: "If the Emir enters the garden, inform me." When he entered, he informed him. The poet wrote a verse of poetry on a piece of wood and threw it in the water entering Ma'n's garden. Ma'n was sitting at the head of the water. When he saw the wood, he took it and read it. Written on it was:
'O generosity of Ma'n, whisper to Ma'n about my need... For I have no way to Ma'n other than you.'
He said: "Who is the owner of this?" The man was called. He said: "How did you say?" He recited the verse. He ordered ten bags of money for him. He took them. The Emir put the wood under his rug. When it was the second day, he took it out from under the rug, read what was on it, called the man, and gave him another one hundred thousand dirhams. Likewise on the third day. When the man took it from him, he thought and feared he might take back what he gave him. He left "and went on his way." When it was the fourth day, he read what was on it, called the man, sought him but he wasn't found. Ma'n said: "It was incumbent upon me to give him until not a dirham or dinar remained in the treasury."

**Anecdote:** It is said Harun al-Rashid sent five hundred dinars to Malik bin Anas, may Allah be pleased with him. This reached Al-Layth bin Sa'd, so he sent him a thousand dinars. Al-Rashid became angry and said: "I give him five hundred dinars and you give him a thousand dinars, while you are one of my subjects?" He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, I have from my yield a thousand dinars every day, so I was ashamed to give the likes of him less than the income of a day." It is told that Zakat never became obligatory upon him (because he spent it all), even though his income was a thousand dinars every day.

**Anecdote:** Sa'id bin Khalid entered upon Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik. He was a generous man; if he found nothing, he would write checks against himself for those who asked him until his stipend came out. When Sulayman looked at him, he quoted this verse:
'I heard with the morning a caller... O who helps the helpful youth against time?'
Then he said: "Your need?" He said: "My debt." He said: "How much is it?" He said: "Thirty thousand dinars." He said: "You have your debt and the like of it."

**Anecdote:**

It is said Qays bin Sa'd bin Ubada fell ill and found his brothers slow (in visiting). It was said they were ashamed because of the debt you have against them. He said: "May Allah disgrace wealth that prevents brothers from visiting." Then he ordered a crier who called out: "Whoever Qays has a right against, he is absolved of it." His doorstep was broken "in the evening" due to the large number of those visiting him.

**Anecdote:** Sheikh Abu Sa'id "al-Kharkushi al-Naysaburi said: I heard" Muhammad bin Muhammad al-Hafiz say: I heard "Al-Shafi'i say: There was a man in Egypt known for collecting for the poor. A child was born to one of them. He said: I came to him and said: 'A child was born to me and I have nothing.' He stood up with me and entered upon a group, but nothing opened up for him. He came to the grave of a man he knew, sat by it, and said: 'May Allah have mercy on you, you used to do and make. I went around today seeking a group for something for a newborn, but nothing worked out for me.' Then he stood up, took out a dinar, broke it in half, gave me half and said: 'This is a debt upon you until Allah opens something for you.' I took it and left and fixed what I could with it. That night, "the Muhtasib" saw "that person, the owner of the grave, in his dream saying: 'I heard all you said, and we do not have permission to answer. But go to my house and tell my children to dig the place of the stove and take out a skin containing five hundred dinars and carry it to this man.' He said: When it was tomorrow, he went to the dead man's house and told the story. They said to him: 'Sit.' They dug the place, took out the dinars, brought them, and placed them before him. He said: 'This is your money, and my dream has no ruling.' They said: 'He is generous dead, and we will not be generous alive? By Allah, we will not hold back anything of it.' When they insisted on him, he carried the dinars to the man with the newborn and mentioned the story to him. He said: He took a dinar from it, broke it in half, gave him the half he had lent him, carried the other half, and said: 'This suffices me; give the rest in charity to the poor.' Abu Sa'id said: I do not know which of these is more generous: the dead man, the asker, or his children?

**Anecdote:** It is narrated that when Al-Shafi'i fell ill with his fatal illness, he said: 'Order So-and-so to wash me.' When he died, the news of his death reached him, so he attended and said: 'Bring me his notebook.' It was brought, and he looked into it. There were seventy thousand dirhams against Al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him. He wrote them against himself "and paid them for him," and said: 'This is my washing of him,' meaning he only intended this.

**Anecdote:** Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: I continue to love Hammad bin Abi Sulayman for something that reached me about him. "That is," he was one day riding a donkey of his. He moved it, and his button broke. He passed by a tailor and wanted to get down to him to fix his button. The tailor said: 'By Allah, do not get down.' He stood up to him and fixed his button while he was riding. He brought out a purse containing ten dinars to him, handed it to the tailor, and apologized to him for its smallness.

**Anecdote:** From Al-Rabi' bin Sulayman who said: A man held Al-Shafi'i's stirrup, may Allah be pleased with him. He said: 'O Rabi', give him four dinars and apologize to him for me.'

**Anecdote:** It is narrated that Talha al-Talhat went out on a summer day. Heat struck him and he became thirsty. He looked at a house with a nice courtyard and extended shade. He turned to it, sat down, then asked for water. A clean maid came out to him with a clean vessel containing cold water. He drank and said: 'O maid, how clean you are and how clean what is with you!' She said: 'May I be your ransom, if my family knew of your location, they would have trusted (been generous) in what they sent to you.' He marveled at her intelligence and her family's generosity. He asked about the owner of the house. It was said he was hiding due to a debt he incurred, and the house was pawned to his creditor for a thousand dinars. He sent to the man and brought him out, sent to the creditor and paid him his money, returned the house to the man, gave him a generous gift, and said: 'Whenever misery touches you from your time, seek us, for I am your helper against your time.'

**Anecdote:** Al-Rabi' said: I heard Al-Humaydi say: Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, arrived from Sana'a to Mecca with ten thousand dinars. He pitched his tent in a place outside Mecca and scattered the dinars on a cloth. Then he turned to everyone who entered upon him, grabbed a handful, and gave him until he prayed Dhuhr, and shook the cloth with nothing on it.

**Anecdote:** Muhammad bin Abbad al-Muhallabi said: My father entered upon Al-Mamun, so he gifted him one hundred thousand dirhams. When he stood up from his presence, he gave it in charity. Al-Mamun was informed of that. When he returned to him, he blamed him for that. He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, withholding generosity is from bad opinion of the Worshipped.' So he gifted him another two hundred thousand.

**Anecdote:**

Hudhayfah al-Adawi said: I set out on the Day of Yarmouk looking for a cousin of mine, with some water. I said: 'If he has a breath of life, I will give him drink and wipe his face with it.' I found him and said: 'Shall I give you water?' He signaled yes. When he was about to drink, a man said: 'Ah, Ah.' My cousin signaled to me to go to him. "He said: I came to him," and it was Hisham bin al-Aas. I said: 'Shall I give you drink?' Another heard me and said: 'Ah, Ah.' Hisham signaled to me to go to him. I came to him, and he was dead. I returned to Hisham, and he was dead. Then I returned to my cousin, and he was dead.

**Anecdote:** A man entered upon Salim bin Qutayba al-Bahili to speak to him about a need. He placed the blade of his sword on Salim's finger and leaned on it. He began speaking to him about his need while making him bleed, and Salim was patient. When the man finished his need and left, Salim called for a handkerchief, wiped the blood from his finger, and washed it. It was said to him: 'Why didn't you move your leg, may Allah amend you, or order him to lift his sword from it?' He said: 'I feared I would cut him off from his need.'

**Anecdote:** Khuzaim bin Abi Yahya al-Muzani mentioned that Al-Rashid invited him one day to eat with him. While eating, he raised his head to a man speaking to him in Persian. He said: I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, if you want to speak secretly to him, I understand Persian.' He ordered me to step aside so he could proceed with what he wanted. Al-Rashid admired his noble manners and truthfulness, spoke to that man secretly as he wished, and ordered a splendid gift for Khuzaim.

**Anecdote:** It was mentioned that a beggar came to Ubaydullah bin al-Abbas while he did not know him and said to him: 'Give me charity, for I was informed that Ubaydullah bin al-Abbas gave a beggar a thousand dirhams and apologized to him.'
