He said: 'Where am I compared to Ubaydullah?' He said: 'Where are you compared to him in lineage or in generosity?' He said: 'In both.' He said: 'As for lineage in a man, it is his manliness and deed. If you wish, you do, "and if you do," you are of noble lineage.' He gave him two thousand dirhams and apologized to him for the tightness of his funds. The beggar said to him: 'If you are not Ubaydullah bin al-Abbas, you are better than him; and if you are him, you are better today than you were yesterday.' He gave him another thousand. The beggar said to him: 'This is the vibration of a noble person of lineage. By Allah, you have pecked the grain of my heart and emptied it into your heart. You only erred by interception of the secret from my ribs (knowing who I am/my secret).'

**Anecdote:** "Among the witty tales mentioned about keeping secrets and concealing them is what" Abu Sufyan al-Himyari and Salih bin Sulayman "narrated": Al-Walid bin Yazid wanted to perform Hajj. A group of the notables of Sham conspired to attack him. They came to Khalid bin Abdullah al-Qasri to be with them, but he refused them. They said: 'Then keep our secret.' He said: 'As for this, yes.' Khalid al-Qasri walked to Khalid bin al-Walid bin Yazid and said to him: 'Tell the Commander of the Faithful to forego Hajj this year.' He said: 'Why?' He said: 'I fear for him.' Khalid informed his father, so he summoned him. He said: 'Is what Khalid says about you true, O Khalid?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Repeat it to me.' He repeated his saying. He said: 'Who are these whom you fear for me? Name them.' He said: 'I will not do it.' He said: 'You surely will say.' He said: 'I will not say.' He said: 'Then I will send you to Yusuf bin Umar.' He said: 'Even if you do.' He sent him to Yusuf, who tortured him until he died, and he did not name the group nor anyone of them.

**Anecdote:** It is said when Umar bin Abd al-Aziz, may Allah be pleased with him, became Caliph, he wrote to the governor of Basra to bring Iyas bin Muawiyah al-Muzani and Al-Qasim bin Rabi'a al-Jawshani, and to look at the more effective of them in judgment and appoint him. When he read the letter, he summoned them and read it to them. Iyas said to him: 'Ask the two jurists of the city, Al-Hasan and Ibn Sirin, about me and him.' Al-Qasim was a friend of theirs. He realized what Iyas intended. He said: 'O Emir, do not ask anyone about me and him. Listen from me and him.' He said: 'Speak.' He said: 'By Allah, besides Whom there is no god'—and he swore a complete oath gathering the meanings of swearing—'Indeed Iyas bin Muawiyah is more fit for judgment than me and more effective in it. If I am truthful to you, appoint him "by my oath"; and if I am a liar to you, it is not lawful for you to appoint to judge between Muslims one who challenges Allah with such an oath lying.' Iyas said: 'Do not listen to him, O Emir, for you brought him to the brink of Hell, so he ransomed himself from falling into it with an oath he swore lying; he will expiate for it and ask Allah's forgiveness for it and be saved "from what was".' The Emir said to him: 'Did you not understand it yourself, O Iyas?' And he appointed him to judge between people.

**Anecdote:**

When death approached Umar bin Abd al-Aziz, may Allah be pleased with him, he called his sons—they were eleven. Maslama bin Abd al-Malik was with him. He left nothing but some ten dinars. He ordered that he be shrouded and a place be bought for his burial for five dinars, and the rest be divided among his heirs. Each son received half and a quarter of a dinar. He said: 'O my sons, I have no wealth to bequeath regarding it, but I have left you while no one has a claim against you. The eye of none of you falls on anyone except he sees a right for him upon you.' Maslama said to him: 'Is there better than that, O Commander of the Faithful?' He said: 'What is it?' He said: 'Here is three hundred thousand dinars; distribute it among them, or if you wish, give it in charity.' He said: 'Is there better than that, O Maslama?' He said: 'What is it?' He said: 'Return it to the one you took it from, for it is not rightfully yours.' Maslama said to him: 'May Allah have mercy on you, O Commander of the Faithful, alive and dead. You have softened hard hearts of ours, reminded them even if they were forgetful, and left for us a mention among the righteous.' It is said that no one of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz's children was ever seen except rich. One of them was seen equipping one hundred horsemen on one hundred horses in the path of Allah from his pure wealth. When death approached Hisham bin Abd al-Malik, he left eleven sons just as Umar left. He made a bequest, and each one of the sons received one million dinars. It is said that no one of them was ever seen except poor. One of them was seen stoking the furnace of a bathhouse for filling his belly.

**Anecdote:** Ahmad bin Musa narrated: Al-Rabi' said: I have not seen a man more composed or steadfast of heart than a man reported to the Commander of the Faithful Al-Mansur as having deposits and wealth belonging to Banu Umayya. He ordered me to bring him. I brought him and entered with him. Al-Mansur said to him: 'News of deposits and wealth "you have" for Banu Umayya has been raised to us, so bring them out to us.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, are you an heir to Banu Umayya?' He said: 'No.' He said: 'Are you an executor for them regarding their wealth and properties?' He said: 'No.' He said: 'Then what is your questioning about what is in my hand of that?' Al-Mansur looked down for an hour, then raised his head to him and said: 'Banu Umayya wronged the Muslims regarding it. I am the agent of the Muslims regarding their right, and I want to take what they wronged the Muslims in and put it in their treasury.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, you need to establish just proof that what is in my hand for Banu Umayya is from what they betrayed and wronged in, excluding other things, for Banu Umayya had wealth other than the Muslims' wealth.' He said: Al-Mansur looked down for an hour, then raised his head to him and said: 'He spoke the truth, O Rabi', nothing is obligated on the Sheikh.' Then he said: 'Do you have a need?' He said: 'My need, O Commander of the Faithful, is that you send my letter by post to my family so they are reassured of my safety, for my departure alarmed them. And I have another need, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'What is it?' He said: 'Bring together me and the one who slandered me to you. By Allah, Banu Umayya have no wealth or deposit in my hand. But when I stood before you and you asked me what you asked, I knew nothing would save me from you except this saying, due to your fame for justice. So I said: That is closer to salvation and safety.' He said: 'O Rabi', bring him and the one who slandered him together.' I brought them together. He recognized him and said: 'This is my slave; he stole three thousand dinars of wealth from me and fled from me "and feared my seeking him, so he slandered me to the Commander of the Faithful".' He said: Al-Mansur was harsh on the slave "and frightened him," so he confessed he was his slave, that he took the money he mentioned and fled, and that he slandered him falsely out of fear of falling into his hand. Al-Mansur said to the Sheikh: 'We ask you to forgive him.' He said: 'I have forgiven him and his crime, freed him, and gifted him the three thousand he took and another three thousand.' Al-Mansur said to him: 'There is no increase upon what you have done.' He said: 'Rather, this is the right of your speech, O Commander of the Faithful,' and left. Al-Mansur used to marvel at him whenever he mentioned him and say: 'I have never seen the like of that Sheikh, O Rabi'.'

**Anecdote:** It is said a man stayed at Ma'n's door for a period not reaching him. When his stay prolonged, he wrote a note to him containing:
'Not all good is in your hand, O Ma'n... In the earth are causes and in it are ways.
The daughters of life (days/nights) will come with what you do... when the bags are searched for the return.'
He appointed someone to deliver it to him and traveled. When it reached him and he read it, he ordered his return and said: 'By Allah, he shall search for much good.' He ordered his bag to be filled with dirhams.

**Anecdote:** An Arab said: I went out in some black nights and saw a girl like an idol. I seduced her for herself. She said: 'O you, do you not have a deterrent of reason if you have no deterrent of religion?' Her words shamed me. I said: 'I was only joking.' She said:
'And beware, beware of joking, for it... makes the child and the vile man covet you.
It removes the water of the face (dignity) after its modesty... and bequeaths humiliation to its owner after honor.'

**Anecdote:**

**Anecdote:** It is narrated that a man from the Ansar came to Abdullah bin al-Abbas and said to him: 'O cousin of the Messenger of Allah, a boy was born to me tonight, and I named him with your name seeking blessing by it, and his mother died.' Abdullah said: 'May Allah bless you in the gift (child) and increase your patience in the calamity.' Then he called his agent and said: 'Go immediately and buy a maid for the newborn to nurse him and give him two hundred dinars for the expense of raising him.' Then he said to the Ansari: 'Return to us after days, for you came to us while life is miserable and money is scarce.' The Ansari said: 'May I be your ransom, if you had preceded Hatim by one day, the Arabs would never have mentioned him. But he preceded you, so you became a follower. I testify that your pardon is more than his generosity, and the drizzle of your nobility is more than his downpour.'

**Anecdote:** He said: Two men left Medina wanting Abdullah bin Amir bin Kurayz to visit him. One was a descendant of Jabir bin Abdullah al-Ansari, and the other from Thaqif. Abdullah was the governor of Iraq for Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him. They traveled until they were in the region of Basra. The Ansari said to the Thaqafi: 'Do you agree with an idea I had?' He said: 'Present it.' He said: 'We make our mounts kneel, perform ablution, and pray two rak'ahs praising Allah Almighty in them for what He decreed of our travel.' He said: 'Yes, this is an opinion not to be rejected.' He said: So they did. Then the Ansari turned to the Thaqafi and said to him: 'O brother of Thaqif, what is your opinion?' He said: 'What place for opinion is this? I have finished my travel, exhausted my body, and tired my mount, and there is no hope but Ibn Amir. Do you have an opinion other than this?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'What is it?' He said: 'When I prayed, I thought and felt shy from my Lord that He sees me seeking sustenance from other than Him.' Then he said: 'O Allah, Provider of Ibn Amir, provide for me from Your bounty.' Then he turned back to Medina. The Thaqafi entered Basra and stayed at Ibn Amir's door for days. When he was permitted, he entered upon him. He had been written to with their news. When he saw him, he welcomed him and said: 'Was I not informed that Ibn Jabir left with you?' He told him what happened with them. Ibn Amir wept and said: 'By Allah, he did not say it out of arrogance or ungratefulness, but he saw the flow of sustenance and the exit of blessing, so he knew Allah is the One who did that, so he asked Him of His bounty.' Then he ordered four thousand dirhams, clothes, and curiosities for the Thaqafi, and doubled that for the Ansari. The Thaqafi left saying:
'Umama, the striving of the greedy does not increase... a wick, nor does the incapacity of the weak harm.
We left together from our birthplaces... trusting in the generosity of Ibn Amir.
When we made the she-camels kneel at his door... The Yathribi Ibn Jabir held back from me.
He said: The gift of a Capable One will suffice me... over what He wills today for creation, Omnipotent.
For He who gave Iraq to Ibn Amir... is my Lord whom I hope for plugging my poverty.
When he saw me, he said: Ibn Jabir?... and yearned as the stallion of camels yearns.
So Abdullah doubled, when his person was absent... for the luck of a sorrowful one, gaping with greed.'

**Anecdote:** He said: Some Kharijites rebelled against Al-Rashid. He sent an army against him and captured him. When he entered upon him, he said: 'What do you want me to do with you?' He said: 'What you want Allah to do with you when you stand before Him.' Al-Rashid looked down for a long time, then raised his head and ordered his release. When he left, some of those present said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, he kills your men, exhausts your money, and you release him with one word? Consider this matter, for it emboldens evil people against you.' He ordered him brought back. When he stood before him, he knew he had been slandered. He said: 'Commander of the Faithful, do not obey them regarding me. If Allah obeyed them regarding you, He would not have made you Caliph for a single moment.' He ordered his release and said: 'No one is to review me regarding his affair.'

**Anecdote:** It is said Ma'n bin Zaida was brought prisoners. He offered them to the sword. One of them said: 'We are your prisoners, O Emir, and we need some food.' He ordered that for them. Leather mats were spread, and food was brought. He said to his companions: 'Eat thoroughly.' Ma'n was looking at them and marveling at them. When they finished eating, he stood up and said: 'O Emir, we were your prisoners before, and we are now your guests. Look what you do with your guests.' He pardoned them and let them go. Some of those present said to him: 'We do not know, O Emir, which of your two days is more noble: the day of your victory or the day of your pardon!'

**Anecdote:** Ruh bin Muqatil said: When Buran bint al-Hasan bin Sahl was wedded to Al-Mamun, his favorite Arib wrote to him saying:
'May you be blessed, the eyes of death missed you... by the wedding of Buran with time, the egg of a chamber.
Her star does not cease... running with the star of the trusted one (Mamun) of mankind.
Until the dominion settled in her lap... blessed in that form a lap.
O my master, do not forget my covenant... I ask nothing but what you know.'
Buran read the note and said: 'I know what you want.' Then she said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, grant permission for her to be wedded to you, for that, by Allah, is her reward for her poetry.' He said: 'That is up to you.' She did so, and she was wedded with her. Al-Mamun was pleased with the harmony that gathered for him between his wife and his favorite.

**Anecdote:** Sa'id bin Muslim al-Bahili said: An Arab from Bahila came to Al-Rashid. He wore a jubba of ink-colored cloth and a Yemeni cloak which he tied around his waist then folded over his shoulder, and a turban he wrapped around his cheeks, letting a tail hang behind him. He sat before Al-Rashid. Sa'id said to him: "O Arab, speak on the nobility of the Commander of the Faithful." He launched into his poetry. Al-Rashid said to him: "O Arab, I hear you doing well, and remember you as understanding. Say two verses about these two"—meaning his sons Muhammad Al-Amin and Abdullah Al-Mamun, who were around him. He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, the awe of the Caliphate, the dazzling of the rank, and the shying away of rhymes from improvisation have taken me up the rugged hill and removed me from the easy level ground. Return me so their shy ones become familiar to me and my awe calms down." He said: "I have done so, and made your excuse a substitute for your examination." He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, you relieved the choke and released the field for the race." Then he began saying:
'You built with Abdullah and then Muhammad... the peaks of the dome of Islam, so its wood turned green.
They are its two ropes, may Allah bless them... and you, O Commander of the Faithful, are its pillar.'
Al-Rashid said to him: "And you, O Arab, may Allah bless you. Ask, and let not your request be less than your performance." He said: "One hundred she-camels, O Commander of the Faithful." He ordered one hundred she-camels and seven robes for him.

**Anecdote:** They said: Umara bin Hamza entered upon Al-Mansur and sat in his assembly. A man stood up and said: "Oppressed, O Commander of the Faithful." He said: "Who wronged you?" He said: "Umara seized my estate." Al-Mansur said: "Stand up, O Umara, and sit with your adversary." He said: "He is not an adversary to me, O Commander of the Faithful." He said: "How is that?" He said: "If the estate is his, I do not dispute him over it; and if it is mine, it is his. I will not stand from a seat the Commander of the Faithful honored me with and raised me to, and sit in a lower one because of an estate!"

**Anecdote:** It is said that when the matter (rule) fell apart for Marwan al-Ja'di and he was certain of the loss of his kingdom and the victory of Banu Hashim over it, he said to Abd al-Hamid bin Yahya, his scribe: "I need you to be with my enemy and show them betrayal of me. Their admiration for your literary skill and their need for you will invite them to have a good opinion of you. If you can benefit me in my life, and not be unable to preserve my sanctity after my death." Abd al-Hamid said: "What you ordered me is the more beneficial of the two matters for you and the uglier for me. I have nothing but loyalty until Allah opens for you or I am killed with you." Then he said:
'I keep loyalty secret then show betrayal... Who will provide me with an excuse whose appearance encompasses people?'

**Anecdote:** Umar bin Shabba narrated, said: Muti' bin Iyas visited Yazid bin Jarir bin Abdullah al-Qasri and praised him with his poem which begins:
'Were you denied the early morning from the family of Layla... and did not meet Layla to cure the slimness?
You were throughout your time in the past... a visitor to Layla and Layla's neighbors.'
Until he says in his praise in it:
'My daughter says when she sees my travel... and I brought near for departure white camels and saddles:
To whom do I see you—may my soul be your ransom against deaths—... enduring this destiny?
I said: To the stallion who... frees the captive and enriches the poor.
The brother of Arabs, most resembling in generosity... and carrying burdens his father Jarir.
When beggars find the little much... he finds the much little for those seeking gifts.
When good becomes difficult among beggars... it is ready and easy with him.
He is not one to prevent a person of need... nor forsake one who comes seeking refuge.
With my soul I ransom you, O Abu Khalid... when enemies raid the throats.'

When news of his arrival reached Yazid, he summoned him at night, and no one knew of his presence. Then he said to him: 'I have known your news, and I am hastening your reward this very hour. When you attend tomorrow, I will address you with harshness, provide you with travel expenses, and dismiss you so that news of me does not reach Abu Ja'far al-Mansur and destroy me.' He ordered two hundred dinars for him and dismissed him. When morning came, he came to him and asked permission to recite. He said to him: 'O you, you have aimed your hope at a wrong target. What am I that poets should seek me? You have done wrong to me because I cannot fulfill your desire, and I am not safe from your anger and blame.' He said to him: 'Listen to what I say, for I accept your available means and extend your excuse.' He listened to him as if coerced. When he finished, he said to his slave: 'O boy, how much remains of your expenses?' He said: 'Three hundred dirhams.' He said: 'Give him one hundred dirhams for his travel expenses, and one hundred dirhams to return to his family, and keep one hundred dirhams for your expenses.' The boy did that. Muti' left him thankful, and Abu Ja'far did not know their news.

**Anecdote:** Al-Asma'i said: I intended one day a man I used to visit for his generosity. I found a doorman at his door who prevented me from entering. Then he said: 'By Allah, O Asma'i, nothing stopped me at his door to prevent the likes of you from entering except the thinness of his condition and the shortness of his hand.' I wrote a note saying:
'If the generous one has a veil... then what is the virtue of the generous over the mean?'
Then I said to him: 'Deliver this note of mine to him.' He did. The note returned with writing on its back:
'If the generous one has little money... he covers with the veil from the creditor.'
He sent with the note a purse containing five hundred dinars. I said: 'By Allah, I will gift the Commander of the Faithful this news, for nothing like it has passed me.' I came to him. When he saw me, he said: 'From where, O Asma'i?' I said: 'From the most generous of the living, excluding the Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'And who is he?' I said: 'A man whose knowledge and wealth matched.' Then I handed him the note and the purse "and recounted the news to him. When he saw the purse, his face changed color." He said: 'This is the seal of my treasury. I must have the man to whom I gave it.' I said: 'By Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, I am ashamed to frighten him with your messengers.' He said to some of his intimates: 'Go with Al-Asma'i. If the man sees you, say to him: Answer the Commander of the Faithful without disturbance or showing severity.' He said: When the man attended before the Commander of the Faithful, he said: 'Are you not the one who stood in our procession yesterday and complained to us of the thinness of your condition and that time had knelt upon you with its weight? We gave you this purse to improve your condition, then Al-Asma'i intended you with one verse of poetry and you gave it to him.' He said: 'By Allah, I did not lie in what I complained to the Commander of the Faithful regarding the thinness of condition and difficulty of time, but I was ashamed before Allah to return one intending me except as the Commander of the Faithful returned me.' The Commander of the Faithful said: 'To Allah you belong! The Arabs have not given birth to one more generous than you.' Then he ordered a thousand dinars for him. Al-Asma'i said: 'I said: Join me (include me), O Commander of the Faithful.' He smiled and ordered a thousand dinars to be completed for me and returned the man to be among his boon companions.

**Anecdote:**

Salih bin Ali al-Adkham, one of the prominent scribes, narrated: My unemployment lasted long, and need reached its peak with me. I went early one day to Ahmad bin Abi Khalid the Vizier to inform him of my disordered affairs and ask him to mend my disarray. He came out of his door with candles before him intending Al-Mamun's house. When he looked at me, he disapproved of my earliness and frowned in my face and said: 'Is there anyone in the world who comes this early to distract us from our affairs?' I said: 'The wonder is not from you, may Allah amend you, in how you met me; rather the wonder is from me, as I stayed up my night and kept all my family awake waiting for the morning to come to you regarding fixing my affairs after the choice fell on you for what I hope from you. But upon me and upon me'—and he swore by the oaths of allegiance—'if I stand at a door for you or ask you a need until you come to me apologizing for how you met me.' I left distressed, thinking about it, regretting the oath that escaped me, despairing of relief due to the unlikelihood of the Vizier coming to me and apologizing. Blaming myself, while I was like that, a servant entered and said: 'The Vizier Ahmad bin Abi Khalid has taken our street.' Then another entered and said: 'He entered our alley.' A third entered and said: 'He is near our door.' Another entered and said: 'He has entered our house.' I went out meeting him. When he settled in the assembly, he said to me: 'The Commander of the Faithful had ordered me to come early to him for some important matters. I entered upon him, and sleeplessness and grief over what escaped me towards you had affected me so much that he denied my state. I told him the story. He said: "You have mistreated the man, and you must apologize to him." I said: "Do I go to him empty-handed?" He said: "So what do you want?" I said: "Pay his debt." He said: "How much is it?" I said: "Three hundred thousand dirhams." He ordered me to sign for it for you. I said: "O Commander of the Faithful, if he pays his debt, what does he return to?" He said: "Sign for him another three hundred thousand to fix his condition." I said: "And a governorship to be honored by?" He said: "He has [that] or others like it." I said: "And aid to help him with his travel?" He ordered to sign for you one hundred thousand dirhams. All these signatures are yours for all that.' He scattered them from his sleeve and left.

**Anecdote:** It is said Al-Mahdi vowed the blood of a man from Kufa who was striving to corrupt his state, and put a reward of one hundred thousand dirhams for anyone who indicated him or brought him. The man stayed in hiding for a time, then appeared in the City of Peace (Baghdad). While he was walking in some of its districts, a man from Kufa saw him, recognized him, grabbed his clothes, and said: 'This is the quest of the Commander of the Faithful.' While the man was in that state, he heard hoofbeats behind him. He turned, and it was Ma'n bin Zaida. He said: 'O Abu al-Walid, protect me, may Allah protect you.' He stopped and said to the man clinging to him: 'What is your affair?' He said: 'The quest of the Commander of the Faithful whose blood he vowed and gave one hundred thousand dirhams to whoever leads to him.' He said: 'O boy, get off your beast and put the man on it.' The clinger shouted: 'O people! Is a barrier put between me and the quest of the Commander of the Faithful?' Ma'n said to him: 'Go and tell him he is with me.' The man went to Al-Mahdi's door, informed the chamberlain, entered Al-Mahdi, and informed him. He ordered Ma'n to be brought. Messengers came to him. He called his family and clients and said: 'No evil shall reach this man while an eye among you blinks.' Then he marched to Al-Mahdi, entered and greeted. He did not return his greeting. He said: 'O Ma'n, do you protect against me?' He said: 'Yes, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'And yes too?' His anger intensified. He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, I killed in your obedience in Yemen in one day fifteen thousand, in addition to many days. My trial and good service have preceded. Did you not see me worthy that one man who sought my protection be gifted to me?' Al-Mahdi looked down for a long time, then raised his head, his anger cleared. He said: 'We have protected whom you protected, O Ma'n.' Ma'n said: 'If the Commander of the Faithful sees fit to reward him, he would have revived him and enriched him.' He said: 'We have ordered fifty thousand dirhams for him.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, the rewards of Caliphs are according to the crimes of the subjects. The man's sin is great, so make the reward generous.' He said: 'We have ordered one hundred thousand dirhams for him.' He said: 'Then hasten it for him, O Commander of the Faithful, for the best good is the hastened one.' He ordered it hastened for him. Ma'n left with the money to the man and said to him: 'Take your reward and join your family, and beware of opposing the Caliphs of Allah Almighty.'

**Anecdote:** Abu Abdullah al-Nadim said: I have seen kings in their compartments and gatherings, and I have not seen anyone more abundant in literature than Al-Wathiq. He came out to us one day saying: 'By my life, he exposed his honor who exposed it to the saying of Al-Khuza'i:
My friend, what do I hope for from the tomorrow of a man... who turned away from me today while he is capable?
And indeed a man who was stingy to me with speech... to block with it a need of a man is indeed stingy.'

Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad sprang to him as if released from a hobble, asking for a man from Yamama. He elaborated in intercession and went on at length, taking every path in speech. Al-Wathiq said to him: 'O Abu Abdullah, you have increased regarding what is neither much nor good.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, he is my friend.
And the easiest a friend gives his friend... of the easy available is to speak.'
Al-Wathiq said: 'What is the worth of this Yamami to be your friend? It is enough for him to be one of your servants.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, he became famous for seeking intercession through me with you, and placed me in view and hearing of rejection or aid. If I do not stand for him in this position, I would be then as the Commander of the Faithful said:
My friend, what do I hope for from the tomorrow of a man... who turned away from me today while he is capable?
And indeed a man who was stingy to me with speech... to block with it a need of a man is indeed stingy.'
Al-Wathiq said to Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik al-Zayyat: 'By Allah, O Muhammad, hasten Abu Abdullah's need so he is safe from the shame of procrastination as he was safe from the shame of rejection.'

**Anecdote:** It is said a man asked Hatim al-Tai: 'O Hatim, has anyone overcome you in generosity?' He said: 'Yes, an orphan boy from Tayy. I stopped at his courtyard. He had ten heads of sheep. He took one head, slaughtered it, prepared its meat, and presented it to me. Among what he presented was the brain. I ate some of it and found it good. I said: "Good, by Allah." He went out from my presence and began slaughtering head after head, presenting the brain to me while I did not know. When I went out to leave, I saw huge blood around his house, and behold, he had slaughtered all the sheep. I said to him: "Why did you do that?" He said: "Glory be to Allah! You find something I own good, and I be stingy with it to you? That would be an ugly disgrace on the Arabs."' It was said: 'O Hatim, what did you compensate him with?' He said: 'Three hundred red she-camels and five hundred heads of sheep.' It was said: 'Then you are more generous than him.' He said: 'Nay, he is more generous, because he gave all he owned, while I gave a little from much.'

**Anecdote:** Abu al-Yaqzan narrated from Juwayriba who said: Nusayb came to Abdullah bin Ja'far. He gave him mounts, gifts, and clothes. A sayer said to him: 'O Ibn Ja'far, you gave this black slave these gifts?' He said: 'By Allah, if this one is black, his praise is white. His poetry shakes me. He deserved by what he said more than what he received. What is that? Only mounts that wear out, clothes that fray, and dirhams that perish, while his praise remains and his eulogy is narrated.'

**Anecdote:** Ziyad al-A'jam came to Al-Muhallab bin Abi Sufra in Khurasan and stayed with his son Habib. One evening they sat for a drink. In the house was a tree with a dove on it cooing. Ziyad al-A'jam said:
'Sing, you are in my protection and covenant... and the covenant of my father, not to be harmed.
Fix your house and do not fear... for hungry small chicks.
For whenever you sing a song... you remind me of my loved ones and remind me of my home.
If they kill you, I will seek my revenge... by killing them because you are in my protection.'
Habib took an arrow, shot it, hit it, and it died. Ziyad said to him: 'You killed my neighbor. Between me and you is the Emir Al-Muhallab.' He went to Al-Muhallab and informed him. He said: 'O Habib, pay Abu Umama a thousand dinars.' Habib said: 'May Allah honor the Emir, I was joking.' He said: 'Is there joking with this? Abu Umama's neighbor is my neighbor.' Habib paid him a thousand dinars. Ziyad al-A'jam said:
'To Allah belongs the eye of one who saw a judgment like... a judgment decreed and executed by Emir Al-Muhallab.
He decreed a thousand dinars for a neighbor I protected... from the birds, brooding over eggs, croaking.
Habib bin Al-Muhallab shot it a shot... and pierced it with the arrow while the sun was setting.
So he obliged him the blood-money of the killed with a rebuke... and Habib said: I was only playing.'
Ziyad said:
'Let not his neighbor be frightened... for the neighbor of my neighbor is like my neighbor and closer.'
When Al-Muhallab heard it, he rewarded him with a good prize and dismissed him honored. This poetry reached Al-Hajjaj. He said: 'The Arabs did not err when they made Al-Muhallab their sheikh.'

**Anecdote:**

Among the witty stories of Judge Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad is what is told that Al-Mu'tasim was at Al-Jawsaq with his boon companions. He had decided on a morning drink and ordered each of them to cook a pot. He saw Salama, the slave of Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad. He said: "This is Ibn Abi Du'ad's slave, come to find our news. Any moment he will come and say: 'So-and-so the Hashimite, So-and-so the Qurashi, So-and-so the Ansari, So-and-so the Arab,' and interrupt us with his needs from what we resolved upon. I call you to witness that I will not fulfill a need for him today." No sooner had he spoken than Itakh entered asking permission for Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad. He said to his sitters: "What do you think?" They said: "Do not permit him, O Commander of the Faithful." He said: "Evil is this opinion! By Allah, a fever of a year is easier on me than that." He permitted him. He entered. No sooner did he greet, sit, and speak, than Al-Mu'tasim's face brightened, and his limbs laughed to him. Then he said: "O Abu Abdullah, each of these has cooked a pot, and we have made you the judge of the best of them." He said: "Let them be brought so I eat and judge with knowledge." Al-Mu'tasim ordered them brought. The pots were presented before him. Judge Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad stepped forward and began eating from the beginning of every pot, a full eating. Al-Mu'tasim said to him: "This is injustice." He said: "How so?" He said: "I see you have indulged in this color (dish), and you will judge for its owner." He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, knowledge of food mixtures is not attained by a morsel or two. I must give each its due in tasting, then judgment occurs after that." Al-Mu'tasim smiled and said: "Your way then." He ate from all of them as he mentioned. Then he said: "As for this one, its owner did well by showing its pepper and reducing its cumin. As for this, its owner excelled by increasing its vinegar and reducing its pepper so its acidity is desired. As for this, its cook mastered it by reducing its water and increasing its syrup." He proceeded to describe them one by one until he covered all of them with descriptions that pleased their owners. Al-Mu'tasim ordered the table brought. He ate with the people with the cleanest and best eating. Sometimes he told them stories of the eaters in early Islam like Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan, Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik, Ubaydullah bin Ziyad, and Al-Hajjaj, and sometimes he told them of the eaters of his time like Maysara al-Tarras, Hatim al-Kayyal, and Ishaq al-Hamami.

When the tables were lifted, Al-Mu'tasim said to him: "Do you have a need, O Abu Abdullah?" He said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful." He said: "Mention it, for our companions want to occupy themselves for the rest of their day." He said: "A man from your family, O Commander of the Faithful, whom time has trampled, changing his condition and roughening his living." He said: "Who is he?" He said: "Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik al-Nawfali." He said: "Estimate what fixes him." He said: "Fifty thousand dirhams." He said: "I have ordered it for him." He said: "And another need." He said: "What is it?" He said: "Harun's estates to be assigned to him." He said: "I have done it." He said: By Allah, he did not leave until he asked for thirteen needs, none of which Al-Mu'tasim rejected. Then he stood up speaking and said: "O Commander of the Faithful, may Allah grant you long life. By your life, the land of your subjects becomes fertile, their living softens, their wealth grows. May you continue to enjoy safety, protected by honor, with the accidents of time and others repelled from you." Then he left. Al-Mu'tasim said: "This, by Allah, is the one with whom one adorns himself and rejoices in his proximity. Did you not see how he entered? How he ate? How he described the pots? How he was expansive in conversation? How our eating was pleasant with him? By Allah, no one turns this one away from a need except one of mean origin and malicious branch. By Allah, if he asked me in this assembly of mine for the value of ten million dirhams, I would not have turned him away from it, for I know it earns me beauty and praise in the world, and reward and recompense in the Hereafter."

**Anecdote:** Al-Asma'i said: A war occurred in the desert and connected to Basra. The matter escalated until people walked for peace between the two tribes. They gathered in the Great Mosque. He said: I was sent, while I was "then" a boy, to Al-Qa'qa' bin al-Dirar al-Darimi. I asked permission to see him, and he permitted me. I entered and found him in his cloak mixing seeds. I informed him of the people's gathering. He waited until he ate the seeds, then washed the dish and shouted: "O girl, give us lunch." She brought him dates and oil. He said: He invited me to eat with him, so I ate. When he finished his need for eating, he jumped to some clay thrown in the house and washed his hand with it. Then he asked for water and drank it, then wiped the surplus on his face. Then he said: "Praise be to Allah. Euphrates water, Basra dates, and Levant oil. When will gratitude for this blessing be performed?" Then he took his robe and wore it over that cloak. Al-Asma'i said: I shrank from him, finding his attire ugly. When he entered the mosque, he prayed two rak'ahs. Then he walked to the people. No waistband remained tied out of reverence for him. Then he sat and bore all the blood money between the tribes from his own wealth. He rose, being the master of all by his virtue.

**Anecdote:**

It was said to Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan: In Al-Hira there is a man from Jurhum who has age, years, eloquence, and intellect. A long period of his time has passed, and he has seen wonders in his age. Muawiyah said: "Bring him to me." When he attended, he said to him: "Who is the man?" He said: "Ubayd bin Shariya." He said: "Then from whom?" He said: "From a people who have no remnant." He said: "How much of your life has passed?" He said: "Two hundred and twenty years." He said: "Have the years grieved you?" He said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful, and death has knocked on me with its doubt." He said: "What have you seen in your years and the length of your life?" He said: "I saw a day followed by a day following it, and I saw people passing and not returning. They gather for what perishes from them and do not take lesson from those who passed before them. Time took them every way. Were it not that the newborn is born, the earth would have gone with those on it; and were it not that the living dies, the earth would have been too narrow for those in it." Muawiyah said to him: "Do you have knowledge?" He said: "Yes, ask me." He said: "Which wealth did you see as most beneficial and quickest in good to its owner?" He said: "A murmuring spring in soft land; it sustains and is not sustained." He said: "Then what?" He said: "A mare, with a mare in her belly, followed by a mare." He said: "Where do you stand regarding the reddish camels and the blond Awsiya?" He said: "Those, O Commander of the Faithful, are for other than you." He said: "For whom?" He said: "For him who manages them with his hand and does not entrust them to another." He said: "Where do you stand regarding gold and silver?" He said: "Two stones clashing; if you turn to them they run out, and if you leave them they do not increase." Muawiyah said to him: "Tell me the most amazing thing you saw in your life." He said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful. I was in a tribe of the Arabs, and a dead man of theirs named Jabala bin al-Huwayrith had died. I walked in his funeral and joined his group. When he was lowered into his grave and the women wailed after him, a tear overtook me for him which I could not hold back, and I quoted verses I had heard." "Muawiyah said: Say, O brother of Jurhum. So he recited:
'O heart, you are deceived regarding Asma'... Remember, and will reminding benefit you today?
You revealed the love you hide from no one... until galloping horses ran with you.
You want a matter, and you do not know if its haste... is better for your soul or what has delay in it.
Seek provision from Allah from what is in His treasuries... For while there is hardship, eases turn around.
While a man is in the tribes envied... suddenly he becomes in the dust covered by winds.
The stranger weeps for him not knowing him... and his relative in the tribe is happy.
As if he was nothing but a reminder... and time, wherever it turns, is calamities.'
While I was repeating these verses and two eyes were pouring heavily, unable to hold back their tears, a man beside me from Udhrah said: 'O Abu Abdullah, do you know the speaker of this poetry?' I said: 'No, by Allah.' He said: 'This dead man "whom we buried" and you are the stranger weeping for him "while you do not know him nor know he is the speaker of this poetry", and his relative whom he mentioned as happy is that one.' He pointed to a man in the group and said: 'By Allah, he cannot hide the happiness he is in due to his loss.'" Muawiyah said to him: "O brother of Jurhum, ask what you wish." He said: "Can you return what passed of my life? And push away the term when it comes?" He said: "That is not up to me. Ask something else." He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, the world is not yours to return my youth, nor the Hereafter to honor my return. As for wealth, I took 'from it' in my prime what sufficed me." He said: "You must ask me." He said: "Since you refuse, order for me two loaves; I eat lunch with one and dinner with the other. And fear Allah and know that you are leaving what you are in and coming to what you sent forth." Muawiyah ordered many loads of wheat and other things for him, but he returned them. He said: "If you give all Muslims the like of what you gave me, I will take it; otherwise, I have no need for that." He bid him farewell and left.

**Anecdote:**

A witty thing written and appreciated to mention is what the messenger of the King of Khazars narrated while with Al-Fadl bin Sahl about the sister of their king, named Khatun. He said: A year struck us whose flame raged upon us with the heat of calamities and varieties of afflictions. People panicked to the King, and he did not know what to answer them. Khatun said to him: "O King, prudence is a precious object whose newness does not wear out, and a cause whose dear one is not humiliated. It is the King's guide to reforming his kingdom and his deterrent from corrupting it. Your subjects have panicked to you out of extreme inability to resort to One whose glory is not increased by mistreatment of His creation, nor is His kingdom decreased by returning to them with kindness. No one is more worthy of keeping a testament than the trustee, nor of riding the guidance than the guide, nor of good care than the shepherd. We ceased not to be in a blessing not changed by wrath, and in satisfaction not muddied by anger, until fate ran with what sight was blind to and caution gone from. The gift was taken away, and the Taker is the Giver. Return to Him with thanks for blessings and seek refuge in Him from terrible retributions. Whenever you forget Him, He forgets you. Do not make shame of humbling yourself to the One who honors and humiliates a partner between you and your subjects, deserving a blameworthy outcome. But order them and yourself to turn hearts to acknowledging the essence of His power and humbling tongues in supplication with pure thanks to Him. For a King may punish his slave to return him from something he did to a righteous deed, and to reward him for that thanks for what he gains of another favor." He said: The King ordered her to stand among them and warn them with this speech. She did. "They received her preaching with acceptance and returned from the door of the lower king to the door of the Highest King. Allah knew from them the acceptance of preaching, command, and prohibition. A year passed over them, and not one of them was in need of a blessing he was on, and increases of beautiful making followed upon them. To Allah belongs praise and thanks."

**Anecdote:** Abu Bakr "al-Hudhali" said: Abd al-Rahman, the nephew of Al-Asma'i, told us from his uncle Abd al-Malik al-Asma'i who said: A delegation came to Hisham bin Abd al-Malik. Among them was a man from Quraysh called Ismail bin Abi al-Jahm. He was the eldest of them in age and the best in opinion and wisdom. He stood leaning on a staff and said: "O Commander of the Faithful, the orators of Quraysh have spoken and elaborated and praised you and done well. By Allah, their speaker did not reach your worth, nor did their praiser count your virtue. Do you permit me to speak?" He said: "Speak." He said: "Shall I be brief or elaborate?" He said: "Rather, be brief." He said: "May Allah guard you, O Commander of the Faithful, with good, adorn you with piety, and combine for you the Hereafter and the First (life). I have needs; shall I mention them?" He said: "Yes." He said: "My age has increased, my strength has weakened, and my need has intensified. If the Commander of the Faithful sees fit to mend my break and negate my poverty, let him do so." Hisham said: "O Ibn al-Jahm, what mends your break and negates your poverty?" He said: "A thousand dinars, and a thousand dinars, and a thousand dinars." He said: "Far from it, O Ibn Abi al-Jahm! The treasury cannot bear this." He said: "It is as if you swore, O Commander of the Faithful, not to fulfill a need for me in this standing of mine." Hisham said: "Then a thousand dinars for what?" He said: "To pay a debt that has bent my back and burdened me." He said: "Excellent paths you took: a debt you paid and a trust you fulfilled. And a thousand dinars for what?" He said: "To marry off those of my children who have reached maturity, strengthening my arm with them and increasing my number." He said: "No harm; you lowered a gaze, fortified a chastity, and increased offspring. And a thousand dinars for what?" He said: "To buy land with it, returning its surplus to my children and the surplus of its surplus to my relatives." He said: "And no harm; you wanted a store, hoped for a reward, and joined ties of kinship. We have ordered it for you." He said: "Praised be Allah for that, and may Allah reward you, O Commander of the Faithful, and the womb (kinship) with good." Hisham said: "By Allah, I have never seen a man gentler in asking nor kinder in speech than him. Thus should a Qurashi be."

**Anecdote:**

Alqama narrated: Al-Fadl bin Ziyad told me: Abu Zayd bin Nawfal told me: I heard Muhriz bin Najiya al-Rusafi say: I was one of those suspected regarding the money of Egypt in the days of Al-Wathiq. The Sultan sought me intensely until Al-Rusafa and other cities became narrow for me. I went out wanting the desert, seeking a man of mighty protection and impregnable house to seek refuge with and stay with. I ended up at Banu Shayban. A house overlooking the back of a fortified hill was raised for me. In its courtyard was a tied horse and a planted spear, its head shining, and under it a great suit of armor. I approached, dismounted the horse, advanced, and greeted the people of the house. Women returned my greeting from behind the curtain. Then they advanced and lifted the gaps of the curtains with eyes like the eyes of young gazelles. One of them spoke and said: "Rest assured, O urban dweller, for excellent is the camel-place of the friend you have made kneel at." I said: "How can the sought one be safe and the desired one be safe without seeking shelter in a mountain that protects him or a stronghold that defends him? Rarely does the one sought by the Sultan sleep while fear overcomes him." She said: "O urban dweller, your tongue has interpreted a great sin and a small heart. By Allah, you have settled in the courtyard of a house where no one is wronged, and no liver goes hungry, as long as this tribe has a support. This is the house of Al-Aswad bin Qannan. His maternal uncles are Al-Araqim, and his paternal uncles are Shayban. The pauper of the tribe in his wealth, and their master in his deeds. He has protection, the lighting of fire, and the seeking of revenge; he is not disputed nor fought. Amama bint al-Jalah al-Kalbiyya described him saying:
'If you wish to meet a youth whom if you weighed... against every Ma'addi and every Yamani,
He would outweigh them in clemency, generosity, sovereignty... and bravery; this is Al-Aswad bin Qannan.
A youth like the virgin girl, his face shines... as if the glittering of his face is two moons.
A noble, the most pious of the sons of Nizar and Ya'rub... and the most trustworthy in contract by word of tongue.
The most fulfilling of covenant and longest of hand... and most generous in deed in every place.
The most striking with the sword in defense of his neighbor... and the most stabbing in his defense with a spear.
A youth whose like you will never see in your life... for a day of combat or a day of stabbing.
As if gifts and deaths in his palm... are two pouring clouds, heavy with rain.'
He said: I said to her: "The fright has calmed, and the loneliness has stilled. Who will bring him to me?" She said: "O girl, call your master." The girl went out from the back of the house. She stayed only a little until she came with him in a group from the tribe. I looked at a young boy whose mustache had just turned green and his beard hair appeared, and his side was feared. I stood up and greeted. He returned the greeting, welcomed, and brought me near. He said: "Which of the benefactors to us are you?" The woman preceded me and said: "O Abu Murhaf, this is a man who loved your neighborhood and desired your proximity. His homelands rejected him, his Sultan disturbed him, and his time alienated him. We have guaranteed him from you what the likes of you guarantee for the likes of him." He said: "May Allah moisten your mouth." He said: "Sit." I sat, and my hand was in his. He turned his face to the group and said: "O assembly of my father's sons and my relatives, bear witness that this man is in my protection and covenant. Whoever intends him intends me, and whoever plots against him plots against me." Then he ordered a tent pitched for me next to his house and provided me with what I needed. I remained in his protection until Al-Wathiq died, while I was with him in the most pleasant life and most enviable blessings. I departed from him being one of the most grateful people to him.

**Anecdote:** Al-Asma'i mentioned: Abu Hanifa the Judge had a neighbor in Kufa who sang. When he returned drunk, he would sing in his room, and Abu Hanifa would hear him and like it. He used to frequently sing this verse of poetry:
'They wasted me, and what a youth they wasted... for a day of adversity and plugging a breach.'
The night patrol met him one night, took him, and he was imprisoned. Abu Hanifa missed his voice that night. He asked about him the next day and was told he was imprisoned. He called for his black robes and tall hat, wore them, and went early to Isa bin Musa and said: "I have a neighbor whom your patrol took last night and imprisoned, and I have known nothing but good about him." Isa bin Musa said: "Hand over to Abu Hanifa everyone the patrol took tonight." So they were all released. When the youth came out, Abu Hanifa called him and said to him secretly: "Were you not singing, O youth, every night: 'They wasted me, and what a youth they wasted'? Have we wasted you?" He said: "No, by Allah, O Judge, but you did well and were generous, may Allah reward you well." He said: "Then return to what you were singing, for I find comfort in it and see no harm in it." He said to him: "I will do so."

**Anecdote:** It is said a Bedouin came to Talha asking him and approaching him by kinship. He said: "This kinship, no one asked me by it before you. I have land for which Uthman gave me three hundred thousand. If you wish, take it; and if you wish, I will sell it to Uthman and pay you the price." He chose the land, so he ordered its handover.

**Anecdote:**

Abdullah bin Ja'far al-Tayyar, may Allah be pleased with them, came to Yazid bin Muawiyah. The Caliph said to him: "How much did the Commander of the Faithful give you?"—meaning his father (Muawiyah). He said: "He used to give me, may Allah have mercy on him, one million dirhams." Yazid said: "We have ordered the like for you and added for you, to have mercy on him, one million." He said: "By my father and mother you are, may Allah reward you with good for me." He said: "And for this (prayer), one million." He said: "I will not say it to anyone after you." He said: "And for this, one million." He said: "Nothing prevents me from exaggerating in describing you except fear for you from your generosity." He said: "And for this, one million." He carried all the money with him. It was said to him: "O Commander of the Faithful, you distributed the money of the Muslims to one man." He said: "I only distributed it to the people of Medina collectively." Then he appointed someone to know his news without him seeing, who accompanied him. When he entered Medina, he distributed those monies in it until he needed to borrow after a month.

**Anecdote:** Abd al-Malik bin Marwan asked Asma' bin Kharija: "Traits have reached me about you, so tell me them." He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, they are better from others than from me." He said: "I resolved upon you to tell me them." He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, I never extended my leg before a sitter with me, nor did I make food and invite people to it but that they were more gracious to me by their acceptance than I to them, nor did a man ever set his face to me asking a need but that I considered anything I gave him too little."

**Anecdote:** Al-Fadl al-Dabbi reported: Ibn al-Mawla came to Yazid bin Hatim al-Muhallabi and praised him with his poem in which he says:
'O unique one of the Arabs who... has become having no equal.
If there were another like you... there would be no poor person in the world.'
He called his treasurer and said: "How much is in the treasury?" He said: "In it of silver and gold is the value of twenty thousand dinars." He said to him: "Give it to him." Then he said to him: "O brother, apology to Allah and to you; if I had more than this in my possession, you would not have needed it."

**Anecdote:** It is narrated from Laqit who said: Musa Shahawat stood for Yazid bin Khalid bin Yazid bin Muawiyah at his door in Damascus. He was a generous, magnanimous youth. When he rode, he jumped to him, grabbed his beast's rein, and said: "Stand and shout when you come to Damascus:
... O Yazid bin Khalid bin Yazid.
O Yazid bin Khalid, if you answer me... my bird will meet me with the star of happiness."
He ordered five thousand dirhams and clothes for him and said to him: "Whenever you wish, call us, for we will answer you."

**Anecdote:** It is narrated from Hakam al-Wadi who said: Umar al-Wadi brought me in to Yazid while he was on a donkey, wearing a brocade jubba, brocade cloak, brocade boots, holding a pearl necklace, and having something in his sleeve I didn't know. He said: "Whoever sings what I desire gets what is in my sleeve, what is on me, what is with me, and what is under me"—meaning the donkey. They all sang to him, but he was not delighted. Then he said to me: "Sing, O boy." So I sang:
'Her crown is colors, and her face is enchanting... and her mole is unique, having no neighbors.
When she walks, she sways as if she were a snake.'
He was delighted and brought out what was in his sleeve; it was a purse with a thousand dinars. He threw it to me along with the pearl necklace. When he entered, he sent me the donkey and everything on it.

**Anecdote:** Ibrahim bin Khalaf narrated: While Abu Dulaf was walking with his brother Ma'qal bin Isa—they were then in Iraq—they passed a palace. Two slave girls looked out from it. One said to the other: "Is this Abu Dulaf about whom the poet says:
'The world is only Abu Dulaf... between his beginner and his attender.
If Abu Dulaf turns away... the world turns away on his trail.'"
The other said: "Is this him? By Allah, I have loved to see him since I heard what was said about him." Abu Dulaf turned to Ma'qal and said: "We have not been fair to Ali bin Jabala nor fulfilled his right, and that is a great concern of mine." He had given him a thousand dinars.

**Anecdote:** Ibrahim bin Ahmad narrated: Umayya bin Abi al-Salt came to Mecca to Abdullah bin Jud'an. When he entered upon him, Abdullah said to him: "A serious matter brought you?" Umayya said: "The dogs of my creditors have barked at me and bitten me." Abdullah said to him: "You came to me while I am ailing from debts I incurred. Wait for me a little until what is in my hand gathers. I have guaranteed the payment of your debt and I do not ask about its amount." Umayya stayed for days, then came to him and said:
'Do I mention my need or has... your modesty sufficed me? For your nature is modesty.
And your knowledge of rights, while you are a lord... having refined lineage and praise.
A generous one whom neither morning... changes from beautiful character nor evening.
Competing with the wind in honor and generosity... when the dog is forced into its hole by winter.
If a man praises you one day... praise suffices him from exposing himself (asking).
If you succeed Abdullah, know... that the people have no reward.
For your land is every noble deed built by... Banu Tamim, and you are its sky.'

'So he showed his virtue truly over them... The sky appeared to its viewer.
Is the sky hidden from a seer... and is there hiddenness for the sun when it rises?'
When Umayya recited these verses to him, he had two singing girls. He said to Umayya: "Take whichever of them you wish." He took one of them and left. He passed by a gathering of Quraysh. They blamed him for taking her and said: "You have harmed him by taking her from him. If you returned her to him—for the Sheikh needs their service—that would be closer for you with him and more noble than any right he guaranteed for you." The speech affected Umayya, and he regretted. He returned to him to give her back. When he came to him with her, Ibn Jud'an said to him: "Perhaps you only returned her because Quraysh blamed you for taking her and said to you such and such," and he described to Umayya what the people said to him. Umayya said: "By Allah, you have not missed anything of what they said, O Abu Zuhayr." Abdullah said: "So what did you say regarding that?" Umayya said:
'Your giving is an ornament to a man if you gift him... He gives, and not every giving adorns.
It is not a shame for a man to give his face (ask)... to you, as some asking shames.'
Abdullah said to him: "Take the other one." He took both of them and went out. When he came to the people with them, he recited:
'Ibn Jud'an is mentioned with good... whenever the noble are mentioned.
One who does not oppress nor disobey... nor do the mean find him stingy.
He gives the noble she-camel and the noble horse... The men and the reins are his.'

**Anecdote:** Yazid bin Muawiyah entered upon his father and found him looking down. He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, what is this matter that saddened you?" He said: "A matter that has sickened and worried me all day, and I do not know what to do about it." He said: "What is it, O Commander of the Faithful?" He said: "This dissolute Abu Dahbal wrote to your sister Atika with these verses:
'O Atika, will you not, since you were stingy and did not see... for a lover any proximity to you or right,
Return a heart that passion has taken over... and calm an eye that does not tire or dry?
But you stripped the heart with promise and wish... and I never saw generosity or truth from you a day.
So oh my liver! Since I have no sitting with you... to complain of what I suffer from your love and what I meet.
My greatest worry is to see a messenger from you... and all day I sit watching the roads.
I saw you increasing in harshness to the lover... and my heart increasing in love for you every day.'
She has not ceased weeping since today; the malicious one has corrupted her. What do you think about him?" He said: "By Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, the matter regarding him is easy." He said: "What is it?" He said: "A slave of yours lies in wait for him in one of the alleys of Mecca and relieves us of him."

Muawiyah said: "Fie on you! By Allah, a man who wishes for you what he wishes and elevates you to what he elevates is without opinion. You have become distressed by a word, and your reach fell short in it, until you wanted to kill a man of Quraysh for it. Do you not know that if you do that, you prove his words true and make us a tale forever?" He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, he said another poem which the people of Mecca recite to each other, and it traveled until it reached me, paining me and driving me to what I indicated." He said: "What is it?" He said:
'The Mighty King protected meeting her... so before her, perils and killing are feared.
There is no good in a love whose consequence is feared... nor in a lover with whom there is no union.
So oh my liver! I stayed up with her love... and there was not a moment of giving between us.
And oh wonder! I conceal her love... and it spread until the ways to her were cut.'

Muawiyah said: "By Allah, you have relieved me. I was not safe from him having reached her. As long as he complains that there was no union or giving between them, the matter is easier for me. Go away from me and conceal what happened." Yazid stood up and left. Muawiyah performed Hajj that year. When the days of Hajj ended, he wrote the names of the notables and nobles of Quraysh and wrote the name of Abu Dahbal among them. Then he called them and distributed splendid gifts among all of them and rewarded them with many prizes. When Abu Dahbal received his prize and stood to leave, Muawiyah called him. He said to him: "O Abu Dahbal, why do I see Abu Khalid Yazid son of the Commander of the Faithful angry with you regarding biting words confirmed from you, and poetry you continue to utter and is sent to our adversaries and clients? Do not cross Abu Khalid." Abu Dahbal began apologizing to him and swearing he was lied against. Muawiyah said to him: "No harm on you, this does not harm you with us. Are you married?" He said: "No." He said: "Which of your cousins is dearest to you?" He said: "So-and-so." He said: "The Commander of the Faithful has married you to her, paid your dowry of two thousand dinars, and ordered a thousand dinars for you." When he received it, he said: "If the Commander of the Faithful sees fit to forgive me for what passed. If I utter a verse in the meaning of what preceded from me, I have made my blood lawful, and So-and-so whom the Commander of the Faithful married to me is absolutely divorced." Muawiyah was pleased with that, guaranteed to please Yazid with him, promised to continue what he gave him every year, and returned to Damascus. Muawiyah did not perform Hajj that year except for the sake of Abu Dahbal.

**Anecdote:** Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, went out patrolling one night in Medina—he used to do that often. He passed by a woman of the Arabs who had locked her door and was saying:
'This night has grown long and its side black... and it kept me awake that I have no lover to play with.
By Allah, were it not for nothing other than Him... the sides of this bed would have shaken.
And I would have spent the night—were it not an innovation—enjoying... a gentle-bellied one whom companions do not contain.
He plays with me upon the mattresses and sometimes... he blames me in his love and I blame him.
But I fear a Watcher appointed... over our souls whose Watcher does not rest.'
Then she sighed deeply and said: 'Does Ali bin Abi Talib slight my loneliness in my house and my husband's absence from me?' Umar said: 'May Allah have mercy on you. Where is your husband?' She said to him: 'In such-and-such expedition.' He wrote immediately for his return to her and sent her expenses and clothes.

**Anecdote:** Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik had a muezzin who announced prayer times to him in his palace. A muwallad (mixed-race) slave girl of his came to him and said: "O Commander of the Faithful, So-and-so the muezzin does not take his eyes off me when I pass by him." Sulayman was the most jealous of people. He intended to order (punishment for) the muezzin. Then he said: "Adorn and perfume yourself and go to him. Say to him: 'Your looking at me has not been hidden from me, and there is more in my heart from you than in your heart from me. If you have a need, I am available for what you want. This Commander of the Faithful is heedless. If you do not hasten, I will never return to you.'" She went to the muezzin and told him what he said to her. He raised his eyes to the sky and said: "O Majestic One, where is Your beautiful covering?" Then he said: "Go and do not return. Perhaps the meeting will be before the One who does not disappoint expectation." She returned to Sulayman and told him the news. He sent for him. When he entered upon Sulayman, the chamberlain said to him: "The Commander of the Faithful has seen fit to gift you So-and-so and carry to you with her fifty thousand dirhams to spend on her." He said: "Far from it, O Commander of the Faithful! By Allah, I slaughtered my greed for her from the first moment I saw her, and made her a treasure for myself with Allah. I am ashamed to reclaim something I stored with Him." Sulayman tried hard to make him take the money and the girl, but he refused. He used to marvel at him and constantly tell his companions his story.

**Anecdote:** It is told about Al-Mamun that he said: I performed Hajj. When I was in Tyre (Sur), I wanted to enter the monastery of the madmen to see who was there. I entered and saw a handsome young man in clean clothes. I greeted him. He said: "Do you know grammar?" I said: "I know of it what fixes my tongue." He said: "Do you narrate poetry?" I said: "Yes." He said: "Recite to me." I recited to him from Abu al-Atahiya:
'Passion melted my body, flesh, and strength... nothing remained but the spirit and the emaciated body.
I saw passion as ember of Ghada wood, except that... in every case, it is sweet to its owner.'
He fell unconscious. I asked about his story. I learned he was from Banu Tamim; he loved a cousin of his and she loved him. Attempts were made between them until she was taken from him, and they both became obsessed. Here she is in the other monastery. I went until I entered upon her. When she saw me, she sighed deeply then said: "Indeed, I find the scent of Joseph, were it not that you think me senile." She asked me where I came from. I said: "From the monastery," and informed her of the youth's condition. She wept then said:
'By the One who, if He wished, would not have created separation... If you are absent from my eye, you are not absent from my heart.'

'Longing imagines you to me until it is as if... I converse with you from near while you are not near.'
He said: Al-Mamun called and ordered their treatment. They were treated until they recovered. He married the youth to his cousin, assigned them what would improve their condition, and they remained among his entourage until he died.

**Anecdote:** Abdullah bin Tahir was angry with one of his scribes and imprisoned him in a compartment. A slave girl of Abdullah, who was a favorite of his, looked down at him. She looked at the youth—who was cultured—and a look from him met hers. Intense love fell into her heart. She tried to be patient from him but could not. She took a note and wrote in it:
'O you who commits adultery with his eyes... while in the glance are deaths.
If you want a union, then... the tame gazelle has enabled you.'
Then she lowered the note to him with a string. When he read it, he wrote in it:
'If you see me looking... with the eyes, then the heart is chaste.
It is nothing but the fatal look... while the mind is witty.'
When the girl saw him writing an answer in the note, she rejoiced and had no doubt he was more desirous of her. When she raised the note and read it, his refusal saddened her. She turned it over and wrote on its back:
'We wanted you to... gaze at a tame gazelle.
Since you refused, may you... cease not to be an ally to your chains.'
Then she lowered it. When he read it, he wrote in it:
'I did not leave the gazelle because I... was harsh to the gazelle.
But because I feared a Lord... who ceases not to be kind and compassionate.'
She raised the note. When she saw it, that saddened her. She gestured with it to put it in her pocket, but she put it in her clothes without knowing. She entered her compartment. Abdullah came walking on the roof of his palace and passed by the note. He picked it up and recognized the girl's handwriting and the youth's handwriting. He marveled at his chastity and patience from her despite her beauty and loveliness, and she was one of his dearest maids. He entered upon her and found her depressed and sad. He said: "What is this note, O so-and-so?" She said: "May Allah honor the Emir, it is what you saw." He said to her: "Allah is witness over you that he is dearer to you than me." She said: "Yes, by Allah." He said: He ordered the youth, his chains were undone, he clothed him, rewarded him, and said to him: "Take this slave girl with all her possessions as a reward for your chastity, piety, and fear of Allah Almighty." He raised his rank among his scribes, and continued to honor him.

**Anecdote:** Al-Haytham bin Adi said: Yazid bin Qurra al-Shaybani was fierce and formidable. He held the opinion of the Kharijites and did not fear the governors of Iraq. That enraged Al-Hajjaj and affected him. He wrote to Abd al-Malik informing him. Abd al-Malik wrote to him: "Use a stratagem for him; if you can overcome him, strike his neck." Al-Hajjaj called Yazid bin Ruwaym and Jarir bin Yazid, honored them, brought them close, and said to Yazid: "You have the police of Iraq," and to Jarir: "The Land Tax Bureau, if you bring me Yazid bin Qurra." They rode to him and said to him: "The Emir is angry with you, and we fear his anger will reach all your family, so ride to him." He said: "I will not do it. If he looks at me, he will kill me." They said to him: "He will not do it, and you must ride with us." He came with them prepared for death, and his women came out with him. When he entered upon Al-Hajjaj, he said to him: "Are you Yazid bin Qurra?" He said: "Yes." He said: "May Allah kill me if I do not kill you." He said: "I adjure you by Allah not to kill me, for I am the guardian of twenty-four women; there is no man among them other than me, nor do they have a guardian but me." He said: "Who knows that?" He said: "They are at the door." He ordered them brought in. Each one of them said: "Kill me and leave him." He would say: "Who are you?" She would say: "His paternal aunt," or "maternal aunt," or "daughter," or "brother's daughter," or "sister's daughter," until they gathered before him. His sister said:
'O Hajjaj, gift him today to Allah alone... and to the weeping screaming women, a distress.
O Hajjaj, either you bestow a favor... upon him, or you kill us together.
O Hajjaj, how many you will bereave if you kill him... eighteen and two and four.
O Hajjaj, if you heard the weeping of his women... and his aunts ransoming him all night.'
Al-Hajjaj pitied her, wept, imprisoned him, and wrote about his matter to Abd al-Malik describing what happened. He wrote to him: "Pardon him and add his dependents to the stipend." So he did.

**Anecdote:** It was said to Abu Aqil the Eloquent: "How did you see Marwan bin al-Hakam when asking for a need?" He said: "I saw his desire to bestow favor above his desire for thanks, and his need to fulfill the need stronger than the need of the owner of the need."

**Anecdote:** Abu Dulama met Abu Dulaf in his hunting grounds while he was the governor of Iraq. He took the rein of his horse and recited:
'I swore that if I saw you safe... in the villages of Iraq and you possessing wealth,
You would pray upon the Prophet Muhammad... and fill my lap with dirhams.'
He said: "As for the prayer upon the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. As for the dirhams, no." He said to him: "May I be your ransom, do not separate them, by the One I ask not to separate between you and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him." He said: Abu Dulaf borrowed them and they were poured into his lap until they weighed him down.

**Anecdote:** Al-Shaybani said: Ziyad looked at a man from Dabba eating uglily, and he was the ugliest of people in face. He said to him: 'O brother of Dabba, how many are your dependents?' He said: 'Seven daughters, I am more beautiful than them, and they eat more than me.' Ziyad said: 'To Allah is his excellence! How witty is his request. Assign for each of them one hundred and a servant, and hasten their provisions for him and them.' The Dabbi went out saying:
'If you are seeking generosity and bounty... then hasten to Ziyad or a brother of Ziyad.
A man answers you giving his money for praise... when every generous one is stingy with kindness.
Why should I not praise him when... my path is from his kindness and my inherited wealth.'

**Anecdote:** A man came to Ma'n bin Zaida asking for mounts. He said: 'O boy, give him a horse, a workhorse, a mule, a donkey, and a camel. If I knew a mount other than these, I would give it to you.'

**Anecdote:** A scholar wrote to Yazid bin Hatim asking for a connection. He sent him thirty thousand and wrote to him: 'Now then, I have sent you thirty thousand. I do not increase it out of obligation, nor decrease it out of arrogance. I do not exclude you from praise for it, nor cut off your hope by it. Peace.'

**Anecdote:** While Khalid bin Abdullah al-Qasri was in a tent of his, he looked at a Bedouin trotting his camel towards him. He said to his chamberlain: 'If he arrives, do not answer him.' When he arrived, he brought him in. He greeted and said:
'May Allah amend you, what is in my hand is little... so I cannot support the dependents as they increased.
A persistent time threw its chest (weight) upon me... so they sent me to you and waited.'
Khalid said: 'They sent you and waited? By Allah, I will send you back to them with what pleases them.' He ordered a great reward and noble clothes for him.

**Anecdote:** Abu Ubaidah said: Delegations of Arabs gathered at Al-Nu'man bin al-Mundhir. He brought out two burned (striped/decorated) cloaks to them. He said: 'Let the most honorable of Arabs in tribe stand and wear them.' Amir bin Uhaym al-Sa'di stood up, wrapped one around his waist and threw the other over his shoulder. Al-Nu'man said to him: 'Why are you the most honorable of Arabs?' He said: 'Honor and number among Arabs are in Ma'add, then in Nizar, then in Tamim, then in Ka'b, then in Awf, then in Bahdala. Whoever denies this among the Arabs, let him contest me.' The people were silent. Al-Nu'man said: 'This is your state among your people, so how are you in yourself and your household?' He said: 'I am the father of ten, uncle (paternal) of ten, and uncle (maternal) of ten. As for myself, this is my witness.' Then he placed his foot on the ground and said: 'Whoever removes it from its place gets one hundred camels.' No one stood up to him, so he went with the two cloaks.

**Anecdote:** Al-Qahdhami, Ibn Aisha, and Khalid bin Jamal mentioned that Ibn Abi Atiq went to Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn, sons of Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with them, Abdullah bin Ja'far, and a group of Quraysh. He said to them: 'I have a need with a man, and I fear he will reject me in it. I seek your help with your status and wealth against him.' They said to him: 'That is granted to you from us.' They gathered on a day he promised them and went with them to the husband of Lubna. When he saw them, he magnified their coming to him and honored them. They said: 'We have come to you all together for Ibn Abi Atiq's need.' He said: 'It is fulfilled, whatever it may be.' Ibn Abi Atiq said: 'You have fulfilled it whatever it may be, whether family, wealth, or property?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'You gift to them and to me your wife Lubna and divorce her.' He said: 'Then I call you to witness that she is divorced thrice.' The group was ashamed and apologized and said: 'By Allah, we did not know his need. Had we known it was this, we would not have asked you.' Al-Hasan compensated him for that with one hundred thousand dirhams, and Ibn Abi Atiq carried it to him. She remained with him until her waiting period ended, then she asked the people for her father and her husband Qays. She remained with him until he died. Qays praised Ibn Abi Atiq:
'May the Compassionate reward the best reward... for kindness better than a friend.
I have tested all my brothers... and I have not found like Ibn Abi Atiq.
He strove to gather my union after separation... and a view happened in it from the road.
He extinguished a burning in my heart... whose heat choked me with my saliva.'
Ibn Abi Atiq said to him: 'O my beloved, refrain from this praise, for no one hears it but thinks I am a pimp.'

**Anecdote:** Hammad bin Ishaq mentioned: My father told me: I went to Surra Man Ra'a after returning from Hajj. I entered upon Al-Wathiq. He said: 'With what have you gifted me (what's new) of the talk of the Arabs and their poetry?' I said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, a young Bedouin sat with me at one of the stops. I saw from him the sweetest youth I have seen in appearance, speech, wit, and manners. I asked him to recite, so he recited to me:
May rain water the solitary mountain in whose shades... are two gazelles hidden, united.
Whenever they wrap around my neck, they communicate... and their glances steal doubts.
I tried to trick them but could not... and shooting, but they missed me and killed me.'

Then he sighed a sigh I thought cut his intestines. I said: 'What is wrong with you, may my father be your ransom?' He said: 'Behind these two mountains is a grief for me. I have been prevented from passing through these lands, and they have declared my blood lawful. I only enjoy looking at the two mountains as a solace when the pilgrims arrive, then I am prevented from that.' I said to him: 'Increase me from what you said about that.' He recited to me:
'If I arrive at the water among some of his family... presence, then hint at me as if you are joking.
If Hudur asks you about me, tell her... he has changed from his illness and he is well.'
Al-Wathiq ordered the two poems written down for him. After some days, he called me and said: 'Some old women of our house have composed a melody for one of the poems. Listen to it; if you approve it, we will show it, and if you see room for improvement, correct it.' It was sung to us from behind the curtain. It was of utmost quality—and that is what he used to do if he composed something. I said to him: 'By Allah, its composer has done well, O Commander of the Faithful, masha'Allah.' He said: 'By my life?' I said: 'By your life,' and swore to him by what he trusted. He ordered a rotl (cup) for me, and I drank it. Then he took the lute and sang it three times, gave me three rotls to drink, and ordered thirty thousand dirhams for me. After some days, he called me and said: 'A melody has also been composed here for the other poem.' He ordered it sung. My state with it was like the state with the first.
