Then he sang it when he approved it, and I swore to him on its quality three times. He gave me three rotls to drink and ordered thirty thousand dirhams for me. Then he said: 'Have I fulfilled the right of your gift?' I said: 'Yes, O Commander of the Faithful. May Allah prolong your survival, complete your blessing, and may your Lord not deprive me of it from you.' Then he said: 'But you did not fulfill the right of your Bedouin companion nor ask me to know him. Your request has preceded regarding him. I wrote about him to the ruler of Hijaz, ordering him to bring him, propose to the woman, and carry her dowry to her people on his behalf from our money.' I kissed his hand and said: 'Precedence to noble deeds belongs to you, and you are more worthy of them than others.'

**Anecdote:** Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan gave permission to the people one day. A young Bedouin stood before him, lowered his veil, and recited:
'O Muawiyah, O possessor of forbearance, knowledge, and intellect... O possessor of generosity, giving, glory, and virtue.
I came to you when the path on earth narrowed for me... So by Allah, do not cut off my hope of justice.
And take my right for me from the oppressor who... shot me with an arrow whose easiest part was my killing.
He intended to kill me, except that my death... was distant and I had not completed the sustenance of my eating.'
Muawiyah said: 'What is your matter?' He said: 'May Allah make me your ransom. I am a man from the people of Basra. I married a cousin of mine. I was in love with her, and she admired me. Words passed between me and her father like what passes between in-laws, so he withheld her from me. That took from me what only Allah knows. I went to your governor Ibn Umm al-Hakam and complained to him some of what I find. He pitied me and sent for her and her father. They were brought. When he looked at her, she pleased him. He ordered me imprisoned without hearing from her or her father. Then he sent to me to divorce her, but I refused. He tortured me with types of torture. When I feared death, I divorced her. O relief of the distressed, is there a trick? For sadness has stunned me and worry kept me awake.' Muawiyah said: 'By Allah, I have never seen a day like today.' Then he called for inkwell and paper and said: 'Write to him, O boy, and emphasize to him to send her by a deadline.' He wrote at the bottom of the letter:
'I give my God a covenant I will not break... and I absolve myself today from my religion and faith.
If you oppose me in what I wrote... I will make you meat between my eagles.'
The messengers carried the letter, set off, and entered upon him. When he read it, he sighed deeply, re-read it, sighed deeply, then said: 'I wish Muawiyah had left her with me for a year then offered me to the sword.' He ordered her prepared, ordered thirty thousand dirhams for the messengers, and said: 'If Muawiyah gives you a choice, choose me.' She said: 'I say what Allah makes run on my tongue.' He wrote a letter to Muawiyah saying at its bottom:
'Do not break your oath, O Commander of the Faithful, for... I fulfilled your vow with gentleness and possibility.
I have brought a face that has no like... in what people see of jinn and men.
So excuse, for if you saw her image... you would say: What is this? A statue of a human?'
The messengers left and arrived at Muawiyah while the Udhri (Bedouin) was staying. When Muawiyah looked at her, she pleased him. He said to the Bedouin: 'Woe to you! Is there patience from her with great compensation for her?' He said: 'No, by Allah, even if my body and head were separated.' He recited:
'Do not make me, while proverbs are struck by me... like one seeking refuge from the scorching ground in the fire.
By Allah, by Allah, I will never leave her... until I am pillowed in dust and stones.'

Muawiyah became angry and said: 'Choose. If you wish, the Bedouin; if you wish, Ibn Umm al-Hakam; and if you wish, me.' She grabbed the Bedouin's hand and said:
'This one, even if he is in my rags... is more honorable to me than my father and neighbor.
And the owner of dirham and dinar... and command and prohibition with greatness.
I fear, if I did, the heat of the Fire.'
Muawiyah ordered her to wait out her period. When she finished, he married her to the Bedouin, ordered a thousand dinars for her trousseau and a thousand dinars for the youth, and returned him to Basra.

The author, may Allah have mercy on him, said: These are one hundred and fifty anecdotes of the best that is written and the proudest that is mentioned and published. I have appended to that Wondrous Jokes of correct answers, for they are deemed good among sayings as the actions before them are deemed good. Allah is the Guardian of success and prosperity.

**Wondrous Jokes**

**Joke:** Al-Asma'i said: I heard a client of the family of Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, say: Abd al-Malik bin Marwan caught a man who held the view of Shabib the Kharijite. Abd al-Malik said to him: 'Are you not the one saying:
And from us are Suwayd and Al-Batin and Qa'nab... and from us is the Commander of the Faithful, Shabib?'
The man said: 'I did not say it like this. Rather I said: And from us is the Commander of the Faithful, Shabib'—putting 'Shabib' in the nominative case (or accusative as vocative, text says nasb on Ra but Shabib ends in Ba, likely meaning grammatical twist). The estimation was: 'And from us, O Commander of the Faithful, is Shabib.' Thus he negated the Caliphate from Shabib the Kharijite on that day—and the news is famous. Abd al-Malik admired his presence of mind and good excuse, so he released him.

**Joke:** A man said to Yazid bin al-Muhallab in a war: 'Why does your sword cut while our swords do not cut, though we pay high prices for them?' Yazid took his hand and placed it on his heart and said: 'How do you find its stillness?' He said: 'I find it still.' He said: 'With this my sword cuts.'

**Joke:** When Imran bin Hittan was brought as a prisoner to Al-Hajjaj, he said: 'O guard, strike the neck of the son of the adulteress.' Imran said: 'Bad is the manner your family taught you, O Hajjaj. Is there a station beyond death for which I should flatter you? What made you safe from me meeting you with the like?' Al-Hajjaj was ashamed and released him.

**Joke:** Al-Mansur said to Amr bin Ubayd: 'It has reached me that a letter from Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin al-Hasan bin al-Husayn came to you.' He said: 'We have seen a letter for him, but I did not read it, and you know my opinion regarding the Kharijites (rebels).' He said to him: 'Confirm your certainty by swearing.' He said: 'If I lied out of Taqiyya (dissimulation), I would swear to you out of Taqiyya.'

**Joke:** Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf went out hunting. He met a Bedouin and said: 'How is the conduct of Al-Hajjaj among you?' He said: 'Oppressive, tyrannical, may Allah not greet him nor keep him.' He said to him: 'Why don't you complain about him to the Commander of the Faithful Abd al-Malik?' The Bedouin said: 'He, by Allah, is more oppressive and tyrannical than him, may Allah's curse be upon him.' That angered Al-Hajjaj, and he said to him: 'Do you not know who I am?' He said: 'And who might you be?' He said: 'I am Al-Hajjaj.' The Bedouin said: 'And do you know who I am?' He said: 'No, who are you?' He said: 'A client of Banu Abi Thawr; I go mad twice a month, and this is one of them.' Al-Hajjaj laughed and left him.

**Joke:** A Bedouin advanced with an adversary of his to a governor. The governor said to him: 'Speak the truth or I will hurt you with beating.' The Bedouin said to him: 'And you too, act by it (truth), for what Allah promised you for it is greater than what you promised me from you.'

**Joke:** Zurara al-Faqmi narrated: Yazid bin Abi Muslim, Al-Hajjaj's scribe, entered upon Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik after Al-Hajjaj's death and Sulayman's succession. Sulayman said to him: 'Upon the one who preferred you and made you a vizier for himself be the curse of Allah.' Yazid said to him: 'May Allah make me your ransom, O Commander of the Faithful. You looked at me while affairs were turning away from me. Had they been turning towards me, what you belittled of me would have appeared great in your eyes.' Sulayman said to him: 'Do you think Al-Hajjaj has settled in its bottom—meaning Hell—or is he still falling to its depth?' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, he is between your brother and your father, so put him where you wish.' Sulayman was embarrassed.

**Joke:** Al-Farazdaq was reciting his poetry at Al-Mirbad in Basra, and people were gathered around him. Al-Kumayt passed by him as a young boy and stopped. Al-Farazdaq said to him: 'Would it please you that I were your father?' He said: 'As for my father, I want no substitute for him. But it would please me if you were my mother so my father could taste your honey.' Al-Farazdaq said: 'Keep it secret for your uncle, O nephew, for nothing like it has passed me.'

**Joke:** It was said to Zaynab bint al-Zubayr: 'You are thinnest when your husband arrives'—her husband was Anbasa bin Abi Sufyan. She said: 'A free woman does not have intercourse with her husband with a full belly.'

**Joke:** Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan said one day to Ibn Abbas after he went blind: 'O Banu Hashim, how often you are afflicted in your eyes.' Ibn Abbas said: 'And you in your insights.'

**Joke:** Abu Bakr al-Suli said: A man said to Khalid al-Katib, having satirized him obscenely: 'With what face do you meet me?' He said: 'With the face I will meet my Lord with, despite the multitude of my sins.'

**Joke:**

Al-Asma'i said: I met a Bedouin with clean clothes and a handsome face in some desert. I said: 'O Bedouin, from where do you eat?' He said to me: 'If I relied on eating from where I know, my hunger would be long.'

**Joke:** Layla al-Akhayliyya entered upon Al-Hajjaj. He said to her: 'Recite to me the wittiest thing you found witty about Tawba bin al-Humayyir.' She said: 'The wittiest thing I found witty about him is:
"If Layla al-Akhayliyya greeted... me while above me are stones and slabs,
I would have returned the greeting of joy, or... an owl crying from the side of the grave would have hooted to her."
I passed, O Emir, by his grave and greeted him, and I heard that voice from the grave.' Some of Al-Hajjaj's sitters said to her: 'Only lust made you hear that.' She said: 'O Emir, do you permit me to speak to this one?' He said to her: 'Go ahead.' She said: 'O youth, have you ever seen Tawba?' He said: 'No.' She said: 'By Allah, if you had seen him, you would have wished that no virgin remained in your house but became pregnant by him.' It was as if she fed him a stone.

**Joke:** Al-Mu'alla gifted a mirror to Al-Mu'tamir. He said to him: 'How did you come upon a mirror?' He said: 'Whenever I saw your beautiful face in it, you reminded me.' He ordered money for him.

**Joke:** A group gathered at Al-Awza'i's door discussing, and a Bedouin from Kalb was silent. The man said to him: 'Rightly were you named the mutes of the Arabs.' He said: 'O you, did you not know that a man's tongue is for others and his hearing is for himself?'

**Joke:** Al-Mubarrad said: Umara "bin Uqayl" said to me: Abdullah bin Abi al-Samt said to me: 'O Umara, did you not know that Al-Mamun does not see (appreciate) the poet?' I said to him: 'And who sees better than him in it? We recite the verse to him, and he anticipates its second half without having heard it.' He said: 'I recited a verse to him in which I excelled, but it did not move him.' I said: 'What is it?' He said:
"The Imam of Guidance, Al-Mamun, became busy... with religion, while people are busy with the world."
I said: 'You did nothing. You did no more than make him an old woman in her niche with her rosary in her hand. Who will undertake the matter of the world if he is busy from it while he is tasked with it? Should you not have said as "your uncle" Jarir said about Abd al-Aziz bin Marwan:
"He is not a waster of his share in the world... nor does the offer of the world distract him from religion."' 

**Joke:** Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said to a woman: 'By Allah, I will harm you.' She said: 'By Allah, you are not capable of that.' He said: 'How?' She said: 'Can you strip Islam from me?' He said: 'No.' She said: 'Then nothing else harms me.'

**Joke:** He said: Al-Rashid ordered Yahya bin Khalid to demolish the Iwan of Kisra. He said to him: 'Do not demolish a structure that indicates the grandeur of its builder, for you removed his kingdom and weakened his command.' He said to him: 'You have cheated, O Magian.' Then he ordered its demolition. Then Al-Rashid thought and estimated an expense for demolishing it that he found excessive, so he desisted. Yahya said to him: 'It did not befit you to demolish. Since you started, how does it befit you to be unable to demolish something built by another, while demolishing is easier than building?' He knew his advice.

**Joke:** A man said to Al-Ahnaf: 'The trustworthy one informed me bad things about you.' He said: 'The trustworthy one does not gossip.'

**Joke:** The Jews said to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Have you not always been a prophet?' He said: 'Yes.' They said: 'Then why did you not speak in the cradle as Jesus spoke?' He said: 'Allah created Jesus without a stallion. Had he not spoken in the cradle, Mary would have had no excuse when she was blamed as others are blamed, but I was born from two parents.'

**Joke:** It was said to the Messiah, peace be upon him: 'If only you prayed to Allah Almighty to grant you a donkey to protect you and carry your luggage.' He said: 'I am too noble to Allah for Him to make me the servant of a donkey.'

**Joke:** Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: 'We slaughtered a sheep and gave it in charity.' The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Did anything remain of it?' I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, nothing remained of it but its shoulder.' He said: 'All of it remained except its shoulder.'

**Joke:** Al-Mamun said to Ahmad bin Yusuf: 'The owners of charities (zakat collectors) have complained about you.' He said: 'By Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, the owners of charities were not pleased with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, until Allah revealed regarding them: (And among them are those who criticize you concerning alms. If they are given from them, they approve; but if they are not given from them, at once they are angry). So how would they be pleased with me?' Al-Mamun laughed.

**Joke:** Hisham bin Abd al-Malik said to Zayd bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them: 'It reached me that you want the Caliphate, and you are not fit for it because you are the son of a slave woman.' He said: 'Ishmael was the son of a slave woman and Isaac the son of a free woman, yet Allah brought forth from his loin the best of Adam's children (Muhammad).' 

**Joke:** A man said to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: 'O Mother of the Believers, when do I know that I am good (Muhsin)?' She said: 'When you know that you are bad (Musi').' He said: 'When do I know that I am bad?' She said: 'When you know (think) that you are good.'

**Joke:**

It was said to Ruqayyah: 'Why are the Quran readers the most lustful of people?' She said: 'Because Allah wanted their women to be chaste.' It was said: 'Why are they the sharpest (toughest) of people?' She said: 'The Quran is mighty in their chests.' It was said: 'Why are they the most clinging to what is in their hands?' She said: 'Because they earned it lawfully, so they hate to waste it except in its right.'

**Joke:** It was said to Yahya bin Khalid: 'Change your chamberlain.' He said: 'Then who will know my old brothers?'

**Joke:** One of them said to Hisham: 'I hold the view of two (creators/gods).' He said: 'Do you say that one of them creates something without seeking help from the other?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Then what do you do with two? One creating everything is better for you.' He was silenced.

**Joke:** Amr bin al-As said to Adi bin Hatim al-Tai: 'When was your eye gouged out, O Abu Tarif?' He said: 'The day you were stabbed in your rear while fleeing'—meaning the Day of Siffin.

**Joke:** Ma'n bin Zaida entered upon Al-Mansur, walking quickly and taking short steps. Al-Mansur said to him: 'Your age has advanced, O Ma'n.' He said: 'In your obedience, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'Yet you are sturdy.' He said: 'Against your enemies, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'And there is remnant in you.' He said: 'It is for you, O Commander of the Faithful.'

**Joke:** A woman passed by Sa'id bin al-Musayyib while he was set up to be flogged. She said: 'O Sheikh, you have stood a stand of shame.' He said: 'From a stand of shame I fled.'

**Joke:** Al-Rashid said one day to Sharik the Judge: 'O Sharik, a verse in the Book of Allah in which neither you nor your people have a share.' He said: 'What is it, O Commander of the Faithful?' He said: (And indeed, it is a remembrance for you and your people). Sharik said: 'And another verse, O Commander of the Faithful, in which neither I nor my people have a share.' He said: 'What is it?' He said: (But your people denied it, while it is the truth).

**Joke:** Abdullah bin Safwan complained of his tooth. A man came to visit him and said: 'What is wrong with you?' He said: 'Toothache.' He said: 'Did you not know what Iblis says?' He said: 'He says its cure is breaking.' Abdullah bin Safwan said: 'Only his allies obey Satan.'

**Joke:** A commander inspected his troops. A man with a bad sword passed by him. He said to him: 'Woe to you! What is this sword? Did you not know that a man is by his sword?' He said: 'May Allah amend the Emir, it is but commanded.' He said: 'This is of what was commanded not to cut anything.' So he replaced it with another.

**Joke:** Al-Mamun entered upon the mother of Al-Fadl bin Sahl to console her for her son Al-Fadl. He said to her among what he said: 'You only lost seeing him, so do not panic, for I am your son in his place.' She said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, a man who benefited me with you as a son is worthy that I grieve for him.'

**Joke:** A man said to Thumama: 'You cannot delay what Allah advanced nor advance what Allah delayed.' He said: 'This is of two types. If you mean that I make the donkey's head its tail, then no. If you mean I advance Muawiyah over Ali when Allah delayed him, then yes.'

**Joke:** A man said to Hisham al-Qurti: 'How much do you count?' He said: 'From one to a million or more.' He said: 'I did not mean this.' He said: 'How many teeth do you count?' He said: 'Thirty-two teeth, sixteen upper and sixteen lower.' He said: 'I did not mean this.' He said: 'How many years do you have?' He said: 'By Allah, I have none of them; the years all belong to Allah Almighty.' He said: 'O you, what is your age (sinn, also tooth)?' He said: 'Bone.' He said: 'Son of how many are you?' He said: 'Son of two, a man and a woman.' He said: 'How much has come upon you?' He said: 'If anything came upon me, it would kill me.' He said: 'So how should I say?' He said: 'Say: How much of your life has passed?'

**Joke:** Abdullah bin Jabir said to a steward of his: 'Where to, O Haman?' He said: 'I build a tower for you.'

**Joke:** Umar bin Abd al-Aziz said to Nu'aym bin Salama al-Himyari jokingly: 'Your people are those who said: "Our Lord, lengthen the distance between our journeys," and wronged themselves.' Nu'aym said: 'What your people said is worse, O Commander of the Faithful, when they said: "O Allah, if this is the truth from You, then rain down upon us stones from the sky or bring us a painful punishment."' Umar smiled.

**Joke:** Bilal bin Abi Burda said to Ibn Abi Alqama: 'I only invited you to mock you.' Ibn Abi Alqama said: 'If you do that, then one of the two judges has mocked the other.'

**Joke:** Muawiyah said one day to the people of Sham, while Aqil bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, was with him: 'Have you heard the saying of Allah Almighty: (May the hands of Abu Lahab be ruined, and ruined is he. His wealth will not avail him...)?' They said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Abu Lahab is the uncle of this man'—pointing to Aqil. Aqil said: 'O people of Sham, have you heard His Almighty's saying: (And his wife is the carrier of firewood. Around her neck is a rope of [twisted] fiber)?' They said: 'Yes.' He said: 'She is the aunt of this man'—pointing to Muawiyah.

**Joke:**

It is said: Mubarak the Turk passed by Ibn Ayyub al-Makki who was standing at the bridge gate. He said: 'O Abu Ayyub, how do you see this horse?' He said: 'Excellent.' He said: Then they passed towards the Saudi minaret (or similar landmark). Ayyub said to him: 'Where did you come from?' He said: 'From Al-Qasr (the palace).' 'Do you have a need, O Abu Ayyub?' He said: 'Yes, to catch Mubarak and give him the Sin and take the Sad.' (A play on words/letters, possibly implying changing something bad to good or a specific context).

**Joke:** A man said to Aqil bin Abi Talib—who was wondrous in answers: 'Indeed there is beauty in you, O Banu Hashim.' He said: 'It is in the men among us and in the women among you.'

**Joke:** A man from the descendants of Abu Jahl said to Sharik: 'Did Ali use to perform Qunut in Fajr?' He said: 'Yes, and curse your father in it.'

**Joke:** It was said to Abu al-Aliya al-Riyahi: 'How are you this morning?' He said: 'Contrary to what Allah loves, contrary to what Satan loves, and contrary to what I love.' It was said to him: 'How is that?' He said: 'Because Allah loves that I obey Him and not disobey Him, and I am not like that. Satan loves that I disobey Allah and obey him (Satan), and I am not like that. And I love not to grow old or become poor or die, and I am not like that.'

**Joke:** It is said a man spoke before Al-Mamun and babbled, then said: 'Shall I be silent, O Commander of the Faithful?' He said: 'Have you spoken?'

**Joke:** Al-Mubarrad mentioned that a man came to the governor of Basra. This governor had been assigned by Al-Mansur to manage provisions for the rules (qawa'id) among women who have no husbands, and for the blind and orphans. He said to him: 'I ask you, O Governor, to register me with the rules among women.' He said to him: 'Those are women, so how can I register you among them?' He said: 'Then among the blind.' He said: 'As for this, yes, because Allah Almighty says: (For indeed, it is not eyes that are blinded, but blinded are the hearts which are within the breasts).' He said to him: 'And favor me by registering my son among the orphans.' He said: 'And that too; whoever you are the father of is an orphan.' He left having been registered among the blind and orphans.

**Joke:** It was said to Ibn Imran: 'Al-Mukhtar bin Abi Ubayd claims that revelation comes to him.' He said: 'Allah Almighty spoke the truth: (And indeed do the devils inspire their allies).' 

**Joke:** Al-Hasan bin Sahl sent to Dinar bin Abdullah: 'What is your religion?' He sent back to him: 'I did not think a living person would ask about this question; I thought it was only for Munkar and Nakir. My religion is Islam and obedience to the Emir.'

**Joke:** A man said to Ibn Uqab: 'Inform So-and-so of my thanks.' He said: 'Say it so I can hear.'

**Joke:** A man said to Sa'id bin Abd al-Malik the scribe: 'Do you command anything (shay')?' He said: 'Yes, fear of Allah and dropping the Alif of "shay'".'

**Joke:** Al-Nu'man ordered Adi bin Zayd to be shackled. When he was shackled, he laughed. It was said to him: 'Do you laugh while you are shackled?' He said: 'I am weeping for the one who will untie it.'

**Joke:** Two men met, a Qurashi and an Ansari. The Qurashi belittled the Ansari. He said: 'Ansari, from whom are you?' He said: 'From Quraysh.' He said: 'Quraysh are three categories: a category we sheltered and helped, a category we bestowed favor upon, and a category we killed. So who are you?'

**Joke:** It is said a man spoke in Ibn Abbas's assembly and confused things. Ibn Abbas said: 'With the speech of the likes of you, birds are provided with love (or grain/sustenance?).'

**Joke:** A man said in Abu Hanifa's assembly: 'I never lied.' Abu Hanifa said: 'As for us, we testify against you with this one.'

**Joke:** Al-Farazdaq looked at a sheikh from Yemen and said: 'As if he is the old woman of Saba'.' The Yemeni said: 'The old woman of Saba' is better than the old woman of Quraysh. This one said: (My Lord, indeed I have wronged myself, and I submit with Solomon to Allah, Lord of the worlds), and that one is the carrier of firewood.'

**Joke:** Abd al-Malik met his brother Abd al-Aziz when he returned from Egypt on a thousand camels. Abd al-Malik said to him: 'On how many was the start?' He said: 'On three hundred camels.' Abd al-Malik said: 'No caravan is more deserving to be told: (O caravan, indeed you are thieves) than this one.'

**Joke:** He said: Adi bin Arta'ah, the Emir of Basra—who was of Bedouin nature—came to Iyas bin Muawiyah, who was the judge then, in his court. He said: 'O you, where are you?' He said: 'Iyas is between you and the wall.' He said: 'Listen to me.' He said: 'To listen I sat.' He said: 'I married a woman.' He said: 'With harmony and sons.' He said: 'And I stipulated to her family not to take her out of their house.' He said: 'Fulfill the condition for them.' He said: 'And I want to go out.' He said: 'In the safety of Allah.' He said: 'Judge between us.' He said: 'I have done so.' He said: 'Against whom did you judge?' He said: 'Against your cousin (yourself).'

**Joke:** Al-Mada'ini said: Amr bin al-As entered upon Muawiyah while he was having lunch. He said: 'Come, O Amr.' He said: 'Enjoy, O Commander of the Faithful, I ate just now.' He said: 'Did you not know, O Amr, that it is gluttony for a man not to leave in his stomach room for more for one who asks for more?' He said: 'I have done so, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'Woe to you! For whom did you keep it? For one who has more right than the Commander of the Faithful? I see you only wasted a right for a right you may not reach.' Amr said: 'And what have I encountered from you, O Muawiyah?' Then he approached and ate.

**Joke:**

A group of Kharijites said to Muhammad bin al-Hanafiya: 'Why did your father risk you in wars and not risk Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn?' He said: 'Because they are his eyes and I am his right hand, so he defends his eyes with his right hand.'

**Joke:** One of them was asked about his state at death. He said: 'What is the state of one who wants a long journey without provision, comes to a Just King without an argument, and inhabits a desolate grave without a companion?'

**Joke:** It is said Quraysh boasted at Muawiyah's, and Al-Hasan bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, was with him not speaking. Muawiyah said: 'What prevents you from speaking, O Abu Muhammad? For by Allah you are neither tonguetied nor of mixed lineage.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, by Allah they did not mention a nobility or virtue but that I have its pure essence and core.' Then he recited:
'Why the argument when I have surpassed, excelling... the surpassing of the fast horse in the extending field?'

**Joke:** Marwan was brought a man taken for his nephew's crime. The man said: 'How am I taken for my nephew when I have no knowledge of what he did?' Marwan said to him: 'Do you narrate poetry?' He said: 'No.' He said: 'Have you not heard the poet's saying:
"Your criminal is the one who commits a crime against you, yet... the healthy are infected by the scabby camel."' 
The man said: 'But Allah Almighty says: (And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another).' Marwan said: 'Allah spoke the truth and Marwan lied. Let him go.'

**Joke:** Abu al-Ayna' entered one day upon Al-Mutawakkil. Al-Mutawakkil said to him: 'I have missed you, O Abu al-Ayna'.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, the slave misses his master, while the master summons his slave whenever he wants.' He said: 'Why do you not visit us often?' He said: 'My donkey was stolen, O Commander of the Faithful.' He said: 'How was it stolen?' He said: 'I was not with the thief to inform you.' He said: 'Why didn't you come to us on another?' He said: 'Preventing me from that is the lack of my wealth, the obligation of borrowing, and the humiliation of the donkey renter.' Al-Mutawakkil said to him: 'How excellent your qualities would be were it not for evil in you.' He said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, I am a storehouse of good and evil. Allah Almighty has praised and blamed. He said in His praise: (Excellent is the servant, indeed he was repeatedly turning back). And He said in His blame: (A slanderer, going about with calumnies). The poet said:
"If I do not praise the people of good for good... and do not blame the mean, blame-worthy wretch,
Then how would I know good and evil by name... and why did Allah split for me hearing and a mouth?"'

**Joke:** It is told that Al-Mamun was separated from his army and passed by an Arab tribe. He looked at a boy standing filling a waterskin and shouting: 'O father, catch the mouth (fah), for the mouth (fuh) has overcome me; I have no power over the mouth (fih).' He said: Al-Mamun marveled at his eloquence despite his young age. He said to the boy: 'Who are you, may Allah bless you?' He named himself. Then he said: 'And who are you?' He said: 'Al-Mamun from the sons of Adam.' He said: 'You spoke the truth. From which sons of Adam?' He said: 'From their best.' He said: 'Then you are from the Arabs; from which of them?' He said: 'From their best.' He said: 'Then from Mudar; from which of them?' He said: 'From their best.' He said: 'Then from Quraysh, by the Lord of the Kaaba; from which of them?' I said: 'From their best.' He said: 'Then from Banu Hashim, by Allah; from which of them?' I said: 'I am the one whom all Banu Hashim envy.' He said: He moved away from me and said: 'Peace be upon you, O Commander of the Faithful, and Allah's mercy and blessings.' Al-Mamun said: 'By Allah, his intelligence pleased me. I said to him: Which is more beloved to you: one hundred dinars immediately or ten thousand dirhams delayed?' He said: 'I do not sell an immediate for a delayed.' While we were like that, a weak old man came out of the house. I tried to take the boy. He said: 'I am a perishing old man, and he has a mother like me in old age and weakness, and we have no one but him, so do not deprive us of him.' I ordered one hundred dinars for him and left.

**Joke:** A poet entered upon Abdullah bin Tahir and recited good poetry to him. A Bedouin was present. The poet said: 'Who is the man?' He said: 'From the non-Arabs (Ajam).' The poet said: 'What do the non-Arabs have to do with poetry? Only Arabs compose poetry, and no non-Arab composes it unless an Arab jumped upon his mother.' The non-Arab said to him: 'And whoever among you does not compose poetry, a non-Arab has jumped upon his mother.' He silenced him.

**Joke:** Sharik the Judge entered upon Al-Mahdi. Al-Rabi' said to him: 'You betrayed the money of Allah, O Sheikh, and the money of the Commander of the Faithful.' Sharik said to him: 'If that were so, your share would have come to you.'
